text: Orange-amber pour with a finger of beige head. Malty, buttery caramel. Just a touch of spice in the finish.

2016 bottle. Mostly clear orange amber with an average off white head that leaves little lacing. Aroma is malty with floral hops and toffee. Taste is full of rich roasted malts, toffee, caramel, and sticky, somewhat bitter hops. Thicker and lingering sweetness. Slight alcohol presence.
Pan, cereal, confitería y alcohol. Cuerpo maltoso, y final seco con presencia de alcohol.

Az Avery következő, mostanában beszerzett főzete egy duplabakként megjelölt, "imperial oktoberfest lágerként" hirdetett ital, melynek címkéjéről II. Vilmos köszön vissza ránk, ízig-vérig német jelleget kölcsönözve ezáltal a palacknak. A benne lapuló sör kinézete és aromái is a germán hagyományok mentén haladnak, a réz színű italból édesen malátás, karamellás foszlányok szűrődnek ki. Csemegeszerű jegyek, melyek által a kóstolás egyszersmind rendkívül veszélyes tereppé is válhat, amennyiben a világos italok leggyakoribb buktatói között számon tartható ragacsos illatok kellő támogatás ígéretének hiányában, tartalmatlan, gyengécske testből röppennek fel. Ez esetben azonban ilyesmiről szó sincs, s ilyenkor rögtön felértékelődik a mézes-mázos aromahalmaz: a szerkezet megfelelő alapul szolgál az édeskedéshez. Vaskos malátakötegek között bukkannak fel a süteménytésztás, élesztős, enyhén aszalványos beütésű elemek, majd egy halványan sós, közepesen száraz, fűszeresen komlós levezetés zárja a sort. Mindeközben a kortyok szabása ideális, kerekded jellegűek, nem élesek, tartalmasak, teltek. Nem feltétlenül az én terepem a lágerek világa, ezért csupán óvatosan jegyzem meg, hogy a duplabak besorolás némi fenntartással kezelendő.
Draft at the Casual Pint, Omaha. Pour was amber with a beige head. Aroma was malty, nuts, caramel. Taste was medium sweet, malts, light alcohol, dough.

Draught @ Albion. Dark amber-copper with very small frothy beige head, faint malt aroma, medium carbonation, sweetish caramelized malt taste with little bitterness, alcohol undertones, medium malty finish with alcohol aftertaste. Quite potent and has significant alcohol bite.

Aroma: rich malt mixed with grassy hops
Taste: intensive malt with some notes of citrus. Hoppy aftertaste (pine and grass). I dont know why its in doppelbock style. Treated it as lager or marzen. 
Impressive beer (not as doppelbock!!!)

Bottle (1 pint, 6 oz); 2016: 9.5% ABV. pours copper color with light beige head that dissipates quickly; some lacing. Bread malt with spicy notes. Caramel, apple, and bread crust. Some subtle spiciness and alcohol in the finish. Medium-full body. Very good overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber. Hazy orange with no head. Toffee, buttery, bourbon and almond aromas. Butterscotch flavor with a grassy aftertaste. Heavy body with oily feel.

Really like the Dictator series. An interesting mix of styles for this one. Nice imperial presence with a sweetness that extends beyond the usual malty Oktoberfest flavors

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very malty. Nuts and caramel, sweet and full. A hint of spice and a touch of hops, but not enough to sway things.

Clear , copper color. Aroma of toasted malt and overripe fruits . Very sweet, malty taste with notes of raisins and hint of alcohol. Floral , hoppy bitterness at the end.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear red copper pour with an off white head. Aroma is dates, bread, caramel, and some berry. Taste is caramel, toast, dates, and raisin. Medium body.

22oz bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, Batch No 13, Aug 2016, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Smells of ripe fruit, cracker malt and dry biscuit with hints of seawater and butterscotch. Pours a deep coppery red with a profusion of carbon dioxde bubble all over the glass and two fingers of pillowy white head. Flavor profile is ripe fruit and seawater followed by malt and biscuit with a long finish of fruit with a mild but distinctive alcohol burn, giving away the Imperial classification. Not too much though. Medium bodied, slightly sweet and mouthcoating with exactly the right amount of carbonation making this supremely easy to drink for a 9.5% brew. An excellent beer. Oktoberfest is not a preferred style for me, but the strength and balance of this one make up for a lot. May have to pick this one up again next year. Nicely done Avery.

Pours a clear golden brown from the bomber with fluffy cream colored head that leaves good lace. Aroma of nice malty sweetness and a hint of earth. Taste follows, clean and easy, to style, but a warming booze on the way down. Good for what it is.
Aroma is strong caramel/toffee, bread/malts and light fruit. The flavor is strong caramel/toffee, malts, fruit, slightly grainy and a mix of alcohol and slightly cloying sweetness in the finish.

Bottle at Seattle tasting. As part of an epic vertical. Rating the 2015 bottle. Rich, darker copper, ring tan head. Fig and orange, rich, tart alcohol. Good take on imp lager. Fresh, tart alcohol. Not bad at all. (older versions were much sweeter, with more reduced flavors)
copper color with a thin white head. aroma is yeast, nuts, and a little booze. Flavor is bread, sweet caramel, and nut. very sweet but in a good way.

Bottle; pours dark amber with a white head; dominant caramel aroma with some hints of nuts, bread dough, and floral notes; taste is sweet with caramel and hints of dough and nuts; finish is sweet with a hint of alcohol; very good

22 oz bottle poured at the tasting, as part of a vertical. Rating the current. Pours golden with a caramely, grainy aroma. Flavor is caramel malts with minimal spice. It was fun to try many years of this, but I believe its by far best when fresh. Good beer here.
Bottle - Sweet, a bit boozy and grains. Clear copper with a decent white head. Sweet, boozy caramel and a long swee finish.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a cloudy reddish color with a thine beige head. Taste is of malt, yeast, banana, caramel, fruit, spice and alcohol. Has a similar aroma. Has a lighter, boozy body. Similar, near burning finish. Overall, it has some good initial flavors, but is too alcoholic and not drinkable.

Pours nicely into an oversized dimpled mug. Aroma is alcohol, fruit, and metal. Taste is very sweet, but not annoyingly sweet. Sort of a brandy without the burn. What an excellent surprise. Warms as it goes down.
A very fine oktoberfest brew. Aroma and appearance would be difficult to beat. The floral tones in the taste sets me back and is my reason for the low rating. One must know I favor stouts overall.

This beer poured a very transparent copper with a white head and ample carbonation. The aroma is indistinct and mostly grainy. The taste is also grainy with a variety of malts imparting some flavors of honey and toffee and other lightly sweet and toasty elements. There is little bitterness and not the body I expected from an imperial - the alcohol is well hidden. Overall, it is not a great festbier or a great imperial and I was disappointed.

Draft at Moriartys. Mostly clear deep orange amber. Slim fizzy tan ring. Sweet dried amber fruit. Dried apricots. Molasses. Dark velvet caramels. Dark toasted malts. Wildflower honeycomb. Hints of blood orange, currants and black cherry. Sticky mouthfeel. High ABV only half hidden. Sweet, dark fruity syrupy cordial. Cinnamon pepper finish. There are hints of re-toasted wheat flavors in the background, but this feels ultimately like a clever tricky Quad.

Aroma: caramel, pineapple
Appearance: clear copper, white head
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate: full body, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Delicious
Clean copper pour, off white head. Nose is solid malt. Sweet. Middle is full bodied malt. Finish is slightly spicy and warm. Amazingly balanced.

Nice. Bottle from Connecticut wines. Pours light brown with some minimal head and lots of lacing. Nose is plums. Flavours of plum, caramel, cheerios, some floral, some spice. Taste med/light sweet, med/light bitter. Medium body, lively carbonation with a spicyness to the finish. Nice beer!! Alcohol very well hidden.
Aroma is great. Flavor is caramely Octoberfest. Mild and easy to drink. Really good beer.

Nice smooth and balanced Oktoberfest. Has that perfect blend of malt, caramel, slightly sweet flavor you would expect. Deep auburn color with the sweet malty aroma. There is a reason why this is one of the highest rated Oktoberfest.

Batch #12, August 2015. 9.3% ABV. Pours a crystal clear amber color, with a tan head. Aroma of malts and sugar. Taste is smooth, sweet, malty, and very drinkable. A nice Marzen, with a bit of a kick...Thumbs up on this one.
UPDATED: DEC 26, 2015 Drinking 2013. This hits you with the alcohol up front. It has a bit of a smoother finish than other octoberfests.
Bomber from Brian....2014 vintage....love the nose on this one....tons of flavors going on....mouth was also very nice...smooth....
Bottle. Pours a dark red color. Aroma and taste are malts, caramel, and toffee.

Rated based on notes taken Sep 2012 -- Im assuming this is the 2011 version since a 2012 isnt listed. This beer fucking rocks. An imperial Oktoberfest super malty, hint of booze; what else do you honestly need? Like German style beers? Drink this one.

Aroma barnyard, caramel, 
Appearance clear, tan foam, 
Taste medium sweetness, 
Palate medium body, slick feel, lively, long finish, 
Overall a very sweet malty beer thats good for one 12oz or a bomber. I would suggest this beer to a friend
As a Malt head, and a devotee to German Beers this is hand down the best beer in the world. Prost!!!!

Caramel and toffee nose with a mystery fruit lingering in the back. I love the intrigue of the flavor! Raisin, floral, resin, with lots of malt finish. This is a great fall beer. I plan to age one for this fall and one for next. Compare the changes in flavor

light beige head with thick bubbles some lacing. amber colour. aroma is toffee, caramel, nuts, oxidised like barley wine, boozy. taste like aroma, sweet, malty with a slight wry finish. quite dense body, medium carbonation. bottle / 2014 version
Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours dark copper with a foamy beige head and a floral malty aroma. There is a full-bodied sweet caramel malt flavor with some smoke and a more bitter finish.
Old rating. Nice solid big fall beer. Amber color. Generously robust malts, light earthy hop profile. Some sweetness and booziness.

Pours a brilliant copper from a bottle, minimal lacing. Aroma is of a sweet tobacco, not processed but dried tobacco leaves, with some boozy esters. Flavor is reminiscent but not exactly creme brulee, with its bitter burnt sugar, and sweet cream/custard. A very pleasant heat in the throat. Great beer.
On tap. Light aroma of hops and malts. White foamy head around the rim. Awesome rich flavour of banana, plum and other fruits. Great full bodied palate.
Perfectly and abundantly splendid. Strong and plentiful malt notes. Smooth lager. A wee bit of alcohol heat. Everything a lager should be, times imperial.
Great color: deep shimmering amber. Light caramel nose bit huge caramel taste. Just big and Malty everywhere. Alcohol intensifies it all. Smooth feel. Fab lager.
Nice deep Amber color with a gorgeous white fluffy head. Great almond caramel dough nose! Smooth light taste, a bit fast going. Caramel and some alcohol notes lingering.

Smells of chocolate very pleasing! Some malt after taste it's very pleasing!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled from 22oz bottle in pint glass.

Appearance: pours a modest off white head that slowly falls with mild lacing. Color is a cloudy amber with mild streaming carbonation.

Aroma: rich aroma of caramel, tangerine, and bread dough.

Mouthfeel; light to medium bodied, quite sticky, with a dry and warming alcohol finish.

Flavor: caramel, toasted bread, raisin, cinnamon, tangerine are all prominent.

Overall: nothing to criticize with this beer. Quite delicious.

Pours a cloudy amber with a tan head and lacing. It has a nice aroma of piney and earthy hops and amber malt. The flavor is sweet malt up front with a sweet, malty backbone and finish al box with some earthy hops.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Copper body with a large head.Distinctly floral flavors show rich caramel and toffee that combine with a long, spicy hop finish, turning a bit sweet and hot as it lingers.
On draft. Aroma of liquid caramel. Flavors of... pumpkin, but not quite sweet that way. Spice? Nutmeg? And lots and lots of caramel? Marvelous.

Location/Date:Bottle on 11/08/2014 split with Jay and friends.
Appearance: Pours a dark red cloud.
Aroma: Aroma of caramel, nuts..
Taste: Malty and complex, caramel..
Palate:Medium body, hard to tell the alcohol percentage.
Summary: This was really interested. Definitely more alcohol than normal Oktoberfest but covers it well. Complex, really enjoyable.

pretty red brown pour. Aroma berries special grain tang. Tastes horse grain, honey, nutmeg, caramel. Some astringency from roasts. lactic. complexity Hops let themselves be known with spicy basil. Sweeeet linger, light on the tongue spritzy.

Everything you would expect from a great "Imperial Oktoberfest" Märzen. Id add that this is the best one Ive ever had, if this also wasnt the only "Imperial Oktoberfest" Ive ever heard of! 
Its a very spicy brown märzen thats beautiful from pour to empty glass.

Bottled August 14, 2014.
Glass: Forgotten Boardwalk tulip.
Appearance: Crystal clear copper body with a creamy light tan head. The head has good retention and leaves a light coating with a latte like ring.
Aroma: The aroma is malty with brown sugar and cherry with a very light floral presence. Sweet but not indicating cloying.
Taste: Big and malty, caramel and brown sugar noted with biscuit and some butter. Fruity fig and cherry undertones are plenty with a dash of perfume like hops on the finish. Finish has a mild medicinal presence and comes off mildly sweet.
Palate: Medium to thick bodied with light carbonation.
Overall: This is a solid as heck beer, whatever they want to call this. Its complex but straightforward at the same time. Big, malty and very drinkable.

香りは少ない
&
Bottle (12oz $7): clear reddish color with small white head. Smells and tastes sweet. Too sweet I think.

Aroma:Big malty and candy nose 
Appearance: Reddish light brown with beige head
Taste: Super sweet lightly smoke malty flavor with some tobacco and apple
Overall: An archetypal doublebock. One of the better American versions youll find.

"closer resembles a sweet dopplebock in the nose and flavor than a regular marzen/oktoberfest. i didnt quite know what to expect here. it was pretty good, and somewhat unique, but overall was a little too sweet to be a highly drinkable brew. pours a good looking copper orange with a thin white head. smells and tastes of sweet malt. mouthfeel is a little thick, and the alcohol is apparent, but not overpowering. Finish is nice. Overall, glad i tried it, but probably wont get another for the price for a long while. If you like sweet big beers this ones for you."
Nice amber color. First fast is of sweet malt followed by a long smooth finish
Bomber into a pint glass. Pours an orange/amber, with a moderate white head. Decent lacing. Nose is malt. Taste is malt, with some sweetness. Creamy mouth feel, and a long, pleasant finish. Yum.
Draft @ Yardhouse. Light malty aroma. Clear reddish brown color. Nice malty flavor, with a noticeable alcohol. Medium bodied. Overall, a very nice Oktoberfest.

Pours a clear copper with a rich, large, tan head with an orangish hue. Marshmallow, a slight note of sour, and toasted malt on the nose. Full-bodied, a bit of a carbonation burn on the rear of the tongue, and some creaminess in the front of the palate. Marshmallow creamy flavor toasted malt, bit giving way to a pretty evident alcohol flavor.

Dark orange tan in color... Aroma of sweet toffee, caramel, oak, vanilla and spices... Flavor is fairly sweet, caramel and toffee notes, light spices, oak, cinnamon... Hint of booze on finish... Really enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours beautiful dark copper, Crystal clear, and almost no head. Minimal aroma - what it does have is fruity, malty, and that of spicy noble hops. Taste is complex! Caramel, marshmallow, spicy, pumpkin-like with a bit of EtOH. Mouthfeel is mod viscous. Ends with spicy and hoppy. Great beer. Easy to drink. Would think its a great pumpkin beer if I didn't know any better 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is awesome. Had good expectations and this blew it away. Partly because the name is close to mine, but mostly because it kicks ass. Clear red pour at Dukes in Crystal lake. Foamy white head coating the whole snifter glass. Sweet fruit punch aroma. Bourbon tropical happiness. Bubblegum. Maybe a little carmel. Just an enjoyable little treat

Poured a beautiful copper colour with a thick off white head. Sweet caramel amd bready aroma with a bit of the alcohol poking through. Flavor of caramel, roasted nuts, malt and sweet toffee with a slightly bitter after taste. Great beer.

22oz bomber poured into a Belgian tulip glass. The aromas are notably sweet, almost candy-like, with prevalent aromas of melon, tangerine, and orange, some fresh baked bread, a light caramel late, and a faint doughy / damp aroma. It pours an orange-brown color with just a hint of haze and is topped by a foamy, rocky, off-white head that leaves behind a sticky puffy lace that forms messy layers along the glass. The beer retains a thick, uneven surface layer that resembles creamy, puffy islands. The taste is a medium high sweet with a medium bitter. The full bodied beer has a thick texture with a sudsy and soft carbonation. Abundant toffee, burnt toast, roasted nuts, and brown sugar come through on the palate and it finishes with a spice and citrus quality, along with a faint toasted grain. The aftertaste is a clingy, buttery, brown sugar-esque character.

Wow this was an awesome Oktoberfest! Sweet aromas of toffee, caramel, dough and just a hint of alcohol. Pours a beautiful burnt orange color with a big white head. Flavors are sweet but not cloying. The alcohol is hidden well. Medium bodied.

Draft at CFB. Deep amber pour with a frothy white head and tons of lace, very nice looking beer. Aroma of toasted bread, dark fruits, light toffee and caramel, herby hops and floral notes. Flavor is big bold, malt character with the above mentioned flavor descriptors. Although heavy in body its not cloying and would be nice on an autumn night.
Draft at craft ale house. Pours clear brown with a medium sized off white head. The aroma is toast, bready, slight booze. The taste is a bit of caramel, biscuit, booze. Meh.
On tap at Colorado Plus. Copper and clear appearance with a small head. Aroma and flavor of noble hops, big malts, light floral notes and light spices. Pretty solid, interesting rendition.

Bomber from Julios. Poured into a snifter. Waited for it to warm up to rate. It is a clear deep amber colored brew with a light tan head that settles to a thin lace. Aroma is of strong roasty malts and booze. Flavor is on the sweet side, but better as it warms. Balance is OK. Decent hop finish.
Draft. Brown/amber pour with creamy tan head. Aroma is nutmeg, allspice, spruce. Spicy on the draw but not overly so...warming and rich. Not the best Oktoberfest out there but not bad.

Bottle. Ruby copper. Caramel, bready malts, and toffee aroma. The taste follows with some booze, apple, brown sugar, and a touch of raisin. Full body with medium carb and high abv at 10% especially for a lager. Interesting ipl/Oktoberfest. Check it out. ----Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
22oz. bottle. Clear lite copper color. Lite toffee nose. Malty bread flavors with caramel and a honey sweetness. Smooth and heavy body. A little boozy and tasty.

Ruby red with some orange and brown; thick head, little visible carbonation. Rich, fruity aroma; raisin, apple, brown sugar, honey. Taste is quite sweet -- spicy raisin, molasses, honey, vanilla, long floral notes. Lingering finish.
Taster @ Trinity. Looks like whiskey. Smells like brown sugar. Starts off sweet and a little bubble gummy, boozy, follows up with a nice bitterness.
Definitely an interesting beer, though my notes are scribbles and I cant remember much. Orange pour. Lots of nice grain. Tap at Snallygaster.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Hoboken Vine (9.5% ABV), 9/13/14


Aroma: The nose is heavy malty, fairly sweet, with a little bit of spice, and some booze

Appearance: It pours a clear amber color with a small, quickly dissipating head

Flavor: The flavor is heavy malty as well, mid-sweet, some spice, and a slightly boozy finish

Palate: The body is fairly full, with a soft carbonation, and a bit of heat and stickiness on the finish

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty interesting beer. Much bigger than any traditional Oktoberfest beer, thats for sure. Sill, theres a good flavor here. Definitely worth trying, though 22 ounces may be a bit ambitious for a one drinker.

taster @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Clear dark caramel amber color with a bubbly rim head and dots of lace. Taste is lightly spiced malt that turns sweeter in the palate. Adds a little bittering late, then turns sweeter as it drifts through the finish. Seems like an Octoberfest or Belgian more than a Doppelbock.

pours orangish amber with a thin white head and no lacing. Fresh apple aroma with some maple. taste is killer with notes of orange, maple, apple, spice and bread. finish is baked bread with orange and nuts. Love this beer.

On tap at Parry's. Copper body making a thin white head and a bit of lacing. Not a strong aroma, but a hint of malt and yeast. Tastes of caramel, roasted malted barley, and spice. A bit of a boozer aftertaste. This is a great ale in the Oktoberfest tradition, but more sophisticated than say, a Spaten Octoberfest. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I always enjoy this. Caramel malt flavors with a woody essence. Nice brandy and caramel color. Full and oily palate with a smooth finish. Strong malty flavors up front with a slight hops presence and sweet finish. Somewhat alcoholic but not oppressive. Fine beer.

It has a copper or reddish amber color with a thin and creamy, light tan head. The body has good clarity and some visible carbonation. Its head fades out quickly leaving just a few stray bubbles on top. The aroma has a spicy hop presence with lighter malty notes and a hint of grainy alcohol. Its flavor starts with its solid malty backbone that has a dark caramel sweetness. A grainy alcohol pops out and gives the beer some bite and its hop flavor is spicy and a little bit earthy. It finishes slowly with some bitterness from the hops. The palate has a slick heavy texture with mild carbonation. The alcohol has a harsh unrefined quality to it, which holds down its drinkability. Overall it is still very interesting

22 oz bottle from backlog notes. Pours a clear amber/copper color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have bready/biscuity malt, caramel, some fruitiness, a hint of banana, floral and spicy hops, enough other stuff going on to cut some of the sweetness. Easy to drink.
Pours a very nice clear copper color with white head. Spice, caramel notes, and some flowery notes as well on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied, alcohol is hidden well. Finishes dry.

Batch 10, Aug 2013. Carmel, malty smell. Sweet, malty, boozy taste. Spices, little bit of bitter, and a little burn towards the end. Beautiful color as well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 Batch

Aroma - the aroma is spice, alcohol, fig, and raisin
Appearance - body is mahogany in color, the liquid is clear, the head is white and small and dies quickly into a halo.
Taste - heavier sweetness and light bitterness dominate - the caramelized sugars, alcohol, and dark fruit (fig and raisin) and spices are really what is noticed in this brew.
Palate - the body is medium in quality; the texture is somewhat oily, but mostly slick; the carbonation is average in the mouth; the finish is somewhat is long and strong and astringent with an alcohol burn.

Heilige Scheisse! Thats a dunkler bock?! That is intense! Punched me out!

10th release, August 2013. Syrupy, stinky floral hop mush and burnt caramel...the type of aroma derived from mixing too much alcohol and a mellow beer style. Copper color that nearly glows under light. Powerfully sweet taste, not starchy but coats the palate. Reminds me of the big German eizbocks if not as heavy, although it may be more profound by subtraction there as the alcohol will really sink in your gut. Dank and sticky are the two right words here.

Bottle from Total Wine in Boca Raton, FL. Opened on Christmas Day and drank out of a snifter. Beautiful amber pour with a thin, sparkling head. Head lasted only a few seconds. No lacing. The aroma was heavy malts, little caramel, spices and dark breads. The taste was spices, deep malts, light flavorful hops, caramel, and bread. Smooth body, medium light. Finish is a little booze and spices.

FROM NOTES: October 21, 13.

A: Big and malty, of course. Bready notes, caramel notes, booze and a general fruitiness. A very faint hint of hops also.
A: Deep orange bordering light brown. Soapy white head providing some lace. 
T: Very much like the nose, with a rich and malty sweetness kept in balance by the bitter and spice notes of the hops. Alcohol burn is present also.
P: Thick, creamy, smooth, lightly carbonated.
O: Very easy drinking; I thought this would be more like a bock than a strong Oktoberfest, but this did a great job of just being a stronger Oktoberfest while maintaining those characteristic Oktoberfest notes.

Batch #9, 2012
ABV 9.1%

Orange colored with a sheet of light cream foam. Smells sweet and malty with a hint of toffee and some tea like character. Flavor is sharper than I had envisioned with hints of anise and peppercorn. There is plenty of malt and sweet malt at that. Medium bodied with sharp carb. This beer is worth trying in a taster tray, not something worth $8/bomber for me. I actually bet its outstanding with about 18 months on it.

Serving type: bottle

10-14-2012

22 oz bottle. Batch 9 Aug 2012 9.1% ABV. The pour is a rich ruby gold work a medium creamy tan head that fades quickly to a film, leaving no lace. The aroma is pretty solid for an Oktoberfest. A lot of caramel and malt with a strong note of spice and pumpkin. The flavor is really, really sweet. There is a lot of spice and pumpkin and then the malty caramel finish. The mouth feel is a touch light and the flavor quickly dissipates but it's not too bad. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
9/2/2010. 22 oz. bottle. Pours amber color with a white head. Aromas of malt, spice and hops. Caramel and dried fruit flavors, hops are showing well and the finish shows the alcohol.
Batch 10. Bomber-> snifter. Dark orange with small offwhite head. A: spicy malt, earth, wood. T: sweet caramel malt, grains. Lively mouthfeel. Nice balance of flavors. Good.

Tap at Stags Head, planned on getting as part of sampler but since it was too crowded had big pour of this beast. pours dark copper with white head. Nose of toffee and malt. tastes of caramel, figs, raisins, toast, malt, metallic, and woody. alcohol burn on finish.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass; Batch 9 bottled in August 2012. Pours moderately hazy reddish orange color with a 2 finger dense cream colored head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big caramel, raisin, prune, pear, apple, toast, biscuit, molasses, brown sugar, light nuttiness, herbal, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/toasty malt and fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, toast, pear, apple, raisin, molasses, brown sugar, biscuit, nuttiness, herbal, light pepper, and toasted/yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of caramel, toast, brown sugar, pear, apple, raisin, biscuit, nuttiness, herbal, light pepper, and toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice complexity and balance of dark/toasted malt flavors with moderate fruitiness; with big malt presence and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a creamy and slick mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent imperial Oktoberfest. All around great balance, complexity, and robustness of dark/toasty/nutty malt and fruity ester flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A very enjoyable offering.
Draft. Hazy amber color, medium tan head. Aroma of fig, raisin, toffee. Taste is boozy dark fruit and caramel.

Pours ruby two finger off white head. 

Smell clean malty hog.

Taste boozy caramel, fall spices, toffee.

Fuller bodied.

Not bad. More of an English Barley Wine but nice beer none the less.
It poured a dark golden color with a white head. The aroma was light and grainy. The taste was a little bready with soft fruits and a sugary sweetness that leads to a warming alcohol finish. Nice.
Bottle shared. Pours clear amber. Aroma is caramel, malts, red fruits and alcohol. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter. Very malty. Full bodied with soft carbonation.
This beer is too damned sweet. Its a good brew but not great. nice nuttiness and spiciness. Too much syrupy sweetness. A lingering sweet burn. Very roasty yet the sweetness is just too distracting.
Very nice oktoberfest beer, whole foods in venice, sweet, crisp, loved drinking this

Pours copper mostly clear with a white head. Aroma had a tad of funk at first, unexpectedly, then some non sweet amber malts and a bit of zing from the alcohol. Flavor is some toasted malt aromas and a small zing from the booze that warms the tongue with of nuttiness.

Light malty aroma. Gorgeous dark copper body with minimal head. Taste is malt and spice, amazingly smooth. Alcohol is a little overpowering in the taste profile. Complexity grows as it warms. Very enjoyable.

Aroma is descent. Appearance is descent. Taste and palate, poor. Taste of alcohol burn, mixed in with malts and nail polish flavor (not that I have ever had nail polish...this is what I would imagine it would taste like). Last few beers I have had from this brewery have been below par. Nope, will not buy again.

Shared from a big brown bottle, into nonic glasses, 2012 vintage, aged one year. Thanks, gregwilsonstl! It poured a mostly clear, deep orange amber, with a thin but long-lasting head of white foam, some lace. Very malty and caramelly, faintly fruity, hint of vanilla. Pleasantly oxidized but not mushy or flawed, surprisingly nice considering strong lagers dont typically age well in my experience. The high alcohol and perfumey hoppy bitterness provide a great balance to the sweetness, the overall impression is much like a Trappist ale. I bet this is even cooler barrel-aged. Good stuff.
2012 vintage. Nearly clear amber.  Lots of cardboard flavor but it works.  I can?t believe this is 10%. Caramel. Smooth. Lacing. Delicious. Lots of barley.

Tap at Parry's Pizzeria, Highlands Ranch. Sweet toffee aroma with a lot of booze. Pours amber colored with a light head and some lacing. Sweet toffee flavors to start and finishes fairly smooth but very boozy. Would like it better if it hid to booze better.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours amber with small head. Sweet, toffee-like aroma with heavy booze notes. Taste follows suit. Very, very heavy booze. Nice toasty nuttiness in the aftertaste. Would be better if the alcohol didnt dominate so much. Very poorly hidden ABV. I can really feel the burn on the roof of my mouth.
Pours a hazy light brown orange. Really sweet aromas of corn syrup and caramel. Similar flavours. Sweet and malty. This is really delicious.

Thanks cards04. Intense sweet cream corn aroma malts vanilla. Very sweet breadt taste a touch of booze. Very nice though maybe a little too sweet for mt personal preference. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fabulous appearance for any beer, but especially for a lager. Deep orange and clear with a great lasting head and sticky lace that coats the glass. 

Aroma and flavor are both boozy, plenty of heavy malt-bomb-ish base, some crisp floral hops to offer a little glimpse of balance, caramel malts galore.

Body is surprisingly heavier than expected, carbonation is about what Id expect.

Its an interesting beer but not one Ill rush to pick up often, even if it was a year round offering. There are other high ABV beers that I enjoy better.

2013 bomber. Dark copper pour with little head or retention. Nose is malty goodness with a little more hops than is typical for the style. Some caramel, toffee and alcohol as well. Taste follows the nose. A little too boozy to take down more than one bomber which is unfortunate. Nice and sweet.
dark amber, small off-white head with short retention. toffee, cinnamon, bread, raisin, rum. medium-heavy sweet, medium bitter. full body, boozy, soft carb. its cool, but i dont love it
Cant believe I have not rated this. Malty with a little sweetness. One of the best fest beers.
Hoppy. Very nice. Entered this beer on a different app and I'm not able to import my comments unfortunately.
Bottle. Pours a darker copper with a beige head of foam. The aroma has some bread, dough, and tomatoes? Im even get a tea note. Taste is fairly bitter and dry. Lasting finish.

Pours copper with a thick tan creamy tan head that slowly creates a ringed lacing as you sip away.
Off the top the smell of sweet malty fruits makes me smile.
Flavor of spicy fruit, raisins, a lovely blend of malty bread.
Overall this is probably one of my most favorite marzen (Dunker Bock) type brews of which I am usually am not a fan. Making it Imperial just made this a lovely booze finish that balances the entire beverage. Remarkably solid!

Amber pour with a white head. Aromas of malt, dried fruit, and brown sugar. Flavor is very similar. The initial flavor is very sweet followed by the dark fruits and malts. Finishes a bit boozy but not outrageous. Interesting beer.

Bomber bottle poured a crystal clear amber w/ small beige head diminishing to a thin cap w/ nice lacing. Big sweet caramel malt aroma. Initial flavor is a moderate sweet w/ the finish overwhelmed by the booziness. Tastes are sweet caramel, rum, raisin, and Belgian sugar. Full bodied, lively carbonation, and boozy finish.
2012 bottle, cellared for 9 months - My only complaint is the alcohol bite. I could stand for a bit more creaminess. Head retention was not great.
Bomber. Reddish orange clear pour with a wispy head. Syrupy, malty, sweet, a little boozy. Caramel and bread. Nice.

2012 bottle at 9.1% ABV. The appearance combines a reddish orange color with a medium off-white head that fades to a ring quickly; also, the aroma is boozy with undercurrents of clove, raisins, and caramel malts. The taste is mildly sour, slightly sweet, and slightly umami, and the palate fuses a boozy finish, medium body, thick texture, and a soft carbonation.

Poured from a bottle.  Amber to Ruby color with a nice thick head.  Head dissipates  within minutes to fine layer of bubbles.  Plenty of lacing and legs visible.  Massive malt smell, like a freshly mashed grains, with hints of bread and dried fruit.  Good body with only a slight bite due to carbonation.

A - Pours a cloudy amber red with a 1 finger off-white head and leaves descent lacing down the glass.

S - Caramel covered cereal, sweet bready dough, a kiss of orange. Reminds my of cinnamon toast crunch.

T - Rich toasted malts, dense caramel, sweet cereal grains, some cinnamon oatmeal, hints of acidic fruit come through, earthy bitterness helps with the sugary malts, finishes a tad hot.
Has a honey wheat biscuit aftertaste.

M - Chewy, thick, full bodied, low carbonation.

Just as you would expect an Imperial Octoberfest to be. Its not complex but delivers a big punch of malt that is semi balanced with carbonation and herbal citrus hops. If you like malt bombs this beer is for you!

Serving type: bottle

05-19-2011
From a bomber. Pours clear light brownish red with thin frothy head. Tastes like spices and bourbon. Smells woody, earthy, sweet, malty, grainy. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle. Pours clear, dark amber with, thin, creamy off-white head; decent retention and lacing. Aroma is cereal and cookie malts, caramel, figs, dates, fresh straw, floral hops, and light herbs. Flavor is sweet, bready malts with supporting dark fruit esters, floral hops, light woody notes, and light spice; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.
Hazy amber with small head. Aroma is floral hops and malts. Taste is floral hops, malt and a hont of caramel with honey. Good stuff.

Poured from a bottle.  Cloudy amber in color.  Minimal head.  Nice mix of floral hops / malt aroma.  Full bodied and fairlu drinkable for this type of beer.  Bought it for the cool label but it is suprisingly good.

22oz bottle (2012 - 9.1% ABV) in a snifter.  Pours deep amber with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of strong of the nutty and caramel malts, a little alcohol, and a nice amount of floral hops.  Flavor the same, with a good malt character and notes of toffee too.  Average to smooth texture.  Much better than a lot of beers in this style.

Pours a clear orange/copper color, minimal white head with little retention and lacing.  Sweet malty aroma, almost honey.  Sweet taste of light fruit and light bitterness.  Not very complex.  Moderate mouthfeel and carbonation.  Not a very good version of an Oktoberfest. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

No comments entered on Beer Buddy.  Will enter tasting notes on Rate Beer when I try again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle. amber with small head. big malty marzen. sweet with fest spice. a bit chewy with alcohol warmth.

2012 vintage 22 oz. bottle poured into an Avery Brewing branded short stemmed tulip/snifter.

Pours copper with glimmering orange accents topped with a creamy two finger off-white head. Above average head retention and a significant amount of lacing is present on the sides of the glass. The inviting, rich aroma of caramel with accents of toffee is rounded out by some grassy notes. Initially, semi-sweet caramel joined by bready yeast. Finishes with mild grassy bitterness and mild phenol alcohol. Medium to low level of carbonation, medium to full-bodied with a slick and a slightly syrupy mouthfeel. Interesting "amped up" version of a traditional marzen. Defintely trends boozy, however the above average abv never dominates. An very original seasonal especially for "big beer" lovers.

Sweet and malty aroma.   Deep amber color.  Taste is sweeter, like a cross between an okto and a bock.  Super delicious.  I love this beer.  I would say that its the best okto Ive had but Im not sure its a true okto.

Heavily unique aromas of oranges, apricots, wood, candied syrup, caramel and oats.Very deep copper with an amber tint. Flavors are extremely sweet on the palate. I can sense caramelized sugar, roasted caramel, orange zest, oak and toasted nuts. Overall, this is truly a unique brew. Nice complexity and sweet flavors. Alcohol is noticeable on the finish. Id give this an A rating.

650ml bottle picked up at Discount Liquor 
Appearance: Clear amber with a small off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet Caramel, esters and candy 
Taste: Sweet caramel, spices and dusty  
Decent warmer.

Bomber thanks to Craig. pours a clear deep copper color with a medium white head. A big sweet nose of caramel and leaves. Really rich malty goodness, light spices, finishes with heavy spices, some banana, smooth. Very good and clean.

Copper, clear, off white head. Rich Munich malt aroma and flavor, bread crusts, a little toastiness prevents finish from being too sweet. Very clean and well made. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nose is some munich malt which has some layers of spicyness, faint off notes of dumpster.  Overall not very aromatic.  No essence of hops.  Boozy.  Nice carbonation, creamy head with the small bubbles.  Color is beautiful copper color.  Taste is a nice octoberfest dominated by hot alcohol.  Oh so boozy. boozy booz.  Dominates the palate.  Finishes spicy, slighly dry.  Medium aftertaste.  Enjoyability 3.5/5.
On tap, pours a reddish orange color. Nose is malty and full of caramel. Taste is sweet and fruity with light caramel malty notes. Carbonation is soft and the finish dry and sweet. Quaff Score 7 / 10

Bomber (2012 release). Pours a nice, clear copper with a thin head, okay lacing. Mouth is big and full bodied and malty in front, then some bitterness, then caramel and some light fruitiness (orangey), with a slight alcohol warmth. I like this one.

Sweet aroma almost like corn. Nice golden color. Taste is sweet with a nice hop bite. Just enough carb. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz.bomber of 2012 release. Clear amber pour with medium, creamy, beige head and some lacing. Aroma is toasted malt and light hops. Flavor is sweet, toasted malt, caramel, spices, and hops, with a sweet finish. Medium body with medium carbonation and high alochol content hidden pretty well. Very good; definitely an imperial.

I liked this beer a lot in college because it was a higher gravity  "marzen" and I probably still prefer it over regular marzens which are one of my least preferred styles.  A good party beer where you can leave it in the brown bag and not worry about all those dork ratebeer categories but fuck it.

great dark orange, almost red color. Sweet malt nose with a hint of spice. Thick malt flavor while being medium bodied. A nice spicy hop element, but this beer is all about the malt and it is fantastic.
Aroma of apple and peach. Red amber with white head that dissipates relatively quickly leaving lots of lacing. Tangerine, lemon. Slightly bitter finish.
Dark amber color with off white head.  Somewhat sweet flavor with a light spicy hop finish.

From notes, 8/14/11:
Poured a 22oz bomber into a dimpled stein. Bottled in 2010 noted on the label; enjoyed on a rainy day in August 2011.

A: Nice amber color with burnt orange around the edges. Lacing was thick and slid down the edges of the glass back into the beer. Slightly cloudy.

S: Sweet & toasty malts, noble hops very aromatic. Some yeast.

T: Sweet & toasty malts are again present in the forefront. Citrusy noble hops linger on the back of the roof of the mouth. Maltiness reminds me of a doppelbock.

M: Thicker than typical oktoberfest,

O: Although listed as an Oktoberfest here, it is definitely an Imperial Oktoberfest full of flavor. Extremely easy to drink, especially for the high ABV.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2013 Rerated on 04-24-2013: bomber (2006) - prettier pour than I recall. Not as flat this time. Spicy. A nice treat after nine days of working double shifts. 

double deuce (batch #9) into a crystal skull - pours amber with a finger of off-white head and decent lacing.  Nose is caramel malts.  Flavor adds rye, brown sugar, alcohol, cereal and faint herbal notes.  Quite flat.  moderately sweet with light bitterness.  slight metallic aftertaste.  Dry finish.  Underwhelmed for a 9.1% ABV beer.
Fantastic! Roasted malt and hop aroma. Dark amber body. Rich malts with a great hop bitterness that gives it the imperial punch. Excellent!
Bottle. Pours an amber color with a rather thick white head. A strong biting nose to this that pulls no punches. Very nutty and malty, this is a little harsh on the palate, but not bad.
Pours dark gold with white head. Smells light and grainy. Has a smooth bready taste with soft fruits and a sugary sweetness that leads to a warming alcohol sweet finish.
black, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, soft carbonation, creamy,

Bottle in September last year. Clearish red pour with soapy white head and great lacing. Aromas of german hops, caramel bready malts, orange peel and light hops. Taste is dried fruit, brown sugar, spicy german hop, and oak. Strong up front but eased as it warmed up. Still a good bit of heat. Decent german style.

Bomber to oversized snifter (2012 vintage).  Looks good; a transparent pale burgundy with thin white lacing.  Smells sweet, spicy, malty, and a little hoppy.  Tastes like it smells with an good mouthfeel.  Abv is hidden nicely.  One of the best Oktoberfests Ive had.

Pours a dirty medium amber with a sudsy/soapy head. Big candy malt aromas of caramel(really big), toffee, candied sugar, some bread, with a touch of spice. Flavors really dominate on the candied malt side of caramel, slight hint of alcohol (doesnt show that much), slight pineapple, candied sugar, and some mellowed floral hops (overcome heavily by the malts and sugars). Highly sweet, very malty, mostly on the desert side for a beer, mellowed flavors, and leaves not much of an aftertaste. Mostly a caramel bomb. Not what I was expecting, but the alcohol is mostly hidden.

22oz bottle. Batch 8, bottled August 2011. Mostly clear amber / red color. Thin khaki / off-white head, fades to minimal. Bit of lace. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Dry finish. Caramel and toasty malt aromas. Some fruitiness, like cranberry, or something. Bigger body. Not too much alcohol taste for 10%, just a little warmth, little bite. Spicy hops are there, little floral. Bitter and sweet taste.

Pours a hazy dark amber color, with good retention of the off white head. Rich spicy sweet aroma. Tastes of light molasses, spice, a wee bit of the german hops, and some alcohol at the end. Well hidden for 9.1, but lacking in the crispness I expect from a lager. Good beer, but really nowhere close to a traditional Oktoberfest ( but gets you drunk quite a bit faster).

Light fruity smell, not very complex. Smooth and alcohol is masked well. Syrupy. Just not great. One note. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Exceptionally smooth flavor. No roast nor cloyingly sweet malts either. More of the dark fruits, with a light touch of figs and cherries. I get some hints of candied orange peel and marmalade. It has a sweet finish with a flavor profile similar to some of the other Avery beasts. As far as I know its not barrel aged but it has a an oaky smoothness. Strong, yet smoothI can taste the alcohol but its mellow and gentle. Delicious and the perfect desert beer.
22oz bottle 2011 from smiths4498 73 out of 73 styles.. Taste is stale malty with a little bit of chew in the beer too hot for me but definitely good on this cooler evening in June

A - pours deep amber orange with high fluffy head that lasts. Strong lacing. S - strong aromas of malts and dark dried fruits. Hints of candied oranges. M - amazingly sweet, sticky mf. Lingering brown sugars and malty alcohol warmed end. T - malty, brown sugar, dried fruits throughout. Hints of candied orange. O - pretty good Octoberfest 6

650ml bottle [Thanx David!] with 10.01% abv. Clear copper colour with very small yellowish head. Malty aroma, malty taste - Intense malty taste, monotonous malty taste. Well hidden alcohol, nevertheless provokes the malt intensity diffuse headache misgivings.
2011 Bomber:  Pours thick with no head.  Rich malt aroma.  Very good flavor of malt with a hint of hops.  Alcohol is well hidden.

bottle grey import platinum cellars, nsw
overall fairly nondescript, clean and drinkable masking its big abv well, but ultimately not very satisfying or memorable

Are breweries still obsessed with making "imperial" offerings of all of the more traditional styles?  This one might have been a bit unnecessary.  One of the best things about oktoberfests is their sessionable qualities.  The alcohol in this is distracting. Still, its a solid offering from a better than average brewery.

*(cuvée 2009): Couleur cuivre, rouille avec des notes puissantes de caramel et desters fruités provenant de la levure lager. En bouche cest liquoreux, riche en malts sucrés. Un goût de tire dérable sinstalle graduellement dans la bouche. Fini sec et légèrement végétal.

2010 bottle.  Pours an orange/brown color with no head.  Aroma is malty hay and crackers.  Taste is quite sweet with bready, nutty malt notes.  FInish is still sweet and a bit unappealing.  Not bad but not good.
Rich malty beer, this one probably has way to much age on it. Alcohol bite a little unbalanced. Like the thick caramelly maltiness though.

Nice amber/orange color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, caramel, fruit, & spice; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, molasses/syrup, fruit, hops, and spice; Finish is dry with some alcohol; Nicely balanced; Overall, a bit too sweet - but still a good sipper.

Bomber. Pours a light reddish copper color with a circle of off-white bubbly foam. Malt dominates the aroma with plenty of toffee, vanilla, brown sugar, baked apple and booze-soaked raisins. Big time caramel and toasted bready malt flavors upfront as well as some butterscotch, candied date, prune and black cherry notes. Also a mildly spicy hops kick toward the end along with an alcohol warming sugary finish. Overall, its a sweet, bready and boozy brew that makes for a good beer to cap an evening of Oktoberfest festivities.

2011 bottle: Grapenut and caramel nose, moderate strength. Clear copper, medium yellow head. Full body. Flavor is maraschino cherries with hints of marzipan, considerably sweet, but finishing with a grassy bitterness. Not cloying. Bockish, which is completely understandable, if not the proper classification anyway. While not a bock fan, Avery did a great job with this creation.
The Kaiser lets you know that it is Fall with its full bodied flavors, a preview of the Winter ales to come.

Bottle. Deep orange color with a small white head. The nose is strong, filled with vanilla, honey, sweet grain, sugar. The taste is a bit hot, sweet. Pastry. Nice malt flavor. Body is medium, the finish is long and slightly boozy. Carbonation is active. Overall, nice beer.

Pour is metallic copper with a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and musty with a definitive alcohol undertone. Medium bodied but very oily in texture. A little over-carbonated. I know a lot of people enjoy this but I really cant get anything from the taste besides alcohol and musty basement. No thanks.
Bottle - average size foamy head, light amber color, sweet malt and alcohol aroma & flavor - a little too much alcohol flavor for me

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a small, white head.  Aroma of malt, caramel and fruits with a hint of hops.  Flavor is slightly sweet with notes of fruit, caramel, some spices and a nice hop character.
Simply put.. this brew is amazing!  As this brew slowly warms the flavors just intensify and the warming effect of the alcohol is definitely a treat!  Truly a malt-heads delight!

Bottle. Hmmm, Imperial Oktoberfest, huh? Pours a darker copper color with a nice slight light tan head that stays for a while. Rich aroma, caramel, slight spice, and biscuit. Medium mouthfeel. Nice lacing. Sweet upfront with notes of caramel, some fruit, and ever so slight booze. LIngering bitterness in the end. Probably not a true representation of the oktoberfest but drinkable and enjoyable.

Had this on draft at Capital Ale, Innsbrook a little while back. Wish I had gotten another taste of it before they sold out... Utterly perfect in appearance; half-inch thick creamy beige head, deep clear golden-brown color with some reddish tones more reminiscent of a Scottish ale than the typical octoberfest. Aroma was sweet and slightly floral with strong roasted malt caramel overtones. Flavor was well balanced, and palate full bodied yet relatively thin, as an octtoberfest ought to be, beginning with the silky smooth creaminess of the head, followed by sweet, slightly toasted nutty caramel with a light, smooth hoppy finish that lingered on the tongue, almost entirely masking the high abv. Excellent beer. By far my favorite offering thus far from Avery. Just wish I had a chance to try it on draft again to make certain it wasnt a fluke...

2011 release on draft at World of Beer.  Pours a clear copper amber color with a dense beige head.  Excellent lacing along the glass with nearly a solid sheet of foam.  Aroma has some raisin and sweet resin along with some floral hop notes.  Flavor has some initial malt sweetness with a bit of sourness in the finish.  The high alcohol is pretty bell hidden.

2011 bomber.  This was actually a great year for this, and is one of my favorite offerings from Avery.  Alot of their style seem to fall short of par, but this one gets points for its uniqueness and overall enjoyment.  Nice orange red clear pour with good lacing, off white head.  Rich aroma of cream, rain water, leaves, vegetable resin.  Really an unbelievable palate for 10%, smooth, creamy, medium to full bodied feel, abv pretty much unnoticeable.  Notes of honey, caramel, leaves, sweet carrot, and nuts.  Very nice.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XPnygkoqKVs

Appearance: Transparent brown/amber, 2-finger head, excellent lacing

Smell: Noble hops off the pour, maraschino cherry, plum, sweet carmel malts, pumpernickel, fig, molasses, lemongrass, cinnamon

Taste: Full body, molasses, pumpernickel, english breakfast tea, sweet caramel malts, toffee, plum, cherry, apricot, raisin, fresh grass on finish, bourbon warming residual, corned roast beef residual, chewy mouthfeel, light carbonation

Pairings: Rueben, bratwurst + sauerkraut

09 and 11 on draft. Pours copper orange with a white head. the 11 had a clean grainy aroma with some light sweetness. The flavor is lightly sweet, with grains, light bread, and a hint of booze. The 09 isnt quite as good, and is showing some oxidation.

Copper/orange beer with a frothy, white head. Weak aromas of toffee and caramel. Taste is one dimensional: caramel/toffee and some assorted, lackluster spices. Sweet and nutty brew. A bit too watery, finishes on a sweet note. The high ABV is hidden quite nicely in this bland beer. I was disappointed.

a bit thick with sweetness yet watery body with low carbonation. opaque light brown with a bit of orange hue. broomstraw as in aged malt with a freshness near the finish. caamel and toffee like, i suppose the low carbonation muted any spiciness, still altogether an amped up interestingly strong Octoberfest with some light flower notes.

Bottle into snifter.

The aroma of this beer is very subtle.  There is a slight caramel with resin lingering.  However, this is speculative because it isnt very bold in the smell department.

The color of the beer is clear amber gold.  Really a beautiful beer to look into.  When I poured there was almost no head but what was there appeared tan.

  I love the taste of this beer.  It has a heavy sweet and bitter mix which tapers to a sweet salty aftertaste.

The flavor is full bodied and slick, almost oily.  There is very little carbonation but the flavor feels active in your mouth.  The finish is long and even.

Overall I really enjoy this beer.  The fact that it has no head and not a whole lot of initial aroma really doesnt mean too much to me.  The taste and palate are really rewarding.  Another solid beer by Avery.

Bomber pours a hazy bright orange/amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, very fruity, spice, and bubble gum. Taste has an empty hop bitterness that rides until the end with a malt backbone with an underlying spice that punctuates a stinging alcohol presence. Ugh.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2014 Sampled on draft at Ds in Monroeville this beer poured a dark orange color with a medium sized foamy beige head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was sweet caramel, pine and somewhat rough fruity hops with undertones of pepper and alcohol. The flavor was bitter and rough with moderate caramel and fruity, piney and spicy hop. There was a noticeable alcohol presence. Long finish. Fairly full bodied. Nice.
Bottle.  Aroma is very sweet.  Alcohol is also present.  Taste is too sweet.  There is no bitterness.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2011 Bomber.  Pours deep golden amber with a small off-white head.  Aroma and flavor are lots of malt, caramel, toffee, cherry, apricot, maybe some maple.  Flavor is very sweet -- overly so, Id say.  Mouthfeel is a bit syrupy.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden.

on tap at mad mex robinson two nights ago.  not real happy with many high alky beers and same with this. darker brown yellow clear color.  has a thin chunky head. sweet aroma and a big strong intial impact that certainly lets you know its impy.  probably some attributes of barley wine in here. yes quite sweet almost too much co.  rather rude at times. mouth coating on the finish. nothing octoberfest pleasant in this unless you wannah catch a buzz fast.  burns a little going down the throat.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Smooth and bitter barley wine style ale.   The hops seem tom be a dominant undertone with a good bitterness, but not much hops floral nose.    I think this is a very good barley wine without too much of any one flavor, but a distinct package

Draft at rattle with streets and b dad. Pours a clear dark amber with no head, light off white lacing. Aroma is sweet dark fruits and maple. Mouthfeel is syrupy with notes of maple, raisins and prune.

Bomber. 2010 bottle. 9.73 % ABV. Pours hazy orange with an off-white large head that falls after a couple of minutes. Aroma is caramel corn; smells like an aged barleywine (uh oh, not what I wanted). Taste is bittersweet with a long bitter finish. I really wish I could have gotten a fresher bottle. Whats up with that, Click?

Batch 8 (August 2011). Pours rich, amber orange  with fluffy yellow foam. Smells like maple, fall spices, bready, and some hoppiness. Tastes sweet with subtle bitterness backing it up and a hint of alcohol burn at the end. Full-bodied with a slick texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Avery The Kaiser finishes with some sweetness and burn.

Draft at Avery Taproom. The concept of an imperial Oktoberfest is interesting but I dont think it quite works. The alcohol overpowers the delicate maltiness of the style. Its all a bit too boozy. But every Avery beer Ive had has been balanced and leaves lacing in the glass so theres care there.

22 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a very small white head.  Aroma of caramel and malt.  Taste is malt, caramel and dark fruit.  Some alcohol comes through with a bit of hops.  Too sweet perhaps.

From 22oz bottle - Why did I get this?  Maybe because I trusted Avery to produce a Marzen I would finally like?  I dont know...this style sucks!  Ive only tried a few that I like, one being Ayingers October.  Nice looking and comfortable mouthfeel, but that damn chemical / astringent quality.  Just cant get past it.

Poured in a snifter. Pours a really nice amber/copper color with a thin head which fades quickly. Aroma is sweet maltiness with apples light caramel. Mouthfeel is light and smooth with light carbonation. Flavors include caramel, banana, and smooth malty sweetness. For ten percent, I found this to be a smooth drink.

Had this in a growler - the first glass had a strange acridness to it but it smoothed out as it went down.  Poured cloudy orange with a thin white head.  Aromas of cloves, bubblegum, and bananas.  Kind of a sharp flavor that I couldnt quite get used to, a bit of sourness as well.  The alcohol was too assertive - something in the balance just seemed a little off.  Willing to try again.
There is great potential with this beer. My pour was probably too flat for me to experience it, I look forward to a re-rate.

Bottle. Pours a clear bright orange brown with a thick foamy kahki head that fades to a tight collar. Aroma is pumpkin spices and malty funk. Taste is warm and more spice with a malty backbone and some faint bitterness, but with a little funk and yeast. Palate is medium slick and dry with a good abundence of alcohol.

Bomber to a pint glass.  Copper/amber with limited head.  Very clean, crisp aroma.  Roasted hoppy taste.  Slight burn on the finish.  At 10%, this is a smooth imperial that could sneak up on you.  Easy drinking Octoberfest.
A very nice easy drinker for 10.1% ABV. A great fall brew with a punch of spicy, citric, floral hops, and a balance of Malts to even the beer out. Another great brew from Avery!

In taster at urge.  Looks amber orange and clear.  White head.  Smells like an amber german.  Tastes of german malts.  A bit amber and noble hop bitterness.  honestly delicious oktoberfest.  Overall 7.5 of 10.

Bottled in 2010, 9.73% ABV - This beer pours a nice copper brown/orange with a decent head, doesnt stick around very long.  Aroma is strongly of sweet fruits, mango being prevalent among those, with a semi-floral and malt note also being smelled.  Tastes somewhat of the mango scent aforementioned up front, but is more balanced with other fruity flavors, along with a strong malt presence to balance.  In the center of the palate has a hay/grain flavor mixed with a soft salty caramel note.  Has a bit of floral finish, not sharp/overwhelmingly hoppy floral though.  This is a wonderfully complex but very drinkable beer, perfect for both the season it is brewed (fall) and the style itself.  Would drink plenty of these and get in trouble possibly (its almost 10% but drinks like a 4%)

Good copper pour with a white head forming.  Very nice toasted bread malts, grains, and a slightly crisp hop aroma are notable in the nose.  The flavor is pretty nice with the toasted malts being upfront, cereal grains in the finish, a little buttery, and sweet caramel.  The finish is a touch dry and hoppy.  Pretty nice brew!

9/1/11. Pours thick with a copper tone, nice head that fades somewhat quick. Aroma is straight malt,nutty with caramel. Wow, very malty taste as well, a little overpowering with sweetness at first, but turns nice with a smooth mellow finish. Very thick brew,very tasty brew.

22 oz bottle, purchased @ Table and Vine, West Springfield, MA. Bottled in 2010 with 9.73 ABV. Nice glowing orange color with a brown hue. Slow mild carbonation. Very thin light, white head. Used a lager glass. Nose of REAL sweet malts, candy sugar and a bit of dark fruit. Good Lord!, this is a malt bomb! Toffee, malt, caramel, malt, apples with cinnamon and more malt!  Did I say I taste malt?? It reminds me of a barley wine, more than anything else. Can you guess how this finishes??  Yep, . sweet. No bitterness and no heat. But for me a BIT much in malt. Still overall a good brew. The Kaiser is  Lieblich .

22oz bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy orange-amber with small bubbly off white head.  Underwhelming sweet aroma.  Flavor is quite sweet, brown sugar, caramel with a slight hoppiness.  A bit nutty.  Medium bodied, slightly sticky.
Aroma of caramel, floral, cornbread, and brandy.  Pours slightly hazy and deep orange with a small pancake head.  Tastes of malts, sugar and alcohol.  Over the top as usual for Avery.

Bottled 2010 .... Cloudy golden amber pour thin off white head light sticky lacing .... aroma of sweet malts and fruity hops ....  taste is lightly bitter and sweet caramel malts little bubblegum with some alcohol and some spicy/sweet fruity hops .... finishes dry and malty with some abv in it .... not a bad brew not great either

The beer is hazy and frothy with an amber color.

It smells of bread and honey before you drink and the flavor is honey, sweet and floral. It can be a bit cloying after a while. 

It tastes a bit like a mead.
Really nice burnt orange color and thin thick clinging head. Maltly, warm smooth drinking. Yummy.

Bottle pours yellow-brown and murky with small white head.  Malty aroma with a little cotton candy thrown in.   Flavor very sweet with malts. caramel, toffee and grapes.  Finish sweet with moderate hops.  Plenty of malts to balance out the hops.  Palate syrupy and sticky.  Alcohol apparent but didnt notice it as much as others apparently did.  I like big sweet beers but looking  at the rankings this beer is obviously a matter of taste.

On tap at Avery.  Filtered orange-brown.  Thin, oily head.  Deep malty aroma, not so much alcohol, but you know there is some brutality in there.  An odd beer all the way, I remember being unimpressed with some of the earlier vintages.  Malty overall, but loses is Maarzen characteristics in becoming a malt bomb.  Pungently fruity, big, syrupy.  Not my favorite.  Bold, but rather unexceptional.  Craft malt liquor.

The beer pours a clear dark amber color with a white head. The aroma is full of toffee and biscuit malt, as well as a lot of grapes and brown sugar. A very malty, fruity beer. The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of grapes and flowers as well as a ton of caramel and biscuit malt. The alcohol is also very apparent. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. This tastes like an Oktoberfest on steroids, just like the brewer intended.

Appears that "Imperial Oktoberfest" is being hemmed into the style of Dunkler Bock on RB.  Whatever.  Ill trust the views of Ratebeer over whatever crap the Alstroms are spewing any day.  And yes, Im bitter.  The Kaiser, however, is not (nice transition, huh.)  Pours orange and Octobery, with the evil alcohol demons inside the liquid keeping the head to themselves.  But it tastes like the first Lager-bomb Ive come across.  Like all the weird, funky-fruit flavors of a normal lager have been concentrated and sugar-coated.  Not bad, but the alcohol comes fuming out as the brew warms, and The Kaiser gets too sweet and burny for repeat consumption.  Interesting, but a little much.   (12/02/08)

22oz bottle.
Deep orange color with some sticky off-white head.  Lots of caramel malt aroma with some fruitiness - flavor is a malt bomb as well with a bit of a hop bite at the end.

2010 bottle.  I was very excited to try this beer, but it doesnt seem like an oktoberfest to me, more like a barleywine.  I can faintly taste some malt in there that resembles the style but I think its a barleywine.  Very strong, very hoppy, rich and decadent.  Nothing like I expected but still a good beer.

Bomber. Poured a dark ruby color with a small off-white head. Aroma was heavy on the malts, light on the hops. Grassy hops, alcohol relatively well masked for a lager of all things. A tough one to drink alone, but one that can certainly be shared and enjoyed by many.

Im not sure what the point of an imperial Oktoberfest is, and if it will even push any type of boundaries. 650ml foiled bomber.

It pours hazier than the style standard, it is a cidre color. Th head is off-white and the lacing is super dirty looking.

The smell has a tangy fruit character, some caramel nut, and alcohol.

The flavor is pretty bad. Super cloying sweetness, rotten fruit, sickly sweet caramel. Huge alcoholic presence.

This beer is not needed.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-07-2010 20:52:44

Nice amber with dense off-white head.  Candi sweet nose.  Taste is very sweet, overly sweet in my opinion,  thick and heavy like a dense dopplebock.  Alcohol is present as well.  I feel this was lacking a hop balance.

On tap at the brewery in August 2009. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderate caramel color with a half-finger white head and not much of any lacing. Nose brings some caramel and dark fruits along with quite a bit of booze. Taste is overwhelmed by alcohol and brings some dark fruit in the background. A bit of residual sweetness. Boozy, hot feel on a medium body. Drinks okay, as it somewhat reminds me of a rum-soaked dessert, but overall not a beer I really enjoyed.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-13-2010

Brown, a bit cloudy, not a lot of head.  Tons of malt aroma - cant really detect any hops aromas in there.  Taste is of malt and caramel - quite soft, but mixed in with a bit of alcohol.  Very little - if any - bitterness in the finish.

light amber apearance with a sweet malt and slight citrus/ caramel aroma, would be the only  word I can use to describe it slight white head, it smells amazing the flavor starts with some caramel malt and finishes very sweet with a slight hop bitterness, albiet this is my first oktoberfest, it is amazing I love the sweet malt across the board,

Caramel colored pour from bottle with a thin head.  Aroma is booze, sugar cane and hay.  Taste is slightly sweet, with a nice alcohol kick.  Kind of like an IPA and an Oktoberfest beer got married.  Really good.
The aroma is malt, sweet caramel. Pours a golden copper brown. The taste is sweet-light. The body is creamy, off white head, good lacing. Not bad.

This beer is over the top for the style. Golden color with modest head , malty fruit fragrance, and a huge alcoholic grape taste that avoids the grape seed bitterness typical of big lagers. Certainly very alcoholic but a great beer

Avery The Kaiser Imperial Oktoberfest. It pours out a nice amber color with an off white head that doesnt have much retention or lace. The aroma screams malt with citrus and alcohol notes. The flavor is where Kaiser really shines. Its a very rich brew and the malts hits you hard but is still balanced out with a great bitterness. Some fruity notes lay underneath and you slowly start to notice it after a bit. The alcohol remains subdued under the flavors and youll only realize it through a nice warmth as you drink. My first Oktoberfest type of beer and i really liked this one.

Pours a slightly hazy orange-amber in the glass.  Rich malty aromas on the nose with notes of caramel and toffee.  Thick mouthfeel with substantial malty sweetness on the palate.  Everything you like about an Oktoberfest, multiplied.  Very interesting and quite delicious.

Bomber served in a champagne glass. 2009 vintage aged one year. Pours hazy orange brown with a short head. Impressive aromatics. Sweet, malty, and complex with toffee, caramel, hops, and heat. The palate is similar to the nose, quite malty, but finishes bitter at the death. Medium body, sticky texture. This can only be considered a Strong Ale in my book. In any case it is worth seeking out.

Almost unfair that this is called an Oktoberfest given the gravity and flavor. Pours orange with an orangish head. Aroma of malt, grain, and grassy hops. Flavor is more of the same, sweet malt and nice German hops on the finish. Fairly full body for the style, but it is 10%, so Im not surprised.
Strong carmalty aroma.  Deep copper in color.  Sweet malty, syrupy in taste.  Probably the best oktoberfest beer Ive had.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 Note: 2010 version, 9.73% ABV...Tasted from a 22 oz bottle purchased in Denver, Colorado. Translucent orange appearance.  Aroma is sweet and malty with a very good malt smell thats not overpowered by sweetness like some Marzens.  Also, theres not really a hint that the beer is nearly 10% ABV.  Very tasty amber malty body with hints of caramel, nuts, and even ever so slightly sour.  Big body with so much flavor that its hard to tell thats the high alcohol content.  A truly unique brew thats highly recommended.

Bottle.   Pours an orange color with a tiny beige head.  Has an aroma of pumpkin spices, a bit of caramel as well.  For an Oktoberfest, it has a pretty complex and full-bodied taste.  Very malty, with plenty of spices and caramel to the flavor.  Finishes slightly bitter.  I suppose overall Im not a big Oktoberfest beer fan, but this one was pretty good for that variety.  9.73% alcohol (2010 version).

Pours out a deep rust/copper tone with an average khaki head that dissappointedly fades much too fast. The complex aroma becons me to stop trying to figure it out and just drink it already. Getting whiffs of apple, toffee, and fruity malts, with maybe just a little grassy hop on the end.  Taste is right where an Oktoberfest needs to be. I get alot of cinnamon applesauce with huge malt overtones, gentle hop bitterness with a semisweet finish. Texture throws me off though. Its sticky and sweet like maple syrup, with not much for carbonation. In all, a fine Oktoberfest indeed. The alcohol isnt too aparent so you need to watch out. I had a bomber with a full meal and I could still feel quite tipsy at the end of it.

This beer is over the top for the style.  Golden color with modest head , malty fruit fragrance, and a huge alcoholic grape taste that avoids the grape seed bitterness typical of big lagers.  Certainly very alcoholic but a great beer. Ijust cant imagine having a big liter Krug or two and still being verticle.
The Kaiser Oktoberfest-on tap @Andys-pours a light tan head and amber color.  Aroma is malty, secondary hops.  Taste is malty-roast/slightly toffee, hops backbone.  Smooth.

22 oz bottle, 2009.  Clear brown with a creamy beige head.  Nose is caramel, butterscotch and toast.  Almost full body with a cloying tang.  Massive for an O-fest and then i noticed it was imperialized.  Taste is Cracker Jack then burnt butterscotch finishing with bitter clove.  Harsh but not without some appeal.

cant imagine having too many of these on oktoberfest or the party would be over very quickly. great aroma of sweet malts and a great deep caramel color make this a very inviting beer. the taste is alsmot completely butter and bread with a little abv kick in the back of the throat, absolutely delicious but does not hide the abv and it shouldnt, you want to know that this will kick you in the ass if you dont appreciate it.

Appearance: Pours a dark bronze with almost no head.

Aroma: Herbal Euro hops, toast and caramel.

Taste: Bitter Eurohops, caramel, alcohol and apricot.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, low carbonation, a bit sticky.

Overall: I really enjoyed this, it wasnt something I could quickly drink do to its warmth and body, but I enjoyed every sip. I didnt like this beer years ago when I tried it for the first time. The lesson is to develop your palate, and circle back on the beers you were close to writing off.

caramel, chocolate, toast, roasty, floral, citrus, herbs, leather, earthy, ginger, smoke, woody, golden, amber, orange, red, brown, cloudy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, slick feel, average carbonation, bitter,

I finally got to use my big glass steins Aunt Sandy got me a year or so ago when I successfully poured the entirety of my 22oz Kaiser bomber into said stein. There were no dimples, but I still felt like I was ready for the biergarten, stein in hand, sausage and kraut on the way. Deep amber-orange, her coppery head fades into a thin blanket while lace proceeds to crawl its way up the sides of my glass to no avail. There is no escape when Kristyn is supping beer; thats alcohol abuse, mind you. Her nose reaches out like a strong-armed fraulein and slaps me upside the head with massive caramelized crunchies and candied apple goodness sprinkled with a healthy dose of cinnamon and nutmeg. For a big beer, there is no readily apparent alcohol heat, and so I greedily revel in layer after layer of red apples and chunky cinnamon apple sauce, melba, caramel crunchies, white raisins, and pears. When holding a stein filled to brimming with beer sipping doesnt come into play, and so my first few quaffs are anything but timid. A creamy sweet mouthfeel greets me fast and sets my tastebuds flying. Melted caramels, toffee, and maple slathered atop succulently stewed apples spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg with a side helping of applesauce and peaches. Besides mingling with her stewed apples, cinnamon lingers long in my breath which is lightly tinged with warm fuzzies. Underneath her sweet first impressions are more crisp apples and golden melba toast. Dry grass and baled hay dries the back of my throat, instigating enough thirst to keep my generous quaffs going at a steady pace. The Kaiser Imperial Oktoberfest is dangerously drinkable, and as I near the end of my stein, dried apricots and apples bid me a final farewell.


Not overly complex by any means, she is immensely rich in the flavors that matter most for an Oktoberfest style beer, imperialized or not. I was also greatly impressed by the overall lack of alcohol heat. Im glad they dont serve the Avery Kaiser Imperial Oktoberfest at German(style) biergartens because any more than one and Id be doing more than just eating and drinking.
had it on tap at the brewery.  Nice sweet aroma, golden red color. Sweet flavor with complex malty tones.  I like ie.

22 oz bottle poured into an Oktoberfest dimpled mug.  Brown pour with a medium frothy head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt and faint almonds.  Great full bodied brew with a sweet lingering finish warmed by alcohol.  This one will sneak up on you...
Had it on tap, bitches. Sweeter than expected, not my favorite octoberfest. Very light color. Did I say how sweet it was? Weird. Didnt like that much.

Beautiful orange-amber with small head.  Aroma mostly caramel malt.  Full body, alcohol is noticable but not overwhelming.  Pretty sweet up front with caramel, candy corn flavors.  Just enough of a dry finish to keep it drinkable and narrowly avoid an excessively syrupy fate.
This spicy little treat tasted like fall.  Interesting take on an Oktoberfest, try it.  Above average but not amazing.
Pours an amber gold, with flavors and aromas similar to many German Maerzen style lagers. Not as crisp as it could be, but has enough flavor to be interesting.
Pours amber/brown into the glass with a white head.  Aroma is heavy in caramel and toffee.  Flavor is much the same.  Lots of big sticky malt flavor.  Nice.

Bomber btl. Pours a clear copper with a minimal white head. Had a malty candied aroma. Tastes more like a strong ale (again) than an oktoberfest or a marzen. Has a malty sweet character and a warming alcohol taste. But not to seasonal so to speak. I dont dislike it but not too oktober.
Very nice. Starts off very sweet--lots of fruit and caramel--but a really well-balanced spiciness comes in as it goes. Very smooth body but rich and densely layered.

Botttle. Pours a beautiful amber color with an off white yellow head. Aromas show slight hoppiness and earthy german malts. Taste is very nice; lots of marzen malts with some sweet fruit flavors and just the right amount of hops. Mouthfeel is great; almost want to say creamy but smooth also works. Alcohol is so well hidden youll get caught.

Pours a hazy deep brown color.  Aroma is your typical earthy Oktoberfest.  Flavor is pretty complex.  I can pick up some earthy yeast, tart cherries, and dirty pine combs.  Is pretty much full bodied for its type.  Leaves a nice earthy malt finish.  Impressive!

Deep amber with a nice puffy head. Sweet with a subtle hop flavor in the background. Where oktoberfests are generally thinner and lighter, this one is thick and full bodied, and the high alcohol content is well masked.
Bottle. Pours amber with a big tan head. Flavor is very malty sweet with almonds, caramel, light hops, and maple syrup. Definitely the best maerzen Ive come across.
Awesome amber color. That was the very first thing I noticed; the second was the strong taste of alcohol in this beer. It tastes ok but its a little overwhelming. Still a tasty beer.

(22oz bottle-2008 version).  Pours copper with off-white head.  Nice lacing shaping up.  Aroma of bubblegum, florals.  Taste is sweet with some light bitterness.  Medium bodied with oily/sticky texture.  Fizzy is pretty lively and finish is rich and long.  I really like this. Would absolutely get again.
Bottle (ABV 9.73%) pours a copper brew with a thin tan head. Scent is sweet malt and a bit musty with booze. Taste is caramel malt and booze.
