Pour: Deep Thick  reddish hue with an off white head. 
Nose: Rich caramel malt with sweetness and a hint of citrus. 
Taste: Very big  octoberfest beer. A bit too much.  There is a huge complex malt character with sweetness and hopps on the end. 
Body Thick and rich
Finish: Slightly acidic. 
Overall: This beer is an avery style beer it is very huge. The one thing that this beer needs is a better finish and a bit toned downed. It was tasty neverthe less.

2007 - A lot of people like this beer a lot more than I did.  I am just a little more traditional when it comes to German styles and I think they should leave well enough alone.  Having said that, this is just another Avery example of pushing the limits and making everything bigger and bigger instead of better and better.  This is way too malty, I never thought I would say that, but this is just too much.

From Løvbjerg, Aarhus 160408
Bottled
Very malty and with a presence of alcohol. Hopbitternes OK

An all-time fave of mine. I guess I love a malty kick in the palate more than others. The four I had were of the 2007 vintage, with a lovely lace and an amber brown color. I wish I had reviewed this earlier, but since I still salivate for the Kaiser, I must of loved it. Bitter? What bitter? This about the malt, baby!!

750ml bottle.  Pours a lovely copper color with a good eggshell white head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy, with an aroma of caramel, apples, cloves, roasted malt, and syrupy hops.  Taste is sweet and full with a cider-like crispness and flavor -- apples, roasted malt, spices, floral hops, and dark fruit make up the bulk of this beer, with a lingering finish containing a few hints of warming alcohol.  An underappreciated gem.

A deep, even sensual aroma with strong hints of cherry and toasted malt; this is an utterly gorgeous brew - somewhere between mahogany and siena.

The flavor itself is intensely fruity tasting almost like a strong cider but with a yeasty minerality. Apricot, plum wine, and wheat all combine to make this fantastically drinkable.

Definitely a sipper, have with a link of garlicy sausage and home-made sauerkraut.

This beer took me by surprise. A lot of crazy fruitiness going on in there. Its like some kind of tropical mango shake or sorbet. Oktoberfest style malts are in there (and complement the crazy fruits as well as can be done), you just have to search a bit. Almond comes out a fair amount in the flavor.

Pours a very nice copper, with an undying off-white head. The aroma is fruity, sweet and pungent with a little bit of spice/floral complexity in the background.  The flavor really caught me off guard at first, but the more I drink the more I like it. Very sweet and malty at first, then transitions into a  bizarre, but increasingly pleasant fruit flavor, and then finishes with a nice lingering floral/almond bitterness. The palate is thick, oily and quite smooth. The alcohol is very nicely hidden in there. A challenging, but ultimately enjoyable brew.
aroma: sweet malt and alcohol. flavour: alcohol, sweet malt and a sweet hoppy finish. not too great...
Amber with huge off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with caramel notes. Sweet flavor with notes of ripe fruits, caramel, sweet malt and hops. Rather full bodied. Ends bitter.
Transparent red orange color. Medium head, some lacing. This beer is pure deliciousness. BIg malty backbone, mild hop finish. Soft on the palate, mild alcohol notes are present. Yum.

Pours a somewhat frosty looking amber gold with creamy white head that dissipates to a nice lacing. Aroma is definitely caramel and hops with bourbon undertones. Flavor is caramel/rum/bourbon mix (the liquor flavors are subtle but touch the palate). The sweetness is balanced by the hops. It is a good beer.

Bottle. [thank you, BelJohansen]
Pours hazy golden amber with a fine, creamy white head. Aroma is very hoppy, with just a slight touch of caramel. Fine, creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is hoppy, soft, quite vinious. Not German at all, but still refreshing.

22 fl oz bottle, thanks to BelJohansen. Pours hazy orange with a lacing white head. Light woody and spiced aroma. Mild thyme note. Woody and spiced flavour. Dry woody and more solid spiced flavour following. Hoppy flavour into the finish. Nice but yet another terrible US interpretation of a German style beer.

Poured from a 22oz bomber (Bottled in 2007) and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a clear, dark amber hue with a one-finger thick head of beige foam that lasted throughout the entire glass.  A decent amount of thick lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of caramel, graham cracker, orange peel, and bread dough.  The flavor consisted of citrus hops (orange and grapefruit), bread, caramel, and also some noticable aclohol.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with moderate carbonation.  Decent, but Ill take a good, sessionable Oktoberfest over this any day.

Orange, grapefruit and grass aroma. Light hazy, amber color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, malty, fruity, bitter, grass, hint of dough and of course very floral. Soft mouthfeel. In between an IIPA and Märzen.

22 oz. bottle, from BevMo LaJolla, 2007 version.  Pours a beautiful, clear and bright medium copper with a moderate sized head.  Rich ripe fruits in the aroma, plum, figs, molasses and earth with alcohol detectable as well.  Sweet and frity flavoer, molasses, prune, cedar bark, florals and brandy notes, pretty phenolic, bitter herbs and astringent in the finish, tainted by a wheaty metallic taste.  Full body and gentle carbonation.
Bottle from Canals. Coppery/orange pour with a sweet, spicy malty aroma.  Brown sugar and alcohol taste its surprisingly one of the better Ocktoberfests.
nice deep color and normal head.   the beer is fantastic. the malt profile suggests a long sparge.  tough of cream and dynamic hopping round out the experience.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2010 2007 bottle, purchased at 99 bottles in federal way, washington.
pour is a clear, dark orange with a red tint, a small off white head, good lacing.
smell is of roasted malt, floral, some hops, molasses, some spice.
taste is sweet, malt, caramel, tangy in the end, slight bitterness, some spice.

2007 bottle.  Pours a translucent golden amber with a medium creamy/bubbly off white head that left some lacing.  Aroma of Munich malt, grains, malty and sweet all balanced nicely with the spicy, floral and citrus notes of the Noble hops.  Flavor was a mix of the same malty, grainy, molasses, sweet with a nice touch of Noble hop spiciness.

Pours red, clear, kind of thick, with a moderate, fine head. Aroma is rather fruity with some hop aroma. Thick mouth feel with a strong fruity quality to the flavor. Bits of caramel come forward. Really tasty, excellent, big beer.

Sweet pineapple/resin nose.  Orange to amber color.    Super sweet malt accentuated by the alcohol, could use just a slight bit more bitterness, but still fairly well-balanced.  Very full , with a long, long, long finish...very unique beer, and certainly in terms of an typical Oktoberfest.  A excellent, even approachable, "big" beer.

Well Ill be horn swaggeled.  It looks, smells and tastes kind of like a marzen.  the big booze is just hidden I guess!  Pours a clear reddish amber with a healthy white head, creamy.  Sweet malty caramel nose.  some floral hops and just a slight hint of toast.  Something rather fruity to even bubblegum like.  Creamy tutti fruiti.  Creamy smooth viscous slick feel.  Decent carbonation.  The flavors are pretty alright too.  Sweet.  Very sweet.  Caramel malt backbone.  A bit of floral hops, and that alcohol just peaks out where it should. Creamy.   Fruity flavors, even lending something like a fruity socky sort of flavor... it is kind of out of place... but it might just be the toast, which I dont care for terrible.  Alcoholic finish.  Lingering toast.
Smoked aroma? Flavor well spiced, taste the alcohol, creamy finish. Burnt orange color, light head. LIghtly hoppy?

22 0z. bottle, Having tried several Marzens lately I thought this was one of the better around ,hazy medium amber color with a nice head that dissipates to a soapy ring, complex malt, with a flowery hop note. I will definitely have another one.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 22oz bottle from the Pizza Port bottle shop.  Poured a very clear golden amber with reddish tint.  Head was off white and small, great lacing left on the glass.  Doubleo was right about the sweet potatoes.  Also picked up hints of clove spice, caramel malt and light hops.  Mostly malt on the palate, very sweet and smooth.

Pours an amber with a decently full head.  The nose is of strawberries, citrus, and sweet malts.  The palate was malty, acidic, orange, strawberry, and some hops.  The alcohol was not well hidden in this one.

Pours a clearish light brown color. Much lighter than I was expecting. Thin white head. Smells sugary sweet, like sweet potatoes or something. Tastes of brown sugar, malt, and just a touch of hops. Thin, but it coats the mouth, sugary. Not one of my favorites.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2009 Bomber 2007 version. Pours clear, dark amber with a small head. Nose of malts, sweetish, very "Octoberish". Tastes of malts, sweetness almost to the point of cloying.  Body is thick and lucious. Very alcoholic. Nice beer but a bomber is more than enough of this beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Pours translucent amber into the glass, with a nice creamy head that diminishes to a ring, leaving soapy lace behind.  Pumpkin, spices and grains to the nose.  The flavors are of bold malt, with pumpkin seeds, raisins, dough, sour grains, and a touch of alcohol to finish out the pull.  Hops are well-integrated, and lend a nice "spice" to any diacetyl notes.  Full-bodied with a rich mouthfeel, this leaves a nice sour grain aftereffect, lending further complexity to the brew.  Well done, and a nice offering.

Pint bottle poured into lager glass- poured transparent light amber brown, small carbonation, white bubbly head formed and stayed foamy.  Aroma of rustic malt, with small notes of honey and alcohol.  Hits the mouth with a medium body, sweet malt throughout, finish stops quickly with a brief alcohol finish and a very small touch of hops.  Nice.

Sampled via 22-oz bomber at Cellars Wine & Spirits and shared by joebrew. Pours a clear orange amber brew with a creamy and thick off-white head that slowly dissipates with good lacing and retention. Aroma of bread dough, some caramel malt, some raisin and a touch of toffee. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with flavors of semi-sweet caramel malt, toffee and a touch of honey. Finish is smooth, creamy, thick  and a semi-sweet caramel malt aftertaste flavor.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of roasted , caramel, cereal and chocolate milk, moderate hop note of perfume, yeast of dough, and toffee, alcohol and honey in the background. Head is small, creamy/bubbly and white, with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy copper. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start, then finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, creamy with a lively carbonation. It finishes dry, astringent and alcoholic. A nice Octoberfest with bold aromas.

Pours a clear pumpkin orange with a thick creamy head. Smells very sweet, almost pumpkinesque, malty and bready. Taste as it smells, strong and sweet, almost syrupy. Not your traditional thin oktoberfest. Full in the mouth. Drinkable but you sip this guy, very tasty and makes you love the fall.
Bright and clear with a golden amber color and a generous head.  Yeasty, hoppy, and spicy in the aroma.  Hoppy spiced taste balances out the typical maltiness of the style.

From a 750ml 2005 bottle, pours a deep, dark amber with no head. Big malty aroma. Medium body, big malty sweet flavor, slight raisin character, slight biscuit character. Not your traditional Oktoberfest. Nice.

Pretty good for an Oktoberfest. Orange body with a  thin white head, no lacing or retention.  A nice sweet aroma with a mix of bread, fruit, & candy.  i also noticed a strange unidentified aroma, it was not offensive just different.  Flavor was a mix of sweet caramel malts and a nice pundgent spice note.  A very rich beer.

Very complex aroma.. Malty, sweet like fruit and candy and the same time, spicy, and somo other odd aromas that I cant quite identify.  Flavor... Damn this is GOOD... Malty, yeasty and surprisingly hoppy.  And you dont even notice the 9.3%.  What a treat!

Very different. Pours a golden deep orange color with a nice bubbly tope head .Smells of sweet caramel and nuts. Tastes like honey and malt and wheat. Great beer and a very interesting take on a good style. Cheers Avery!

22oz bottle 2007. Very sweet malt aroma. Candied oranges, caramel with a wisp of grassy hops and a good dose of alcohol. Pours rich, oily copper with a creamy white head. Sweet toffee and caramel dominate the flavor. Some candied fruits with minimal hop presence as well. A strong alcohol presence. Syrupy on the tongue. Finishes with a blast of alcohol hotness.
On tap at Pizza Port.  Golden amber with a fizzy white head.  Sweet bready aroma and taste of caramel and honey.

This is nothing like any ocktoberfest Ive ever had. It pours out visible viscous with slow-rising carbonation and a slow forming dense off-white head with thick lacing. The aroma is dominantly honey, dried fruit and super sweet grain. The flavour is sweet honey, apples, fragrant hops, and a sweet, syrupy malt backbone that is slighlty vinous. Hardly any booze overrides the sweetness. It has a thick, syrupy texture with perfect canbonation and has a long, fruity and alcoholic finish.

This beer pours a clear amber color with a moderate head that fades rather quick, also there is no laceing along the sides of the glass. The aroma has somelactate notes almost like rancid milk and there is also some hints of honey. As you drink it this beer is unlike any other oktoberfest, it is much sweeter with a strong apple like flavor which is very pleasing. It also has a tart honey flavor on the sides of your mouth on the palate. The palate duration is kind of short but is full of apple and other light fruits.

Pour: copper, golden, with red/orange hues. Head: creamy, offwhite, laces some. Aroma: molasses, barley wine, sweet, candy, nice alcohol. Flavor: sweet, molasses, barleywine hints, malty, alcohol. Palate: thick bodied and smooth. Finish: warm.

Dark amber/orange color. about a fingers worth of head. Aroma is quite sweet, im picking up apples, bubblegum, and sweet grains. Aroma is quite malty sweet, with a touch of alcohol for good measure. Its very sweet, but not cloying. Overall a nice beer, but a little too much. More of a sipper than a good quenching lager. But still VERY good.

Orange-amber pour, large off-white head, aroma is grainy sweet and hoppy, Caramel notes of grain, floral earthy hops, medium body with a nice spicy finish. A concept beer that lives up to its goal; a big marzen. Nicely done.

Beer Mail this user about their beer review and beer ratings of The Kaiser CyberkediInitiate in The Halls of Beerdom w/ 365.6 Beer Karma points ( Atlanta, Georgia )

overall: 4.35
appearance: 4  smell: 4  taste: 4.5  mouthfeel: 5  drinkability: 4.5

It pours a lovely dark golden yellow, very appetizing. Aroma is strong and malty with fruity hints, mainly apple. Flavor is rich and mouth filling, very malty with hints of spice and apple and just a whisper of sweetness. It goes down with just a touch of hop bitterness. Very satisfying. Prosit!
Bottle 07. Poured a clear rubish color. Aroma is sweet hoppy aroma very nice. Taste is smooth and crisp kinda fruity with a grape finish.
2005 Edition complimentss of Piscator.  Medium carbonation,  bit sweeter than i expected. nice hop finish

Bomber from HalfTime.  Bottled in 2007.  Light copper, very clear.  Beautiful.  Head starts very white and dissipated quickly.  Huge caramel flavor, nicely hopped but not overly so, nicely winey not too much.  Sweet.  Very tasty indeed.

2005 edition. Hazy amber in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of toffee, caramel, apricot, alcohol, and floral hops. Flavors are heavy on the bready malts and black pepper, with more apricot and alcohol. A bit of a sherry note... probably oxidation, but perhaps this is to be expected in a two year old bottle. Theres a good amount of hop bitterness on the finish too. Its not really fair to compare this with standard oktoberfest beers, as its more intense in just about every regard. I think it achieves what it set out to achieve.

Bottled in 2005.  Dark amber, nice rocky one finger tan head that never diminished, nice lacing.  Sweet to the nose, even sweeter to the tongue.  Malty and sweet up front, finishing clean and dry.  Very nice.

650 ml bottle.  Pours a medium-light copper with a dense off-white head.  Complex nose with notes of malt, spice, plum and caramel.  Medium-heavy body with a surge of flavors.  Spicy plum and toffee notes up-front offset by a nice malt and hop profile.  Pleasant lingering finish.

Dark copper with off-white head (1 finger). Nice lacing. Malty-sweet aroma with light fruit and the slightest hint of cheese (Is my my bottle old?).  Taste is sweet, malty, slight  diacetyl. Good mouthfeel. Very tasty.

Bomber, pours a clear light amber with a frothy one finger tan head, good lacing.  Aroma is candied fruits, caramel malts, and some spice.  Flavor is light spice and more candied fruit sweetness, kinda like fruitcake; some warming alcohol present.  A bit sweet, overly malty and generally unexciting; guess Im still looking for that Avery beer that can break the 4.0 mark for me...

22oz Bomber - Gravity Room - Olympia, WA 
Aroma  Deep rich malt aroma with tons of spices and hops.  This was a huge beer. 
Appearance  Dark in color, clear with a thin head
Flavor  This had a deep malty Oktoberfest Beer taste with hops and flavor to give.  A great beer to drink.  
Palate  Dry to thr finihs and great flavor to the mouth this was a great beer.
Overall I liked this beer it had flavor and intresting hops and spices added.  The beer just was awesome to drink.  I will be sure to catch one next season.

Bomber.  Poured a deep amber/copper with a frothy almond colored head.  Spotty lacing. Aroma of caramel apples, maybe candy corn and fruit candies-- very "Halloweeny."  Sweet caramel  flavor with a noticeble booze presence.  Almost tastes on the mild side of a barleywine or doppelbock.  Some marzipan and candied orange peel notes.  Soft herbal hops which IMO are too timid to support the malt sweetness.  Thin but not watery.  Basically an overly malty OF but with way more alcohol.  Not really my thing.
bottle.  Very unique aroma with a background of raisins in the smell.  Very unique heaviness on the tongue.  Tastes too much like malty raisins for me.  Hard to swallow.

650 ml, 9.37% (2007). Clear orange-amber with a medium-sized, lasting head. Aroma is malted candy and boiled corn.   Initial flavor is sweet corn, but slowly turns more  to a spicy-sweet alcohol, then finishes with some tingle and a touch of grassy-herb, slightly bitter hops. Palate is medium-bodied and tingly.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2008 Pours a gorgeous transparent copper hue with a fluffy, tan, full head. Nose is very sweet and bready/ yeasty. Flavor is sugary and malty with honey. Really an interesting brew that packs a bit of a punch.

Lagers arent supposed to taste this good. Aromas of caramel and flowers with hints of apples and brown sugar. Smells sweet, like a barleywine. Sits surprisingly full for a lager. Heavily carbonated mouthfeel. Tastes of apples, honey, deep, ripe, noble hops. Finishes very clean. This beer takes on some Belgian maltiness as it warms to room temperature. And it should be served at room temperature, like an ale. This is one of the more complex, flavorful lagers Ive ever had.

Sweet aroma of caramel and light molasses. Nice amber color and an off-white head that didnt have much lift. Full bodied with very mild carbonation. The flavor is sweet brown sugar with floral and fruit aspects. It is somewhat complex. The finish is malty, and as the sweetness leaves, there are floral notes and perhaps a bit of herb.

Bottle (2006).  Pours a med copper/amber color with a med-sized head.  Has a sweet, light malty aroma, with some yeast and trace of hops.  Very malty flavors, with a nice dose of spiciness.  Some alcohol comes through.

Pours a nice Amber with a slighly oranish head. Lots of sweet caramel in the Aroma. The flavor has lots of Alcohol but also a good sweet character. Body is nice and full. If you are expecting an oktoberfest beer you might be surprised by the character but it is good.

2005 bottle.  Thanks Ross.  This thing aged much better than expected.  Poured out a nice orange color with an small of white head.  aroma was malty, and rather spicy.  Flavor was fantanstic.  Was like a marzen on steroids.  Alcohol was well hidden.  Taste was much better as it warmed.  Nice beer!

Pours a deep reddish amber with a thin creamy orangeish head. The aroma is barleywineish, caramel, very rich, fruity. The flavor was similar, also resembled a barleywine. Caramel, alcohol, brown sugar, molasses, fruity. The palate was smooth and fuller than the rest of the oktoberfests I had at the time.
Pours a clear copper with a strong off-white head. Sweet malts, caramel, lightly fruity, a brief hop presence. Very sticky. Not bad.
22oz bottle.  Poured on the lighter side for an Oktoberfest.  Smelt and tasted remarkably fruity Strawberry/Banana.  It was okay, to be honest, i only bought it because of the nazi on the label.

22oz.  Clear, honey-to-copper-colored body topped by an off-white head of medium size, somewhat creamy texture, and leaving behind lots of haphazard lace.  The aroma is bubble gum, candy, and something yucky.  The yucky is like yeasty, sweet, honey-comb--it smells like spoiled food.  Body is fullish with light carbonation of coarse bubbles and a fairly wet finish.  The yucky smell is also in the flavor.  Extremely malty with fruits, sugars, esters, noble hops, alcohol is noticeable, but hiding somewhere.  My mouth is sticky from this stuff.  Tons of malt.  Beautiful beer.  Dont care for it.

courtesy of fiulijn - pours a hazy copper-brown colour with a little beige foam; robust hoppy and malty aroma; strong presence of caramel; full-bodied, very sweet and slightly sticky; solid bitterness lasting in a long and moderately dry caramelish finish - a very free interpretation of the style

Sampled @ GDBTF.  Probably my favorite avery at this point.  Pours a crystal caramel color with minimal head.  Massive caramel on the nose, some grassy hops, very fruity on the palate, an intensified oktoberfest for sure.

2007 bomber. Pours a nice, clear deep gold with a decent head that leaves near-perfect lacing. Nose is more weizen than fest-marzen, with sweet fruit and a hint of spice. I didnt know what to expect from an "Imperial Oktoberfest," as I had not tried The Kaiser before, but my first thought on the first swallow was "bock." This carries the sweetness and alcohol of a bock in a slightly lighter shell of flavor. As noted by other raters, there is a sour, bready note to the flavor, suggesting then... weizenbock. I then recall Averys Thirteen, and realize that there are some common notes here. Fest-marzens do emphasize malts over hops, and I suppose if you take this to the extreme, you get a beer like this one. I like the idea, and I like the beer for its aspects, but my overall score is a touch low, because the malty sweetness is not in balance. Split a bomber with friends is my advice; you may not get through it yourself.
terrible. extra sour and sweet. pale color fizzy head. actually did not even finish it. sorry maybe it again but as is was bad bad

This rating took place over the course of about 30 minutes. Light amber color with a small white head. Super sweet aroma. I get caramel malts, some fruit, perhaps bananas, and some toasted nuts. Alcohol in nose too. Syrupy sweet. A little vinegar? Sour notes. Sweet fruit - fruit punch or banana - I cant decide. Sweet toasted caramel malts. Alcohol in the finish. Actually, for how heavy and sweet this is, I find it relatively easy to drink. It does have a nice light bitter finish, and the vinegar/sour notes were really only around during the first sip. You know what? I think I really actually enjoy this one...
22 oz bomber.   Golden/amber color.  Aroma was of banana and cinnamon.  Flavor is decent, but way way too sweet.  Thick, malty beverage.  Tough to get down.
A big, thick, sticky--and extremely sweet--beer.  It could use some more hops to balance out the sweetness, in my humble opinion.

From bottle : Pours a nice dark clear amber color with a significant white head that diminishes pretty quickly to a white ring, lacing is ok.  Kind of a skunky smell of malts and spice.  Very smooth on the palate and going down.  Flavor is malty with a little pumpkin and spice.  Kind of a skunky taste on the end.  Still not to bad.

Having been rather unimpressed with this the last couple years, I must say I very much enjoyed this years bottle. A massive looking ruby/copper pour with a fairly modest head, the aroma on this one is fairly potent, with a big nut and floral combo. The malt-forward flavor is winning, especially now that the weathers cooling (at last), but the fruity and floral notes make for a winning balance. Not earth-shaking but pretty damn tasty.

Pours a copper with white head.  Aroma of wet band aids, sweet malt, and caramel.  Very sweet and not very tasty (whats with the band aid flavor).  Yes it tastes like a strong oktoberfest, but no it doesnt work.

Pours a light transluscent copper with a huge fluffy white head.  Points for a big, delicious and unique smell.  Had a hard time describing it until my girlfriend mentioned raisons, so that is what Im going with.  Sweet, bright, honey suckled raisons.  Taste is sweet, and raisiny sweet as well with an obvious alcohol flavor noticeable which detracts a bit.  A bit sweet at times, but still drinkable.  This one grew on me after a bit, and then faded away. Not sure exactly what to think, but its a decent all around beer that is certainly unique, but not something Id buy again at 6.50 a bottle.

Bottle.
Copper color with a sweet malty aroma.  The flavor is out of this world.  The flavor is malty and of apples, pears and caramel.   Avery delivers what it promises.  They take a classic style and tweak it to take it to the next level without getting away from the core characteristics of a Märzen.  The characteristics of a Paulaner or Löwenbräu Oktoberfest are here but imperialized.  

Another superb brew from Avery.  They cant do wrong.

bomber, 2007 vintage. 9.3%abv. this bottle was just released so the sample is pretty fresh. pours clear copper with fluffy white head. nose is sweet toffee, toasted biscuit, and noble hops. flavor is initially too sweet, sweet throughout actually, but more toasted biscuity flavor in the middle but this thing brillantly finishes with a big floral noble hop flavor. an awesome noble hop flavor. body is medium, and carbonation was smooth. perhaps they over did it a little , a bit too sweet, maybe at 7.5-8.5%abv would be better, but the great noble hop flavor is whats doing it for me. im glad i got to try this thing so fresh. it still maintains an oktoberfest beer taste to it but at other times reminds me more of a fresh bock. with it being a bit too sweet i couldnt say Avery nailed it, but they come pretty darn close, and that hop flavor is worth the price of admission.

Bomber, ABV is 9.37%, cool label: Sugary aroma, lots of sweet malts with a nice floral scent accented by biscuits, and theres a faint soapiness involved here too. Awesome pour, rich amber/copper color with aggressive carbonation. Massive light tan head and a blanket of thick lacing that wraps around the glass. Hearty body with a creamy-velvety smoothness and a low alcohol burn. Overly sweet flavor, initially its distracting. Sugar and bread are the main components. The alcohol is noticed and helps to counter the big sweetness. Somewhat one dimensional. An odd milk taste was noticed here and there, hard to explain. I dont know why you would want to imperialize an Oktoberfest, but this was a solid attempt even if I am slightly disappointed overall. It took a while to finish the bottle. Good but not worth the price tag.

After nearly 350 ratings, this is a beer unlike any other that Ive sampled. It pours a clear copper with a creamy/frothy beige head that laces beautifully. The aroma is intoxicating: candy sugar, banana, pineapple juice, and light caramel malt. It smells like a malty tropical cocktail and has very little in common with the typical Märzen. Medium to full-bodied and creamy smooth with a sweet, clean finish that carries just a whisper of alcohol that hides in the background. The flavor follows the nose with a solid malty front and notes of banana, pineapple juice, brown sugar and even more malt with just enough Noble hop bitterness to keep the flavor from becoming cloying. This is NOT an Oktoberfest, by the traditional definition, but it is delicious. Thank you, Avery, for creating such a unique and enjoyable brew.

2007 release - 220z bomber. .. Clear, rich copper/amber w/ light tan head.  pretty bubbly. .. Carmelly, malty aroma w/ lightly fruity hop notes. .. The flavor started with some sour notes, but rounded out to be pretty malty.  Maybe got a bad bottle?  ..  Medium body, high carbonation. .. I think that I got a bad one - but its pretty good nonetheless, so Ill try another.

deep amber with a fizzy off white head. malty slightly roasted aroma. Full malt character with a heavy dose of sweet. Slight to moderate fruit notes. Slight hoppiness weaved it. I guess we have to have imperial everything at some point...

What a fun beer.  Very nice sweet malt on the nose with a dose of roasted character and a healthy dose of alcohol.  Nice powerful, and yet creamy mouthfeel leads to a great warming mouthfeel that is just delicious.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 Bomber. Huge tasting beer! Pours nice and clean and the aroma is mild. The flavor however is huge. Big chewy thick malt flavor , nearly syrup like texture. Long sweet finish.

22 oz bomber: I finally got my shot at this Oktoberfest after years of searching for it on the shelves. I knew one day I would of crossed paths with, I just didnt want to resort to ordering it off liquid solutions. This marzen  pours as a glossy burnt orange and maintains a decent froth of foam to keep me intrigued. The aroma is basic and typical of the style with a strong back bone of malt and sweet goodness.  The flavor is a bold delivery of dryness and sweet malt that really gives you the feeling this is a true winner to be had at a real Oktoberfest event.

2007 bottle.  Malty aroma with some hints of smoke.  Copper/orange color with a medium white head.  The malts predominate in the flavor, but the sweetness seems to be well balanced by the alcohol. Mouthfeel is a little bit sticky, and the aftertaste is more bitter than I would have expected.  Quite a pleasant drinking experience.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma rich with hops and malt. Taste is strong with malt and hops with a long lasting bitter finish.

9/29/07 On draught at the Rogue Issaquah brewhouse.  Aroma is extremely sweet with a bubblegum candilike character and very sweet citrus in the background.  Appearance is clear gold with a moderate white head.  Flavor is very sweet with moderate bittering, no Munich malt and low bittering.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, kind of syrupy with a lingering finish.  Overall, this is just not to style and needs much more grain character.
ah, not so much here. To much alcohol burn and way to sweet. I couldnt taste any hops at all. Certainly a cool spin on the oktoberfest, but just to sweet for this guy.

Gylden øl.

Bitter, sød, varme og alcohol smag.

Duft: Sød, karamel og humlet

22ozer. Very good looking copper/light brown color. Very clean. Nice upfront Marzen lager yeast taste with a smack of spiciness at the end. The website and bottle state that this spiciness is from the noble hops but you would think it was from an actual adjunct being added. One pint was enough...a bit of a hot alcohol touch to it too.
pickle brine aroma? doesnt matter, this beer is tasty! clear clean caramel color misleads you into thinking this will be weak but it tastes dark, burnt sugar, and nutmeg. unique

2007 Bomber.  Deep amber beer.  Small head.  Very sweet fruity aroma.  Sweet beer with very little hoppy flavour.  Good finish with a touch of alcohol.  *Almost* tired of it by the end of the bottle.  Another excellent beer from Avery.

Amazing. Best Octoberfest style Ive had. Pours a dark brown orange with a 3cm head. Has hints of caramel, some hop, wheat, dark fruit, and spice. Finishes with a weird "twang" on the tongue. Overall has good body and carbonation.

Rating number 300.  2007 version.  Pours a clean, crisp, amber color in the dimpled mug.  The scent was of malt, light hops and some wheat.  The flavor is very nice for a marzen...which is not my favorite style.  This beer hides the alochol well...I was surprised that this was over 9%.  I am a big fan of Avery though...they like to push the limits.
Strong aroma of dark fruits and light roasted caramel malts.  Hazy orange body with off white head.  Similar tastes with a strong thick body.

Pours deep amber with a small bubbly tan head. Strong and very sweet (almost too sweet) syrupy aroma. Some floral hops buried deep underneath, but mostly just sweet syrupy fruit. Flavor is slightly more reserved with sweet notes of apples, toffee, and raisins. Alcohol is noticeable, but unoffensive, and there are hops somewhere in there, but they almost disappear in the sweet body of this beer. Palate is medium, slightly syrupy/oily, and semi-sweet.
If every Oktoberfest tasted like this I would look forward to the end of summer.  Sweet smelling.  Smooth and slightly syrupy.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma is sweet.  Smells of fruits, alcohol, toffee, sweet malts, hops, dough, and a hint of spice.  Poured amber in color with a large, foamy, rocky, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Great lacing.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of alcohol, malts, and some apple.  Medium body.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet apple/malt finish.  Overall, a decent brew that hides its 9.3%ABV pretty well, but its just barely an Oktoberfest.

2006 vintage, aged one year.Dark orange color with medium white head and nice lacing. Malty aroma with light fruits. Flavor also dominantly malts, spices and light sweet fruits. The alcohol was masked well, but just not that interesting to warrant drinking a whole bottle...got boring after the first glass. I suppose the alcohol made up for it, as a 3.6 seems a reasonable rating even though I didnt enjoy it that much..?

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2008 I almost want to say that this is a bad bottle, as I love Avery beers. It pours out with a nice copper red color and thin white head. Malty aroma accented by the smell of band aids (???). Thick malty taste, but aroma was so off putting that I had to pour this out. I will have to get another bottle and re rate this, because I cannot see Avery coming out with something this awful. 

RERATE Day!!!!!!! I rerated this on Feb 29 because I know it could not have been that bad.
Pour golden brown with a thin white head. Aroma is beautiful malty, caramel malt, thick with floral hops. Smooth thick body. Malty taste that has a crispness to it balanced with deliciously bitter hops. If we could only drink this for octoberfest!. A great beer and I am glad I finally got around to rerating it.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 Had half a glass courtesy of a friendly guy I met at the Pizza Port bottle shop who had just cracked this open. Light amber color with small white lace. Sweet sugary aroma, malt presence is dominant over the hops. Not much going on flavor-wise; toasty malt with a crisp finish. High alcohol content is very well hidden.

Had this beer on 9/28/2006.  Aroma is a faint malt scent with tones of alcohol.  Color is a orange/brown with mild carbonation and thin tight head.  taste is sweet and mellow.  Starting with a body that goes down with a sharp feel.  Finish comes in with a mellow caramel malt flavor backed by a mild bitterness and a strong alcohol taste on the end that seems to build as you drink.  The alcohol feel on the end is a bit strong, but it gives you a warm feel and would be a good brew on a cold October day.

Wow! I would consider this a European strong considering the ABV but whatever. As an Oktoberfest, this is amazing (as any style its amazing). Aroma was strong alcohol and caramel. That scared me as I thought this was going to be a typical big mouth burner. Pour was a dark gold with a thin off white ring for a head. The taste was a great suprise. Strong caramel malt comes through all the way with molasses in the aftertase. Very wet mouthfeel. I would not take this beer to be higher than 7%. This beer is dangerously good.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 22oz bottle: 2004 release-Pours a clear copper with a small off white head. The aroma is sweet with caramel and molasses and  notes of clove. The flavor is malt driven with caramel and toffee being most noticeable. There is some alcohol noticeable. The mouth feel is excellent with a nice coating effect. Not bad for a 3 year old beer.

I was reluctant to have this beer included in my o-fest sampling, but it turned out to be a solid brew.  Pours copper with a thin off white head.  Smells of lots of caramel and biscuits with touches of earthiness.  Taste is spicy with caramel and some citrussy qualities.  Good beer but not even close to an o-fest.

22. Pours a crystal clear rubied amber with a thick, sudsy off-white head. Surprisingly neutral nose, especially from Avery. Very soft caramel and nougat notes, if even that. Soft medium body with light carb. Sour cherry and light vinous notes near the finish. Kind of a mess and not much in the way of a dimensional, characteristic flavor profile...cant say I associate this kind of brewing with what I usually expect from Avery.

POurs a hazy copper color with a small white head.  Smells of some sweet malts, and molasses.  Not a very inspiiring nose.  The taste is very malty as well.  Maybe a little cinnamon spice and candy sugar.  Interesting beer for an Oktoberfest.  Swetter than most that Ive tried.  Not a bad brew at all.  Finishes clean with a sweet aftertaste.

Pours deep copper with dense head which remains through drinking.  Toasty malt aroma.  Slightly sweet.  The after dinner Marzen.  Kind of an odd, dusky malt taste.  Reminds me of some of my brews gone bad.  Finishes clean.
beautiful copper color, creamy head, complex candy flavor, reminds me of horehound candy. It tastes as much like a liqueur as a beer. with its richness

Could not find much on the nose but caramel malt.  Pours dark amber with a light head.  Medium bodied with hints of caramel, toffee, light nuttiness, malty sweet but strong alcohol.  Sweet finish.  I was lucky enough to try this from tank during a brewery tour.  Great Beer!

bomber. pours a very attractive copper/amber shade. the cream colored head stands about 3/4 of an inch tall. big sweet nose is reminiscent of traditional barleywines. a very clean aroma that must be from the lagering. figs and raisins also appear. starts with the flavors of sweet grains and golden raisins. a considerable amount of alcohol stands out on an otherwise clean finish. smooth palate, crisp, concise finish and grainy aftertaste are hall marks of lagering. this too sweet and too boozy for my taste.
bottled in 2007. pours clear copper with frothy beige head. lacing in spots.  fruity aroma almost like carmel apples.  hops, malts and fruit. ok beer

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2008 Name: Kaiser Imperial Oktoberfest
Date: 06/23/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Sherlocks, GA

Appearance: clear dark blood red, whispy fine beige head, 
Aroma: huge sweet dark carmel aroma, aroma picks up an earthy note, 
Flavor: thick sweet and alcoholic flavor, another typical Avery alcoholic mess, eventually settles down, flavor turns into a rich carmel sipper, hint of fruity character, aroma fades into sweet apple and alcohol, 
Overall: never gets any better

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 5/20
Rating: 2.1/5.0Drinkability: 4/10
Score: 4
Amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of malt and caramel. A flavor of sweet malt and caramel.

22oz bottle, 2006 Vintage.  Dark amber, copper color, tan head.  Heavy malt aroma, caramel, and golden raisins.  WOW!  Deep, heavy malt flavors.  Sweet toasted caramel malts.  Medium bodied.  Heavy hitter.  Finishes like a Belgian Strong Ale.
Imperial Oktoberfest/marzen. Hides the 9.1% with diverselight fruits including mango and peach and pair. Toasty.   Liked the balance. Extremely  drinkable. Not acidic. Not too sweet. Over priced.

(Bottle) Pours amber. Sweet fruity and almost a bit sticky malt aroma with some caramel and nutty almond notes. Flowers are the most notable features from the hops but grass is also present. Undertones of grainy bread, honey, apricot, orange, green unripe banana, pancake and tangerine. Medium to heavy sweet malty and a bit alcohol bitter flavour with a sticky caramel finish. Hoppy tones of flowers and orange. A bit spicy. Undertones of apricots, almond and glue. Medium afterbitterness with only a touch of citrus. Round and sticky mouthfeel with a minty alcohol sting. Medium full body. A bit too much alcohol and a lack of complexity make this beer an average experience.
Tap. At the Avery 14th Anniversary party. A Crude black oil in appearnce with a heavy malty aroma. A nice sweet spiced finish.

Bottle.
Cloudy orange coloured with a white ehad.
Fruity aroma oof malts, caramel and hops.
Sweet flavour of fruits, caramel, hops and spices.
Thanks to Juancho.  Pours into a cloudy, golden color with a nice creamy head.  Beautiful malt, sweet, and subtle hops at the end.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Pours orange/ copper, with a medium head and some noble hop aroma.  Looks and smells like an octoberfest but that is where it stops.  Once again this beer is disgustingly sweet.  Way off-balance; the hops come nowhere close to balancing the enormous body of this beer.  The octoberfest seems to me to be something of a finesse style, and Avery has smacked it in the face with this mother of a beer.

Bouteille 650ml datant de 2006, courtoisie de Blankboy. De couleur cuivrée foncée et transparente. Nez malté de caramel terreux et moyennement rôti, de pain, léger de noix et de houblon herbeux aux notes terreuses ainsi que des notes de levures fruitées (notes de mangues, de pommes, de nectarine et dagrumes sucrées), de sucre bonbon, dépices (poivre) et dalcool très doux. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et légèrement croustillant ainsi quune texture bien crémeuse et aux notes sirupeuses et huileuses. Goût moyennement amer de houblon légèrement terreux et floral aux notes herbeuses (qui progresse tout au long de la gorgée) avec un léger goût de levures fruitées (léger de pommes, notes dagrumes et de pêche, traces de raisins), épicé (notes de cannelle et de poivre) et de grains de malt pâle lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel toffee sucré, terreux et rôti ainsi quun goût de pain, de biscuits au miel et de petites notes de sucre bonbon parallèlement à un léger goût dalcool moyen et légèrement réchauffant (faibles notes liquoreuses et vineuses) puis en finale lon assiste à un regain damertume de houblon plus herbeux accompagné dun léger goût asséchant de noix. Post-goût long et moyennement sec, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux et légèrement terreux, de rôti, dalcool moyen ainsi quun léger goût fruité (zest dagrumes, notes de pelures de pommes).

Dark copper pour with a thick off-white head.  Hearty aroma of brown sugar, bread, yeast and noble hops.  Unbeliveably smooth taste.  Sweet with malt, but balanced by the nobles, some cookies, vanilla, and white pepper.  I just wish they had this in my hometown.
bottle. it has a golden color with a small head. it is very sweet and malty. there is some hops and grain in it as well.

Very deep copper in colour, long lasting medium sized off-white coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is bready, some caramel, surprising amounts of hops, toasty, some yeast.  The flavour is quite hoppy, very dry and bitter, some alcohol, floral, grassy, some caramel and slight roast.  Very bitter mouthfell, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes long, hoppy, noticable alcohol heat.  Not sure how this is an Oktoberfest.  Leave it to Avery to do something over-the-top again.  At least this is drinkable and shows signs of having some balance.
650ml bottle shared by <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>beerhugger, thanks Steve.
Opened on February 16, 2007.
Vintage 2004.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2009 2009-10-18, draught at Ginger Man, NYC, 7-4-6-3-13=33Light amber color. Nice nutty and breadish malt aroma. Good body strength, malt flavor, a bit cloying. Correct bitterness. In the end, warming alcohol feeling. Average.2007-04-21, bottle, 7-5-8-4-16=40Hazy amber color; creamy head; beautiful perlage. Aroma of malt, sweet caramel, bread. Good body structure, well malty, with caramel flavor, sweet. Long and quite strong ending bitterness. German hops with some aromatic characterisitc. Excellent; very good evolution for Lagers and Oktoberfest.

The Dan Journal #50.  Sampled 10/22/06.  22oz bomber.  2006 vintage.  Filtered and amber hued.  Spiraling white head.  Aromas of caramel and cookies.  Cooked candy sugar and slight spices.  Vanilla and cirtus with a slight burn in the nose.  Full bodied with a smooth malt flavor and big kick of juice.  Sugary bready sweet.  Sticky hops in the finish.  Big beer, but delicious!

2006 bottle.  Clear deep straw colored pour with a large fluffy off white head.  Sweet malty nose with a bit of candy sugar aroma.  Smooth, slightly sticky mouthfeel with lively carbonation.  Flavor starts fairly sweet, just a touch of floral hoppiness.  Finish is slightly earthy.
[bottle] Amber colour, rich head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of marzipan. Rich flavour of sweet malt, caramel and some alcohol. Nice Doppelbo......  I mean Märzen.
Heavy malt aroma.  Medium reddish brown body with some specs of sediment.  Full palate.  The taste is mostly caramel malt with some light hops and a hint of alcohol.  Pretty darn tasty.
Bottle at KØ07. Good malty aroma. Dark copper colour, small white head. The flavour is nice, good pepper and caramelly bonbon notes.
Bottle. Amber colour. Malty, bit sweet and hoppy aroma. the flavour is quite sweet, hoppy, fruity and with some toasted maltiness and alcohol. Bitter-sweetish finsih.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Alc. 9,3% Clear amber color with a small fizzy fair lacing off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate hoppy, fruity, vintage like BW. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, syrupy, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic.

White head on dark golden body; Big malty sweet almost BW like nose; Very soft and sweet body, a bit of bitterness gives it some depth; Long a little bitter finish, soft and malty sweet. Oktober what?

2006 Bottle (9.1%).  Pretty happy about finding one of these in PartyPak, hoping its held up well.  Aroma is a load of caramel malt with good toasted notes and, yes, a touch of alcohol.  Clear copper body with medium carbonation and a medium, soapy beige head.  Body is just massive - loaded with bittersweet, slick, delicious malt.  Alcohol actually gives needed backbone to a style with the potential to be very weak - and then goes a little bit further into burning territory.  But only subtly.  Actually, the heat is nearly indistinguishable from the prickling spice at the back of the throat and lingering into the aftertaste.  Mangled German on the label is EXTREMELY ANNOYING, but the product is good enough - a malt bomb, yes, but a successful experiment.

Bottle @ Copenhagen Øl Festival 2007. Small fizzy off-white head that mostly diminished. Spar lacing. Clear flat amber colour. Rye bread, caramel, grain, fruit, medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet flavour with some toasted bitter notes. Sweet finish.
Slight unclear gold with ful lasting head. Malty grain & hop aroma. Full fruity and spicy taste - filling body. Slight warmth from alcohol. Sweetness (malty caramel) and very good lacings

2006, this pumped up marzen is a tad toasted malts and even a drop of smokiness.  It is drinkable and fine with food, but a bomber is way too much.   I get a lot of carmel offset by hops.  Well done, but Maybe 6 oz. is all I want to drink.

Sampled at a gathering of TN Ratebeerians a couple months ago; thanks to Springslicker for bringing it.  Almost clear orange in the glass, with a fuzzy sudsy white head of medium size and retention.  Smells creamy at first, giving way to some funky bread yeast; in all, reminds me of a biere de garde farmhouse smell in its maltiness.  Thickish in the mouth, warming.  I insisted in my tasting notes on describing it as syrupy, but with qualifiers like "soft" and "not too sweet" to debase that words pejorative meaning.  Flavors are like overripe fruits (mainly, glowing apricot) in a silo full of year-old maize and Indian corn.

2006 bottle. Slightly hazy copper, cap of butter-color foam. Tons of melanoidan aroma--very exaggerated bread. Rounded out with toffee and rummy fruit cake. A rich full aroma. Toasted caramel flavor, a fair amount of alcohol heat, but in the same general direction as the flavor. I liked this. Like Samiclaus, except good. It feels like an idea carried to its logical end, without getting stupid and undrinkable. I enjoyed the ride once, though I cant say this would be a regular pick. I think the beauty of a true Marzen is subtly, and this is not that.
Pleasant, fruity aroma of apple juice.  Alcohol is apparent, there is not enough flavor to mask it. This is OK -  though I am not usually much of a fan of German styles

I am the Kaiser! Seriously, I am. Slight cloudy amber with good head. Slight honey aroma. Lots of sweet malt tatse.  A bit of honey and lots of caramel sweetness with some hops to top it off. This is what it is....a beefed up marzen that doesnt really fit the style anymore. Good, but just too sweet for me.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with an off-white head. Sweet malty alcoholic and hoppy aroma with some citrus hints. Sweet malty hoppy caramel flavor. Malty bitter finish with a long bitter hoppy aftertaste.

2006 bottle. Pink golden color, frothy head. Lychee and peach in the aroma. Malty very fruity flavor (lychee, mandarin, mango, peach). Medium bodied, even a bit creamy. Hint of hops, next to the fruit, in the aftertaste.
Bottle. Caramel color with an off-white head. Spicy, caramel, earthy aroma. Big caramel, big earth flavor with spice and some backing hops. Hides alcohol well. Lingering earthy caramel.

65 cl bottle. Amber clear colour with a little fine white head. Aroma of sweet malt with notes of caramel. Nice sweet malty flavour with a nice weak feeling from the alcohol a nice and malty imperial oktoberfest beer.

22 oz Bomber-pours an off amber color w/a moderate off white head. Kind of cloudy w/a floral hop aroma. Very smooth drinking, kind of sweet w/a rock candy/cane sugar tint to it. Traces of raisens, caramel, toffee & spices. Had a nice, bitter malt backbone which provided a rich, long, full finish. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle 2004- The last one I stashed away.  This beer is no Oktoberfest. It is one to be savored many years down the road. When available, I will buy in abundance, from this point further. The beer is such a malt bomb, huge carmel. A light Samiclaus.
On tap @ MadMex: Pours a hazy orange amber in color with an off white head. Aroma, caramel, some spices, and some floral notes. Flavor, caramel, brown sugar, spicy and floral hops. Good beer.

Aroma is rich malty with some caramel in it. Amber-red colour with below average carbonation.  Off-white head which lasts longer then usual. The high alcohol contents reveals itself in the flavour, which is almost overpowering sweet, and the rest of the beer suffers from this. I normally associate Oktoberfest beer with regular easy-to-drink pilsner/wiener/lager type beers, but this one is for me over the top  although I will not go as far as bad. Ill give it an extra overall point for the cool label.

Bottle courtesy of Beerandblues2: Poured a medium brown color lager with a generous white foamy head with great retention and lacing. Aroma of nutty caramel malt is perfect with some subtle bitter hops. Taste is dominated by semi-sweet nutty caramel malt with some light slightly bitter hops. Body is somewhat creamy with no discernable alcohol. I really like the take on this style while avoiding going overboard and keeping some balance and complexity.

2006... Clear amber/copperlike color with a creamy, slight tanned head. Malt, hops, orange, apple and peach. Nice fruity taste and a nice dry bitterness. Slight uninterresting. Not the worst from Avery, but not the best either!

Poured a clear amber with a nice off white head. Aroma was a little on the weak side but wow did this have some flavor. Nice malt, hops, spice balance that left me very happy compared to the flat aroma. Very full mouthfeel felt almost like you could chew this one. Will definitely be buying this one again.

2006-pours a thick burnt orange, nice head on it too.  smells great, hops, and malt.  taste is so good, like an ipa and marzen beer mixed together.  those are my two favorite types so this is a winner for me/

A copper amber pour with a gooy lacing. An aroma of sweet malt and not hops a very sweet aroma. A flavor of sweet rich malt and alcohol. The malt handles the alcohol well. A palate that is just a tad fizzy but the malt makes it rich and creamy.  A very good beer that the carbonation keeps it from being a better beer but not bad at all.

The aroma is incredibly sweet and malty with a hefty dose of citrus hops. The appearance is amber with a foamy two finger head. The flavor is simple but very good. Its very malty and doughy while having lots of spicy hops to balance. The palate is really what makes this beer so nice. It is chewy compared to all Oktoberfest beers I have had. The finish is hoppy and sweet just like the first sip with no paper or cardboard taste. Leave it to Avery to make probably the best Oktoberfest.

2005 Edition - 22 oz. bottle. Pours a muddy, rusty color with a moderate cream colored head that faded to a thin ring. Very nice malty aroma. Nice malty flavor too with a little spice noted as well. Warming alcohol finish without the burn. Tasty.

Intrigued by the Imperial Oktoberfest. I tend to stay away from lagers but this was interesting. It was great. Great enough to make me want to go back and check out the lagers again. Surprisingly citrusy and hoppy. Nice body with a slightly alcoholic aftertaste. I had a 2005.

Bottle.  I havent had an oktoberfest in quite some time.  So I decided to give "The Kaiser" a try.  Wow!  I dont remember Oktoberfests tasting like this.  Thick foamy white head that leads into the hazy amber body.  The aroma is malty, malterness.  The flavor is a thick maltiness with some floral hints also some hops show through in the finish.  I am glad I decided to give this beer a try.  Maybe not everyday but I will try again.

Thanks to SpringsLicker for sharing this bottle with us at the Nashville Tasting! Poured an amber color with an off-white head. Spice aroma with hints of alcohol. Sweet flavor of chocolate malts and spices. Full body with a sweet aftertaste.

Imperial Oktoberfest?  Thats neat.  Awesome flavors to come out of this one.  A little bit too metallic for me, which took away from som of the later flavors.  Very sweet and bold up front with a mouthful of malt.  Those darn nazis.

Bottle thanks to Santa(Iowaherkeye). 2006 version. Poured a deep golden/amber body with big head that stayed well. Aroma is malty and sweet. Sweet malts dominating the flavor with a big notice on hops and citrus being present. Slightly bitter and syrupy. An intresting take on the Oktoberfest.

Enjoyed from a 2005 bottle.  This is excellent!  As much as I love Ayinger and even more in the off season (approaching brew time in March for Marzens), this Imperial is pipe-hitting!  Rich body balanced with appropriate hops and yeast... slight caramel context.  Hell Yeah!

This is a 2006 bottle, 22 oz. it actually says 9.3% abv on the bottle, despite the above commercial description touting a 9.1% abv. the beer pours a beautiful deep reddish amber, with a creamy, frothy off-white head. smells sweetly of malts. it tastes excellent. tremendously sweet tasting, with tons of malty goodness and an excellent mixture of hops adding to its rich, spicy flavor. very easy to drink; smooth and creamy. highly recommended.

Clear, deep amber color with white head.  Rich malt with toffee notes.  Toffe carries into the flavor with more hoppiness than would be expected in a regular Octoberfest.  Full bodied and pleasant, but not your typical fest beer.

Bottle that Springslicker brought to the Nashville Tasting. Pour amber with a small white head. Aroma was not as expected, it was more funky like a bier de garde.Lke many Avery high ABVbeers, this was sweet and syrupy. So much that it overpowers the german characteristics.
Amber colour wiht a small white head, this beer has small floral aroma with tastes of caramel and hops.  The alcohol is noticeable, but given the ABV, it is well-balanced and easy to drink.

]

Pours a clear reddish copper, topped by an inch or so of cream colored foam. Okay head retention and lacing. Sweet malt and some fruit in the aroma.

Caramelly beer, very sweet up front, loaded with caramel and dark honey. A raisiny yeast frutiness accompanies that. The hops provide good balance to a sweetish beer, with a light but lasting bitterness in the finish and aftertaste.

Full body, smooth and gently carbonated.
copper brown ale with huge off white head, the aroma is hoppy with notes of orange and caramel.  sweet and relatively thick, but drinkable.

I did not think i would like this. Im not a fan of Oktoberfest styles... but this changed my mind. Nice malty aroma, great sweetness and overall fantastic balance. A bit like an american ale more than a marzen to me. Solid beer.

The color is incredibly nice, red amber and the head is huge and creamy. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel. The flavour is sweet, very sweet, but not sticky and it has a nice counterweight in a dry citrus-bitter finish. The flavour has notes of caramel and aroma hops. 1721

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2009 09 bomber again. Just as great this time. Now I can purchase up the road, ahh. Yeah, so, a very solid, warming, Oktoberfest... then someone tells you the a.b.v., WTF!? Are you fucking kidding me? Still a very nice Euro-Strong Lager w/ added Fall complexities. Clean Yeah.

06 22oz.  A tremendously large lager! , has a strong yet deep/complex malt backbone.  The alcohol begins at its moderate level, but gets much more noticable when warmer... def. takes on a barley wine feel. agro0s description works perfectly, well said.  This is a good beer, and could be a great: a.) cheaper bomber, but hey!... b.) available in SOUTH CAROLINA  : (

Pours a clear copper with a nice fluffy head.  Interesting peppery aroma.  Light alcohol to it as well, with some caramel, bread, and dried fruit, but mostly pepper.  Tastes very bready, with some toffee, caramel, and a light roast flavor to it.  Finishes toasty, with some peppey hops to it and more bread in the aftertaste.  A little bit hot, but it wasnt too bad.  Despite the imperial moniker, this beer remained easily drinkable.  Malt flavors remained true to the O-fest flavor, which was nice.

A nice beer -- definitely full and aromatic at 9.1%, but I found it to be a bit too sweet.  Sugary malts that tend to dominate oktobfests made in America anyway were definitely here in full numbers.  Not terribly soft-spoken, but an interesting take on a style that is consistently aborted by american brewers.

(Bottle 65 cl) Clear amber golden with a creamy, off-white head. Fat aroma of caramel malt and aroma hops. Very full-bodied - looks thick as oil when poured. Extremely solid and full malt base with almost sherry-like notes. The alcohol gets quite prominent in the finish. But lovely indeed. 221206
Bottle.  Malty, good hop profile.  Much better complexity than I was expecting from and Oktoberfest.  Balanced, smooth.  Nice beer.
A hazy dark orange with a slightly orange head. Flaavor is pleasing and smooth taste of both malt and hops.
Bottled. Amber golden coloured with a rather large head. Sweet and kinda alcoholic. Notes of nuts, caramel, fruits and yeasts.

Pours an amber gold with a blonde head that is frothy and pillowy.  The aroma is nutty, caramel, sour fruit, that has a crisp nose, and is tart in nature.  The taste starts heavy on the palate syrup consistancy that has a caramel sweetness on the palate.  The alcohal is warming and smooth followed by a toasted nut, charachter througout.  The finish is again sweet with a nice hop bite that rounds out this delicious brew.

Pours clear and orangish amber with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of is surprisingly mild for this high of ABV, some notes of toasted malt, caramel, and mild estery breadiness. Taste is caramel fruity, with apparent heaviness, but remains light and transitory due to the restrained esters. Mouthfeel is full bodied and with lively carbonation. Excellent attenuation, I was hoping this wouldnt be a sticky mess, and it was digestable enough. An impressive brew from Avery!
Amber with off-white head. Weak aroma of malts and raisins. Very "clean" (lagerlike), sweet, highly carbonated with a great mouthfeel.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette, Lars, Morten, David. Clear glowing amber - white head. Sweet malty, nice hoppy, light metallic, pine, dry - strange kind but nice.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, biegaman & mds -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Vintage 2004. Pours a very cloudy copper with a small diminishing off-white head. Aroma of lots of caramel malt  and fruit along with yeast, some wood, spices and alcohol -- nice. Caramel malt flavour with some wood, fruit, alcohol and hops and a very bitter finish. Its boozy but not overly so. Medium bodied. Pretty good, Im not sure how this is an Oktoberfest, it reminded me more of a Barley Wine, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.
Bottle. Amber with huge off white/beige head. Sweet aroma with alcohol, caramel, malt and hops. Flavours delivers what the aroma promised: its sweet with caramel, nuts, fruit and malt. Nice beer.

My work here is done. Tonight is the first night of "winter" in Chicago with a drone of storm advisories drowning out a clamor of salt trucks and plows.  Id prepared for this moment hours ago, chilling a Kaiser knowing full well it would be a fitting reward after a cold, wet, miserable day of chores. 
To satisfy the beer nazis who think I shouldnt be drinking a Märzen past September, let me mention that Ive savored this beer on many occasions in the past. Ive simply never felt the need to analyze nor defend it... much in the same way I dont need to justify who I keep as my friends. To whomever questions my sensibilities, Ill simply ask them politely to go to hell. Regardless (and for the sake of civility) Ill drop a reviewers word or two: Deep amber bodied, yes, yes... with a long lasting head, yes.... but Ive poured todays beer in a huge ceramic stein in which it feels simply perfect. Thick in the mouth with ramped up hops, malts and alcohol. Balanced? Piffle. Whats the phrase? "When you have fat friends there are no see-saws, only catapults?" Thats the sense of balance you get from this fat friend. Along with the Maharaja and the Czar, The Kaiser is not a dictator to be trifled with.Yet together we relax and laugh at the growing storm outside... and Ill be calling on this old friend in the future, probably in the most remarkable of situations.
<font size=-4>Purchased several months ago from <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/palati Worldwide Liquor, Palatine, IL 60067</font>

looks like an octoberfest. heady, malty. lagerish aroma. good palate. really syrupy. alcoholish at first, not so bad after acclimation. getting better as i drink it.  i have no need to ever drink an octoberfest again.

22 oz bottle, 2005 version - Pours translucent copper with a very thin head.  It smells malty with floral hops and alcohol also present.  The flavor is of course malty, but nicely balanced with those noble hops.  I also picked up some licorice notes and later in the bottle a bit of spice.  One can also taste the alcohol somewhat.  Theres a mildly dry finish.  I appreciate the adventuresome take on the Oktoberfest style.  Avery is known for pushing styles to the limit with their Dictator and Demon series and I hope they keep experimenting.  They could have buried the alcohol a little more and had an even better brew, but this is nice.

[Bottle from Beermouth tasted with the hop-bros at Jess cosy inn.]

Really a nice wellbalanced oktoberbeer in an american way, but it keeps the german soul inside.

Bottle (650ml - bottled 2004).  Shared with biegaman, blankboy and mds - my bottle. Deep copper pour, small off-white head.  Boozy, bready  aroma of roast caramel malt, thick yeast and bitter herbal hops - nice.   Very bitter taste - syrupy grainy malt, herbal hops, longish finish - sweet and fruity, more like a barleywine.  Pretty thick body, only mildly carbonated, nice grainy toasted malt aftertaste - a little "big", but nice - held up well.

Clear almost orange amber with a huge foamy head that leaves lots of lacing in the glass.
More malts in the aroma than I expected - reminds me a bit of a wiener actually. Very good oily mouthfeel, sweet malty flavour with a nice bit of fruits and some funky hops.
Didnt really seem like an oktoberfest to me, but this is way nicer.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2007 Pours a nice clear, caramel color. Not much of a head at all. Nose is a bit bubble-gummy (my second bubble gum beer tonight) with banana in the background. Sweet malty, lightly hopped body. Malt turns a bit fruity with nice finish that tastes much like banana bread. Nice.
Bottle. Off-white high and lasting head. Beautiful clear amber body. Sweet and stong malt aroma. Fruity malt flavor with a pleasant bitterness. Notes of alcohol.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 (Daft at Barcade) Very cloudy orange copper body with a small white head.  Malty on the nose but the malty taste was not what I expected from an Oktoberfest.  Very sweet with lots of toasted barley malts and some alcohol.  Like some kind of cross between an Oktoberfest and a light barley wine.  Hops make a surprising but appreciated appearance at the very end.  Very good, brings something new to this usually rather restricted style.  When youre a german emperor you dont follow the rules, you make them.

Bottle. Amber colour with a big white head. Heavy sweet malty, corn, hop aroma and very sweet malty, light caramel, hop, alcoholic, floral taste. Medium to full body with a very sweet, light alcoholic, dry finish.
Sampled at an American Beer Tasting Event but unfortunately I forgot my notes. Sweet and malty with a nice oily palate.

Dark orange, amber colour with a large dense off white head. Malty, caramel sweet aroma with a hoppy floral note. Wellbalanced malty sweet flavor with caramel and hoppy notes and a light warming alcohol finish.

2004 bottle.  Nice dark orange/amber color with medium head.  Sweet, apple-cider and aged barleywine aroma (very similar to an aged DFH olde school).  Taste is richly sweet - honey, sweet apples, and some degree of oktoberfest-ish malts.  Not as much hops, but this is aged 2 years.  Overall, about as good as it gets for an Oktoberfest, but if it were an ale it would probably be a considered something beyond the base style.  Best lager Ive had in awhile.
I think they just make up thier own styles. Smells like a golden ale, the taste is rather medium, not too heavy, with a dry finish. Pretty good per the style.

Bottle. Pours clear with a golden color.
Head is smallish and does dissipate quickly. Aroma is dominated by fruity notes such as strawberries as well as caramel. The flavor is malty and fairly sweet, the alcohol is in the background.
One also gets some more fruit flavors combined with grains and only a faint hint of hops. Fairly big bodied with a nice finish.

Pours very clear, and bright orange with a thick, nearly white head. The aroma is full of malts, doughy bread, a little yeast, and a touch of fragrant hops. The flavor is quite malty, with a touch of fruity hop flavor, a little bitterness in the finish - quite quaffable (dangerous for a beer this strong). There is a little caramel in the flavor and the malt profile is excellently spicey and sweet. The beers finish is long and full-bodied with the hop flavor growing stronger as the finish lingers. The mouthfeel is thick and malty (almost chewy) with a nice crisp carbonation - not too thick, not syrupy, but definitely not light either. The named style of the beer (Imperial Oktoberfest) is quite appropriate.
Bottle 2006. Great looking beer. Amber color with nice thick, longlasting off-white head. Smells of malts, taste is sweet malt. Sort of like a barley wine.

Tap, OBriens. Pours a dark amber to light ruby color. Strong roasted malt aroma along with a touch of hops and some dark fruit. Very creamy mouthfeel. Rich dark fruity flavor. Very full bodied. A little alcohol is present.

Bottled in 2006, mine says 9.1% ABV.  Pours a clear orange copper with a two finger fading beige yellow head.  The aroma is toasty malts, sweet maple and brown sugar, red delicious apples and raisins, very light ETOH presence.  Some grassy and spicy hops as well.  The taste is much the same minus the apples.  Some spicy bitterness meets me up front followed by some brown sugar sweetness into a bone dry finish.  Moderately carbonated, full bodied.  ETOH is present in the finish, not terribly strong though.  A pretty good Oktoberfest.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Big flavor with a great malts sharpened by loads of alcohol. This is definitly a good beer.

One of the best looking beers I have seen. Red/copper/amber colorwith very thin head. Malty, earthy, fruity aroma. The big maltiness reminded me of an Oktoberfest beer, but the alcohol made me think I was drinking a barleywine. The flavor was big -- fruity sweet alcohol with huge malts and a bit of hop bite in the background. Very interesting and intoxicating brew. My bottle listed it as 9.3%ABV.

Poured a dark amber, colored like a grapefruit with a spotty white head.  Malty aroma, fruity and floral as well.  Yeasty, grainy flavor initially.  Heavy and thick mouthfeel which hints of the heavy alcohol.  The finish on this beer is awesome.  Its a little sour at first taste and youre not sure what to expect.  The flavor changes over your palate and is sweet, malty and delicious at the end.  I honestly anticipated alot more, it turns out to be just another oktoberfest.

Very nice lager and Im not a lager fan.  Decent yeasty/alcohol nose, poured a gorgeous copper with foamy head.  Huge malt and hops combo, with a strong finish.  A little watery for such a big beer.  Surprised that its describedas a lager.
One of the better Oktoberfests that ive had.  Very malty and some noticeable hops.  Ill tell you what, Avery makes some great beers.  Very balanced.

Big honeyed german apples and fall foliage, cold earth, sweet malts.  reddish amber with diminishing beige head.  delicious sweet alkohols, apples big barleys, not too comples though.  lightly watery? only vaguely feels imperial at all.  a little alcohol hots.
Standard coppery colored beer with almost no head.  Aroma is excellent... sweet strawberry, and a hint of smoke. Taste is same sweet and delicious with fruit and honey.. $7/22oz

Theres something absurd about an Imperial Oktoberfest, and by that label alone my anticipation of Averys craft was of a rather mediocre grade. The crepuscular copper hue transpared perfectly, displaying in full light the ugly claims of filtration, and foaming above in an ephemeral white mousse. Volatile vapors of alcohol appear sharpened upon the nose, followed by fruity tones of pear, lemon, melon and rosé wine. The sweetness of acacia honey soaks the prominent alcohol in a cloying and unpleasant combination. Malts become far more conspicuous in the flavor, blending burnt coffee, bitter caramel and honey to a an equally hot mouthfeel and strong carbonation. Despite the intense aggression this beer invokes on the palate, I found the complexity lacking, yielding nothing more than a bland and painful experience.

bottle.  clear dark copper pour with beautiful tan head.  nice lacing.  big floral, malty aroma with some oak, alochol and sugars.
nice caramel malts, fresh hops, spice and toasty.  a little thin in the body, touch syrupy and sugars are too dominant even as it warms.  mild alcohol warming.  
Good but one of my least favorite of Averys big beers.
Lots of sweet, bready, doughy, rich, and delicious malt. Hops play backup in this one. Pretty good, if you like a rich, malty beer.

holy maltyness.  this beer poured a deep brown with a tan head.  aromas of caramel, sweet bread and nuts.  very thick mouthfeel, almost syrupy.  malt, malt and more malt flavor, not much hop presence til the finish.  i think ill stick to regular strength.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Sampled at the Fall Crawl 2006 (our camping trip) Pours a medium amber with a medium head. Aroma and flavor was a nice malt with mild spices. A very good beer from Avery.

Dark amber orange color.  Aroma is a dusty malt, alcohol, and bready.  RIch bready taste, a nice spicy hop presence, alcohol is noticable.  Syrupy and sticky.  Im a fan of the Oktobersfest beers.  A fun beer to try if your not afraid of a Marzen on steroids.
nice amber color beer malty a bit hoppy, much better than the average lager and better than most octoberfest brews but when it came down to it i am not trying to drink it again

Bottle. Amber, foamy golden head. Sirupy and caramelly, a tad milk chocolate  aroma, citric hops. Big chewy fruity body, sweet caramel, candy - Aromatic hops, dry bitter finish. Medium body, light sticky mouthfeel, Sweet caramelly, light roasted and citric aftertaste. Has left the realm of Märzens long ago, but that was the point of course.

Trade with footbalm, thanks Eric. Beautiful orange color. Very thick and syrupy. It seemed as if the carbonation bubbles were having trouble making it to the top of the glass. Nice white head. Huge sweet malty taste with alcohol finish. The taste was fine at the begining but started to bother me towards the end,almost like it was too rich and malty.

On tap at Tylers in Durham, NC. Dark orange color with a light tan head. Sweet, malty, biscuity nose, notes of nectarine. Sweetly malty, intense and thick. I laughed when I read "Imperial Oktoberfest", but it really fits. Syrupy body, and the finish is more sweet malt. Somehow, the hops dont get lost, they are well represented in a spicy/floral way. Very good.

I found this one bottled at my local neighborhood Binnys in St. Charles, Illinois.  Clear, dark red pour with a thick, light orange head.  Nose of grape juice, almost like wine, apple, baked bread and apricots.  The wine continues into the body of the beer, very alcoholic in character.  Finishes sweet.  This is good.  I dont know if I just dont get into the Marzens but I dont see why this is ranked so high.

Gorgeous pour into a bitter glass. Incredibly rich orange color, like pure motor oil. The golden blonde, two-finger head held for about 5-8 minutes. Tiny, tiny, hyper-carbonated bubbles. Swirling created rapid re-carbonation. The aroma is spicy and sweet; dried leaves, dark fruits, heavy gravity. The palate is very smooth and syrupy.  Rich, sweet malts and acidic hops, balanced, somehow. I guess thats what happens when Oktoberfest gets concentrated. It truly descends/evolves an Oktoberfest.

22 oz. bottle. Pours rich copper color.  Aroma of alcohol, florals, and hops.  Taste of hops with some malt and spices and evident alcohol.  Bottom line:  I like this beer, but it is probably not what you would expect from a more malty and less alcohol German-stle beer

This is a very beautiful example of the style...Deep copper colour, thick creamy head that barely diminishes. The carbonation is good on this one is adds a nice visual touch to the beer. The flavour is quite rich, fairly thick in the palate as well. There are some nice toasty malts with some spice notes up front. The malts present a pretty sweet flavour but is well balanced by just a bit of hops.
Poured with a nice copper color, clear, thin body, boozy presence for sure, sweet flavor, spiciness helps cover some of the alochol, better as it warmed up

2006 22 oz Bomber, 9.1% ABV. Crystal clear copper color with fluffy off white head. Striking appearance. Strong spicy hop aroma with just a hint of sweet and nutty malts. The flavor hits up front with a load of noble hop spicy flavor and bitterness and some sweet malts. As the taste experience progresses the hops seem to recede and the sweet maltiness builds. The hops are still the main flavor component right to the end. Nice rich mouth feel with some sense of the ABV. This beer may need some more cellaring to peak and bring out more of the malt flavors that are now playing second fiddle to the hops.

22 oz bomber, 2006 version. Im kind of a pursit when it comes to mazen/Oktoberfest bier, so I was really too interested in an "Imperial" Oktoberfest, and found it to be a gimmick. Glad, I gave this beer a shot, as Avery did a good job with this one, and really has created a beefed up version of marzen/Oktoberfestbier. This beer pours to a beautiful, bright, deep amber color, with a thick and creamy head, and a good carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent, with lots of good toasty, and nutty malt aromas. The palate is firm, with a slick mouthfeel, on a very smooth body. Lots of good toasty and nutty malt coat the tongue, with hints of malted milk ball sweetness. This beer finishes with more good toasty and nutty malt up front, then ends with some really good grassy/herbal hop bitterness to balance out the malty character of this beer. The 9% abv is hidden well in this beer. You get a little heat in the finish, but this is a rich, hearty, delicious beer.

22oz bottle that I picked up while in Denver at the 2006 GABF. 9.1%. There are about 6oz left and the bottle has been open for an hour. Pretty copper color and a small persistant head. Aroma is tons of malt with honey and brown sugar hints. The alcohol and grassy, earthy hops stick out too. A bit of spice as well. The initial taste is very sweet and malty, almost like pure wildflower honey followed by a rush of warming, but appropriate alcohol and a moderate bitterness.
