The finish is spicy with lingering noble hops flavor. Nice mouthfeel. Pretty tasty and certainly unique.

Bottle.  Not a typical Oktoberfest.  Very full bodied.  Murky and deep orange on the pour.  Less malt flavor and more hop and alcohol flavors than traditional Oktobers.  That being said - very delicious and unique.  Give it a try for sure.
Pours amber into a shaker.  Significant white micro head leaves no lacing as it slowly recedes.  Malt and alcohol aromas.  More alcohol than Oktoberfest in from front to back.

Poured a dark orange with a large white head.  Unappealing aroma... slight spiciness masked by a tart, alcoholic bitterness.  Full bodied and rich on the palate for an "oktoberfest."  Taste is lightly hoppy with a spicy pumpkin finish.

2006 bottle, 9.1%.  Good-sized, fluffy, white head that lasts and leaves great lacing; body is clear and orange.  Nose is sweet, toasty caramel, with faint noble hops noted.  Flavor is intersting and not what I expected.  Big, sweet malt flavor is dominate with toasty, caramel, brown sugar, and maybe apricot?  Alcohol is present and powerful but well hidden.  Palate is medium bodied and lively with a creamy texture, but lacking the crisp lager palate usually noted in OFests.  Finish is still sweet with only a slight hop bitterness emerging.  This one is too young and needs some time to complex, but lacks the hop character to make a great Imperial.  Such a great hybrid syle, but never meets its expectations.

2006 bottle, 9.1%. Pours orange with a lasting white head. Aroma of malt and a few spices. Taste is of malt and alcohol which is not so well hidden. Rather thick and oily palate. Balanced finish, slightly dry. A decent and respectable offering, but could be a bit better.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 The people of Germany, their kin and their adoring fans have much to be proud of in Germanys cultural heritage.  It bore the birthing pains of Protestantism, is marked by an acute proficiency in engineering and philosophy and is responsible for the manufacture and export of some of the finest seasoned and cured sausages.  And anybody who treats meat and its consumers with that kind of respect is okay in my book.  But lets face it; the Kaiser was a fool.  I distinctly remember my A.P. European History teacher praising the practical and often cruel genius of Otto von Bismarck, then relegating Kaiser Wilhelm II as the Shtoopid shtoopid boy that messed up Bismarcks calculated plans.  It seems unflattering for Avery to christen one of those beers as one of Europes most celebrated regal dunces, but the name is fitting.  Averys Kaiser is altogether inadequate; it fails to live up to a loftier legacy of brewmanship with the same flare of ineptness that marked Wilhelms catastrophic statesmanship.  It is a typical pumpkin colored beer with a defiantly large head that compresses, developing a center of bigger bubbles and a periphery of smaller ones.  Beneath the optical delectation is a deceptively full aroma  pumpkin, brown sugar, vanilla, hops, malt, orange and coriander twist and turn amongst themselves to develop a candied sweet sniff.  And there, even further is the truly fulsome taste.  Its a plain and humble flavor, but proud of its humility; the worst kind of humble.  It seems flat and tamed, like an ESB with a delicate touch of pumpkin, pumpkin pies brown sugary sweetness and an enveloping smooth texture.  These qualities, though pleasant, deny the Kaiser any level of complexity itd need to be a defining beer experience.  That aside, its a reasonable well brewed beer for casual company on a casual day, in the same way that Germany would have been better off having their Kaiser a casual man working in a casual profession in a casual town as far away from Berlin as Bismarck could have booted him.  We cant loathe either the beer or the man, but we know theres better, and thats my take on Avery as much as its a historical judgment of the perils of monarchy in 19th century Europe.

Just got trough with a current vintage and last years as well.  First of all, this beer, with a year of age is amazingly dangerous.  The light touch of alcohol bite is completely gone and has given way to a malt cream that smooths the beer down the throat.  The label decries exactly what it is, a big Marzen.  Apricots and other dried fruit acompanied by a sensational hop spice really make this one a moutful.

This is worth your money.

06 22oz bottle- An orangy amber body with a faint haze and a white head that dissipated quickly. Has an aroma of alcohol and a faint maltiness. Taste of malt and a lot of alcohol with a caramel malt mix in the middle. The alcohol taste is on the back end. Not bad but was expecting something different.

2005 bomber. Murky, opaque russett; thick, creamy beige head. Completely inappropriate nose: soapy and caramelly, with notes of artificial chocolate syrup and cherry cola. Oxidized? Swiss cheesey, woody, and chocolately flavor. WTF? Intensely dry finish with offensive charcoal-y rough bitterness. Medium palate. Aftertaste is muddy, phenolic, and harsh as broken glass. Like chewing on a burnt circuit board. Absurdly unbalanced, utterly crappy. Hard to imagine that even without flaws, this could ever be called an oktoberfest. Something was very wrong with this beer when it went into the bottle.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 Clear, dark copper, with a sturdy eggshell head. Spicy, caramelly aroma. Intense malty sweetness at first, followed by a crisp, almost but not quite sour hop bite. On tap at Barleys, Asheville.
Clear deep yellow, frothy head that dies quickly.  Faint malt aroma.  Taste is intense malt.  Perfectly adequate palate.
Good golden red body with a nice white ehad.  Slight soap aroma, some honey with wheat.  Semi-dry and sweet ending.  Overall, not bad though Ive found better beers to have for Oktoberfest.

2006 bottle. Clear auburn pour with a big fluffy head. Interesting aroma, nutty and sharp, with gin botanicals/juniper, spice, vodka. Similar flavor, with very spicy hops, strong caramel, almond, amaretto. Really not that malty for 9%, and very well balanced, not to mention quite unique.

2006 bottle. A light amber orange. Thin but persistent head and lace. Nose of sweet malts which are caramelly and a bit toasty. Spicy hops noticable as well as an alcohol presence. Medium-full body, malty as hell, lots of lingering hop spice, alcohol warmth and a bit of flavor that lingers in finish a bit. Lots of flavor and a nice kick. Its good and damn drinkable but just doesnt blow my doors off for some reason which was suprising seeing I though this was right up my alley. Will revisit to see if I was in a pissy mood or something.

This is a big bitch...can you say kaiser soze.  This one smells good.  Huge malt a little too much alcahol burn...I think Avery kicked this one up a notch this year...I dont recall it being a 9er...ABV=9.1 on the 2006 batch.  Adam likes brewing big examples of different styles...if that makes any sense.  AIGHT!
Clear red body with a small off-white head. Sweet caramel and light spice aroma. Sweet caramel and spice flavor.

Nice Amber to light orange hue with no head.  Aroma is a bit of citrus, wheat, alcohol is there also.  Taste is a bit of caramel along with honey, wheat, and a touch of alcohol.  Alcohol is well covered.

22 oz. bottle on 9/13/06. Pours a clear amber with a medium off white head. Smells toasty and grainy - a ncie malt dominated aroma. Rich and smooth with a medium/full body and very light carbonation. Just a bit of spicy bitterness helps offset a big caramel malt sweetness. Alcohol was never a prominent feature. Quite enjoyable and drinkable.
22 oz bottle 2006 bottle:  beautiful clear copper color with off white head. matly aroma with nice fruity caramel notes.  big maly caramel flavors.  sweet and fruity.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 Rerate 2007: Oh boy, Im getting a bad smell from this years version.  Medicinal and artificial sugar.  Maybe some dietcytal notes as well.  Im sorry Avery, but this is undrinkable.  Very disappointed.  Last years version was a little sugary, but this is a drain pour.  Based on this experience, I cant say Ill be doing the Kaiser experiment any longer.

Original Rating 2006: I have found Avery brews to be very hit and miss.  Poured this from a 22 oz. bomber.  Very sweet malty backbone and true to the style.  A good octoberfest impression.  Notes of apricot, butterscotch, caramel.  I would say this is one of Averys better offerings.  The sweetness slightly detracts from the beer being world class. 
Aroma: 7 
Appearance: 3 
Flavor: 7 
Palate: 4 
Overall: 15 
Total Score: 3.6

Tastes just what it sounds like it would.  I am no expert on Oktoberfests so I shouldnt say anything bad but can say that since this style is so delicate, when you put 9% ethanol in there you can taste it.  I couldnt ignore the alchohol warming - it was intense.  Neat beer for novelty but not balanced and I wouldnt buy this again - although I am happy I gave it a try.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2007 Rerate.  Odd hop aroma that doesnt fit very well with the style, but it doesnt smell bad.  Flavor is sweet, really, really sweet, but there is also a ton of alcohol in t here, and in my opinion, so much so that it damages the quality and negatively impacts the flavor.  Score lowered from previous tasting.

2005 Bottle. One year old. Clear amber color with creamy white wisps. Aroma is actually kinda fruity, a little alcoholic and beautifully malty. The flavor is much better than I expected. A little spicy a little alcoholic. Big fully body. A heck on an octoberfest.

bottle.  Brown/amber with a medium off white head.  Aroma is hoppy, sweet malts/caramel, raisins/plums and alcohol.  Taste is about the same, strong alcohol in the finish.  could have used some more age I think.
Édition 2005. Robe cuivrée très claire aux reflets ambrés surmontée dune mousse jaunâtre persistente. Arômes de pain et de caramel. Saveurs de pain, de caramel, de levure et de houblon amérisant.
2005 bottle.  Poured a dark amber with tannish head.  Smells raisiny and sweet.  Alcohol is there but not overpowering taste-wise.  Hops in the taste too, and well balanced with spicyness.
Very boozy, with lots of malt.  The alcohol is not well diguised.  Not terrible but not my favorite.

9.3% 2004. Pours amber dark with creamy tan , large head. Rich , full aroma with massive amout of malt that was gently touched by bitter hops . Rich , juicy malts neatly submerged in this alcoholi, potent brew . Big lager, surley. Sipper , but good sipper .

Bottle. 2004 vintage. Pours a cloudy brown-orange body with a medium-sized fluffy white head receding to slight bubbles. The aroma has oranges, fruity apricot hops, bread, and caramel. The alcohol is around right from the beginning as one might expect with Avery stuff; but in this case its not overwhelming. Interestingly bitter with well balanced bread caramel sweetness. Light carbonation. Certainly an interesting take on the style and definitely has some parallels with the American Strong classification. A solid sipper.

West coast hoppy nose, some malt, deep orange, small custard head. Taste has a big hops start, a fine malt backbone. Full bodied, quite bitter, in fact the hoppiest of the style Ive tried. Extremely good beer, yet it doesnt suit the style? Thanks very much mds.

another found rating.  this was quite a good oktoberfest.  had an amber appearance with some carmel malt, munich malt, some spice, and some clove aroma.  the flavor was also clove with some pennies, carmel, perfume, and just a hint of roasted malt in addition to the munich and carmel.

Nice aroma of caramel, toffee, fruit and some citrusy hops. Pours a real dark hazy amber with an off-white head with pretty good retention. Great lacing. Very malty. Lots of caramel, brown sugar, and fruit. Definitely a spicey finish with just barely an alcohol presence. Hops linger in the background and really blend mix well. Somewhat bock-like. An excellent Oktoberfest. Probably the best Ive had.

"Ah well they tried. Poured a amber color with okay head but didnt lace very well at all. Aroma was of caramel. Flavor was of caramel as well some spices and way to sweet. This one missed the mark, although i dont have much to compare it to."

Pours a caramel orange amber color with a very nice initial head that sat around for a while but didnt lace great. The aroma was of caramel and toasty notes. The flavor had a lot going on, but it wasnt all that great. Caramel, tea bags, light spices, toasty/bready notes, and generally sweet. Mouthfeel was a bit sticky, although the alcohol wasnt too strong. Ah, Im not a huge fan of this one, but give em props for trying to expand the style.
Aroma is rich with malt and hops, with an almost orange scent.  Very heavy, with a good balance of hops and malt.  A tad sweet for my tastes.  But, overall not bad and quite a good deal.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: I believe this was a 2005 bottle.  Pours a crystal clear amber- almost like a new shiny copper kettle.  Thin and lasting head- some lace.  Aroma is sticky sweet with lots of light munich, melanoiden, and light crystal malts- very low on the herbal hops- almost none in fact- jsut pure malty sweetness.  Flavor is much the same with mostly malt, and a touch of hop bitterness in the end to keep from getting cloying.  I actually expected this beer to be very malty sweet and cloying- thus I wouldnt like it, but turns out I did like this stuff quite a bit and am glad I saved a bottle to age for a bit.  This should be nice in another year.  Very much like a malty sweet barleywine as others have noted.
bottle, at Dickinsonbeers pre-TAP gathering.  bright copper color, aroma is sweet syrupy malt like a barley wine.  flavor is also strong malty sweet like a barley wine.

2004 bottle from BBB63.  Dark copper with some great orange highlights.  A creamy biege head.  Tons of beautiful, resinous, sticky belgian lace.  Crazy aroma.  Ridiculous amounts of toffee, caramelized sugar, spicey, and floral aromas.  A very long drawn out drink.  It starts off quite caramelly, mapley sweet, crosses the tongue, then hits you with some rather intense bitterness, and finishes with a soft alcohol burn.  Ahhhh.  Full bodied and sticky in the mouth, this beer is very under rated.  Thanks a million for this treat Mike.  I will do my best to repay you.

2005.  Nose of spice, berries, raisins, and oats.   Pours a clear copper.  The large stiff
creamy off white head is fully lasting with decent lace.  Alcohol sweetness greets the
tongue immediately.  The immense fruity bouquet dances about the palate.  However, the
alcohol and malt are forced to duel with a strong hops presence for the drinkers attention. 
The finish is floral spicy hops and becomes much more pronounced as the brew warms. 
The full creamy body is uber soft.
Red-amber color accompanied by a small white head. Malty aroma, toast and caramel. Moderately sweet, some malty caramel notes. Well balanced and not overly alcoholic. Not bad.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, citrus, and sweetness. Flavor is malty, sweet, and alcohol.
Pours a nice deep dark amber color.  Aromas of bread, caramel, fruit and nut.  Flavor has a nice big malty taste with a almost noticable hop finish.

Beer pours a clear, medium brown-amber color with a small, frothy, white, mostly and quickly and diminishing. The aroma is bold, bitter-sweet and estery: Heavily malty with notes of toasted grain, cookie and caramel; Sharply hoppy with heavy notes of resin/pine, dried apricot and herbs; Light yeasty note of bread dough; Miscellaneous notes of heavy sherry, raisin, moderate notes of alcohol, peach, white pepper. The flavor is heavily sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter with a long, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish full of tummy-warming alcohol. The body is light-to-medium, the texture is almost velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Appearance: Pours a rusty orange color that is nearly completely opaque. Light tan minimal head that fades quick, but leaves some residual lacing that sticks around.
Aroma: Sweet malty nose, slightly pungent and rich like candied plums but not too fruity. 
Flavor profile: Big sweet syrupy malt, but not overpowering. A slight understated hop smell and a bread-dough mouthfeel and texture. Big flavor, big presence, and at 8.9% its got a big alcohol kick to it. 
Palate: Wet and quenching, thick but not too much, warming and overall not too bad. I think this would be a killer ale if it was oak barrel aged.

The aroma of this beer is of oak, fruit/berries, and hints of vanilla.  It is a copper colored solution with a thick off-white head that dissolves slowly leaving moderate lacing behind.  This moderately thick beer has mildly bitter taste of fruit, oak, and caramel with a biscuit taste in the background.  It fades a little hot with the flavors of oak and caramel lingering.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 2006 release: Brew pours a burnt orange, firey copper color w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Good head retention receding to a fluffy ring of lace / a full dusty canopy. Aromas of earthy, sweet cherry malts. Full nectar w/ creamy residual effers. The creamy texture turns squeaky like moving around on a raft in the pool while sun bathing. Big ripe cherry malts push forward stealing the show away, but from whom ? Theres no competition here. Like rushing to be first in line and no one else shows up. Theres a defined yet mild hop component that gives its all to help balance it out but its efforts are futile. The gobby caramel runnith over and drown thine hoppy stickers. Other nuances of sweet maple, sugar cane, tree bark, soft leather, ripe red apple milk. The finish never ends and barely bitters, just a faint acidic twitch. Alcohol is well hidden like a poisoned apple. The 2006 release is much better than the 2005. ******************2005 release: Amber honey in color. Smells like fresh cut bailed hay. Pours a thick, clumpy froth with long hang time. Full nectar up front yet finishes thin and runny. Smooth with a slight sweetness. Big bread and malted hay flavors w/ a spicey, slight bitter finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Score: 3.3

2005.  Ruby amber.  Malty, surprisingly maerzen-y aroma, with loads of sweet malts and some melanoidins, with some noble hops and sharp alcohol.  Medium bodied. Long malty flavor, rich and warming, some persistant alcohol, but thats understood for its nearly 9% alcohol.  This is extremely drinkable and surprisingly octoberfest-y for the imperial label and alcohol content.  Im pleasantly surprised.

Aroma:malt,peper,ligh cooked veghetable,hops....
Appearance:Clear orange,small white head...
Flavor,fruity,carmael,ligh peper,alcohol....

(bottle - 22 oz: 2005 vintage) Clear copper/red pour with a thick but quickly fading tan head and good lacing. Lots of malts in the aroma with other sweet notes and the slightest bitter hint. Mainly sweet malts. Flavor is very sweet and malty, like a good and strong Oktoberfest with a very nice but subtle hop balance and a smooth and warming finish. Alcohol is hidden nicely.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 Bottled in 2004 (9.3% ABV).  Poured out a nice deep copper color, mostly clear with a medium-sized whitish head.  Aroma is very nice and complex, very malty, a bit sugary, but not in a bad way, some notes of citrus.  Very malty flavor, quite sweet.  Mostly malty but pretty well balanced with hop flavor.  Alcohol content is somewhat noticable on the tongue.  Very thick mouthfeel with a long sweet, almost chocolate finish.  This is an excellent Octoberfest, though its pretty malty for my tastes.  Not a session beer (at least not for me).

Sweet, sugary nectar aroma; almost like cotton candy. Slightly hazy amber body with steady carbonation and a thin, off-white head. Excellent, sheet lace. At first swallow, doesnt really blow my socks off; tastes like a regular Ofest, albeit sweeter than most. At second swallow, the considerable acohol is more evident. At 3rd sip, the hops chime in, and at that point you know this is no ordinary ofest. This is a very strong brew, despite their "toning it down" from last years version. I dont think it needed to be this strong to be good. Granted, its an imperial Ofest, so its supposed to be strong. This style is a little bit of an oxymoron. Oktoberfest is about drinking mass quantities of beer; if you had one mass of this stuff, youd be in a word of hurt. Therefore, its less an ofest than an imperial IPA is an IPA. About midway through my first glass I am still looking for the wow factor and its not coming. It tastes like they just threw alcohol at it. I still like it better than 90+% of the ofests Ive had (or perhaps 97.5% according to the style percentile). After pouring the last of the bottle into my glass, the beer takes on additional depth of flavor.

2005 22oz bomber: Big Big beer!! Pours a clear orange color with a medium head that lasts. Aroma is sweet with cooked citris and decaying flower. Flavor is a blast of sweet malt, a twinge of hop and alcohol in the finish. The aftertaste accually gets more plesant after a few seconds which keeps dragging you back for another drink. This is one that I prefer colder than normal. The sweetness became too much when it got near room temp. It would be nice if it were sold in 12ozers.

Man, the folks at Avery outdid themselves this time. This one deserves the accolades. My favorite Oktoberfest by far. Cool bottle = extra points too. Is it really an Oktoberfest, though? Kinda HUGE and POWERFUL for a medium body brew. Still, even if you called it a  Chardonnay, Id lift a heavy stein to the sky. Wonderful.
One of the few Oktoberfests Ive had thus far.  Brownish amber pour with a nice hoppy aroma.  Malty flavor with a decently alcoholic finish.  Nothing Id try again.

2005 Bottle: Big, sweet toasted orange aroma; spicy hops and huge marmalade tartness with a prickly alcoholic palate but a bit viscous; duffle-bags of noble hops, enough to keep it from being too sweet; doesnt finish dry like an Oktoberfest; interesting, but I cant say Im crazy about it.

Bomber bottle from World of Beer, Clearwater.  Poured a nice deep translucent amber-brown with reddish highlights and a medium sized brownish head.  Lotsa sweet malt in the nose with quite a hop presence.  Nice full mouthfeel matched well with the fruity malt flavor...I liked the spicy hop balance, but one thing had me thinking....this is unlike any "Octoberfest" beer Ive ever tried.  Nice dry finish.....this one surprised me.

Bomber bottle. Poured a clear brown with a large frothy light brown head that was lasting and produced excellent lacing.  Heavy malt and heavy hops aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky texture. Full well balanced flavor with a moderate bitter finish. Very good brew.

2005 vintage. In the bomber bottle. I knew this had to be good because they put aluminum foil over the top of the bottle, right? This is a MONSTER. It is a märzen in name only. Maybe if I took an entire barrel of Spaten Oktoberfest and vacuum evaporated it to 22 ounces while adding a brick of hop pellets, I might end up with this lager. Yes, the ethanol is strong and mean, but what you should really love about this beer is the complete palate. Beers just dont get much thicker. You could hide strychnine in here with all this malt masking power. You dont really drink this, you just tear off your sips using your incisors. I just cant imagine the crazy people who can and do get this on tap. Life is good.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2005 Deep orange/amber with a off white head. Aroma is huge  malt and some roast. It is a powerfully tasty aroma. Nutty just pure aroma domination here. Body is malty and nutty 9% ABV not noticable. Has a milky texture.  The hops come through ever so slightly at the end to let you know they are there, but nothing more. The octoberfest all should be judged by. Massive malt monster for the style.

aroma of alcohol, sugary malts and some hops.  orange amber color with a big orange head.  light bodied.  chewy texture.  big malty beer with a quick hop finish.  still good even after averys "intensification". similar to an english strong ale, like old jubilation.  a bit too alcoholic.

2005 Bottle. Copper color with rust discoloration. Aroma of toasted malts doused in honey. A condensed version of a regular marzen,thick and ultra sweet, with touches of nutmeg and assorted spices. A lingering film of sugar in the finish. Impressively large for the style, but way more than you would ever need or want in an Oktoberfest.

Tea, honey, baklava, peanuts.  A nice malty sugary combo that somehow manages to not be as terribly alcoholic tasting as Averys other big beers.  Hopped appropriately with spicy overtones but not so much as to ruin the sticky finish.  Really not bad.

Went into this one not expecting much cause thus far Avery hasnt impressed me. Well, they finally did it! This beer pours out a nice ruby/orange color with a snall head. There is a nice aroma of sweet malts. The taste is rather complex for this style, nice fruit and some good notes of hops, dry as youd expect, but none the less a great brew.

Bomber, bottled in 2005.  You know, this whole Imperial thing is getting out of hand.  Just because you take a certain style, and add a little bourbon, doesnt necessarily make it better.  Imperial Oktoberfest is a bit much.  Pours clear and orange with a good head, pretty much like any other marzen.  Very earthy and malty aroma and a tad metallic.  Very sweet and spicy in the mouth, but the alcohol really knocks things out of balance.  Dry and tingly (is that a word?) finish.  I seriously think they added some scotch to a normal oktoberfest.  Not something Ill for again.

2005 bottle. The day after Thanksgiving, what better beer to share amongst ourselves. Pours a nice clear orangish brown with a fluffy head. Aroma smells of toasted malts, sweet caramel apples, a bit of citrus, hints of floral hops. I left it outside overnight so the first sip was ice cold. Nice sweetness likend to brown sugar and full mouth feel. As I kept drinking and it warmed up, the malts and earthy spices really came through. It was nice and strong with a nice dry hoppy back of the mouth taste.

Pours an absolute crystal clear orange, lightly tinted red, with golden fringes. Topped with a creamy off-white head that stays thick and provides nice lacing. Aroma is a light, sweet malt backed with lemongrass, fresh jalapeno and some barbeque. Flavor is intense. Extremely creamy and lucious fruity malt, loaded with figs and pears and light apple. Flavor moves across the tounge with elegance and sheer volume. Alcohol really rounds this Octoberfest, as lesser ones usually lack some fullness from lesser strength. An almost perfumy fruit quality to it, like mulled wine. Crisp clean malt on the back end, mingled with grassy hops. Most interesting is that the palate is what shines strongest for this beer, with the liquid cream, warm alcohol, yet balanced with a bright soda level and finishing with a smack of hop dryness. In my opinion a perfect palate. A very appreciable interpretation of the style.

(picked up from liquid solutions..thanks guys!i am very curious to try my first imperial oktoberfest)the kaiser poured a clear orange with no head what so all.aromas were pumpkin,spice,and sweet malts.flavor was of the aroma plus ice tea,cola,and seltzer water.i was very impressed with the mouthfeel on this one,and the palate was nice and complex...good stuff avery.

Bottle of the 2005 vintage.  A dark orange-amber color with a cream colored head.  The aroma was sweet with a sugar spice and apple.  A sweet, rich and spicy flavor.  The lager element was more obvious than I would have thought.  Sweet, earthy, caramel and a sparkling sharp spice.  The alcohol is noticeable.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2006 Rerate. The first time this was hella better, but my palate has changed. Same aroma with a highly detectable alcohol note. While other Oktoberfests have balance, this one came off as a reckless mess of flavors. Oh its Avery? Ok whatever. Still enjoyable, but definitely flawed. A better one awaits..

Pours with a two-finger cream head that fades slowly and leaves a ton of lace.  Clear amber color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Nose is a malty bread.  Starts sweet with a good malt/hop mix, stronger flavor than normal Oktoberfest.  $7.99 for a 22oz bottle from Julios Liquors Westborough, Ma.

22 oz bomber.  Dark copper color with a thin head, nice lacing. Taste is all malts, and then the alcohol burn kicks in.  A little too much of an alcohol flavor for an Oktoberfest in my opinion, kind of ruined the beer for me. Makes me want to look Uncle Frizt right in the monacle and say NEIN.

Bottle. Deep red/copper with small white head. Aroma is sweet and caramelly with hints of rose hip. Smooth pleasant mouth feel with lots of texture. Flavor is malt dominated (surprise!) with a nice (wal)nuttiness. However, there is an aftertaste that I also find in many doppelbocks, that I do not care for in this beer... like vegetable or something (not DMS like) ... probably it is byproducts from fermenting high gravity wort with a lager yeast or something - maybe it is just the munich malt (which I suspect has been used in vast quantities for this brew). Alcohol is very incredibly integrated and the bitterness is perfectly balanced with the huge malt body, making this beer a winner anyway. However, I cannot understand why it is not categorized as a doppelbock, which it really is, right?

Pours a big time ruby red brown, has a great head, and decent lacing, great bitterness that tickles my ribs.has a musky kick-your-ass sweetness. The Kaiser is a tasty smooth yet rip roaring strong brew. crunchies! just b careful!

2005 Bomber:  Now, this is my idea of an Oktoberfest - a deep amber, near red body with a dense, rocky, off-white head - a rich, sweet malt aroma breathing out wafts of alcohol - a heavy malty flavor balanced with some earthy hop bitterness - and an alcohol kick, to boot!  Excellent drinking.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Frankfort, IL<font size=-1>

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2006 2006 version. Bright clear amber with a thick white head. Ridiculously sweet and malty aroma. Strong apple smell. Silly sweet with a syrupy mouthfeel. This 2006 draft version is ridiculously alcoholic at the end and rather unpleasant.  Might never try again.

Clear coppery amber with a dusty yellow cap of small stature but firmly thick. Thin sheeting lace sticks well with some moth holes strewn across.

Aroma is a bit subdued if not super clean and sweetly set in a malt sided waft of melon candy and slight caramel drenched golden raisins.

Taste is pretty darn big on the malts. A slight step above what a normal Oktoberfest would be as it has an evident warmth and broad dobblebock stickyness to its character. Fairly chewy and malty smooth with a warming bready malt center and slight candied melon parts. Nicely rounded in hop tones make a slight floral and spice appearance in the finish.

Feel is big and malty with a heavy thick, rich, and lush creamy smoothness that tilts to an acceptable cloying measure of balance.

A big and sweet warming Oktoberfest thatll make for some good Fall time drinking. It says right on the label "Imperial Oktoberfest", yeah, thats a pretty close conclusion of what this is, if not just a straight up dopplebock.

Draft. Brilliant copper. Light khaki head. Pretty beer. Intense fruity aroma but on the acidic side of things. Sweet tomatos and a little bit of green viney edge. Some bubblegum as well. Hop bitternes at first in the mouth. Very IPA-like or american strong aleish. As it warms it takes on some fruity belgian qualities and then finishes very dry. Slight plastic lager edge. This is a well crafted beer.

(Bottle)   Pours a lightly cloudy burnt orange body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, grapes, and pumpkin spice.  Flavor is malty with caramel and vinous.  This is probably the best Oktoberfest beer Ive had.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2009 2005 Bottle, Halloween night. And the last time the White Sox won the Series, there still was a Kaiser Okay, enough of that. Sweet, malty marzen smell when opened and poured. Should not be drinking this after any Halloween candy. Deep copper color, almost like ancient amber with extinct species of insects trapped in it. Pours a thick German head that leaves a big rime around the glass. Taste is definitely strong, a little bit mediciny, though, and reminiscent of fine caramels. A definite hop pack wanders in, more than youd find in the average Okto, to try and hold a balance aainst the malts (and ultimately losing). Gotta say its everthing they promised. If you cant go subtle, go imperial!

22oz bottle - Pours copper with a nice offwhite creamy head that laces pretty well down the glass.  Aroma of caramel.  Very malty and a bit of german hops.  Flavor is rich and malty.  Nice caramel, and toffee flavors abound in this one.  Much bigger than any marzen Ive had before.  Some brown sugar and a nice alcohol finish.  The palate is full bodied and creamy almost buttery mouthfeel.  Another nice beer from a great brewer!

Bottle-An Oktoberfest beer with a bit of everything, extra alcohol, lots of malt/caramel flavor with a hop taste sitting right there too, along a bitter taste and sweet finish.  Looks like an Oktoberfest but has a lot going on behind the appearance.
22oz bottle fron LES  Reddish, orange ,color very fall like.good malty sweet flava . straight up brown shgar spice . not too much like other Ofest brews.overall pretty good a marzen on steroids

Rusty orange hue, poured from a 22 oz bottle:  Butterscotch, caramel, sweet grainy nose, faintly alcohol and resinous hops.  Palate is slightly chewy, caramel, grain, husky grain, brwon sugar, how you taste so sweet.  I must say I enjoyed this one, but my lady friend seemed to enjoy it more...Finishing with sticky hops, nicely balanced, alcoholic smack.  Nicely done I must say.  I consistently enjoy Averys products.

Bottle, from Julios. Ok nose, Sweet, apple, caramel, hints of cinnaminn, brown sugar. Clean reddish orange color, ok head that faded away. Bittersweet flavors, like aromas caramel upfront fruit and spice in back. Thick body, creamy syrupy mouthfeel, bittersweet finish. Good beer, warmed up nicely.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: This beer is such a cool concept and I must say the bottle labeling is beyond stellar. That being said, the beer itself was a nice burnt sunset color and had a solid caramel spice thing goin in the aroma. I got caramel cooked up with some roasted brown sugar in the body  mainly, and it was damn fine.

Bottle poured a dark red amber with athick white head and lacing.
Aroma ofsweet malts, alcohol and ripe fruit.
Flavor is spice, sweet, citrus, caramel.
Light sweet alcohol finish.
Easy drinking and not overly sweet.

2005 version.  Thanks Legion242.  Crystal clear, deep orange colour beer, thin tan head.  Malty, sweet, vineous aroma with a bit of brown sugar.  Rich but clean.  Flavour is also sweet but nicely balanced by an assertive spicy noble hop aroma and flavour.  Sweet, but never cloying.  Well-balanced and dangerously drinkable.  Another great beer.

This is finally an Avery that is about more than being big. Looked like an ordinary Oktoberfest, but it had a bigger malt aroma. Flavor was sweet then spicy with a thick palate. The alcohol is much more subdued and adds rather than detracts.

This was a really BIG sweet beer. A reddish orange appearance. A hoppy and alcohol filled nose. The flavor is full of caramel, grapefruit, oranges, and some mild spice thrown in. The alcohol does show in the finish. The beer has a very cloying and syrupy aspect to it. Good in small amounts but I dont know if I could finish the bomber myself.

On the surface, this is just a normal Oktoberfest. Deep, clear mahogany body is topped by a small, creamy head. The aroma is mostly malt in the caramels that youd expect from an ofest. There is a bit more hops than youd expect and this bit of alcohol that you definitely wouldnt expect under that maltiness, however. The flavor has a good wood and caramel maltiness. Very clean. Theres a bit more bitterness than usual, but then, theres also a bit more sweetness than usual, so they end up balancing each other out. The slight warmth of the alcohol helps cleanse the palate after each sip. Really much better than I expected. It really tastes like a normal, good Oktoberfest except scaled up to doppelbock strength.

Hazy medium amber colour.  Complex whole grain malt notes with toast and light caramel.  Complex malt, with lots of earthiness and a light flowery hop note.  Drinks very nicely for a beer of its size.  WIth the marzeny malt complexity and drinkability wrapped in a large format, theyve nailed the concept and I quite like it.

Bottle (2005). Pours a light, clear copper color with a yellow-white head. This smells a lot like light malt extract. The flavor is initially straight up malted barley. It fades into some subtle hops and alcohol, and by the finish has the characteristics of a more traditional Oktoberfest. Not bad for this style (which is not among my favorites) but it doesnt seem as graceful as it could be.

2005 Bottle.  Lots of sweet bubble-gum vinous notes in the nose with a hint of of booziness and a bit of caramel-cereal maltiness.  Smells like a barleywine.  Transparent orange-copper color with a frothy light tan/orange head.  Starts a bit sweet, with a bit of booziness in the middle.  Finishes very smooth, roasty, and caramelly.  Dry Saaz hops are also present in the end.  I must say that I was skeptical of this beer at first, but they have done a good job of hiding the alcohol as well as maintaining the characteristics and the integrity of the style.  Well done.
This beer tastes more like an IPA to me then an Oktoberfest/Märzen so it has a grapefruit rind palate component, however it is mixed with some notes of caramel and orange spice.

2005 edition.  Clear, opulent and magnifying copper-orange in color with a few dusty concentrations for the head.  Aroma entices with peppered grain, caramel, rye, flame licked hazelnuts, cedar, vanilla, black licorice and a touch of canned sweet corn.  Imperial Oktoberfest indeed.  Flavor grabs that caramel and toasty signature qualities and amplifies the shit out of it.  Strong caramel and almond extract impart a quality as if theyve been lacquered onto a porous wooden park bench.  Spiciness is dialed up a notch as well, most prominently prickling with peppered and floral phenols.  Stinging sensations all the way home.  Full-bodied, given the style, with a syrupy viscosity.  Substitute the word "balance" for "malts, malts, malts" and we have an accurate recording on the congruency, which, in turn is paired with respectable noble hopping.  Boozy, with the tongue sonorously pressing against the roof of the mouth time and time again to gain a more accurate comprehension of what this mother lager truly is.  Toned toffee and butterscotch with rye comprise the finish, moving into peppered bread aftertaste.  Well done, Avery.

Pours medium red brown with nice off-white head with fair lacing.  Nose is floral and fruity with hops.  The flavor is complex, creamy and fruity, almost no smokiness, alcohol to the fore.  Long lasting caramel aftertaste.

Tap at Papago. Decent sweet malty aroma. Dark amber body with small head. Malty backbone with the alcohol hidden till the beer is gone, alcohol kick about 1/2 hour after this one. Smooth on the palate decent beer.

Dark copper pour with some initial active carbonation which leads to a pretty big head right off the bat.  Malty aroma with some dough and light vegatable that I always associate with marzens.  Take in a few more sniffs and you can tell that this one has some heat in it.  Mouthfeel has a yeasty creaminess, even from the bomber.  Mostly malt taste with some caramel, dough, dried fruit perhaps plum in there.  Some of the flavor is lost when the alcohol burns off your taste buds.  Hops evident in the bitter finish, but still predominantly malt.  I guess if you want to be a stickler to the style, I think an Ayinger still wins, but this is more what I would prefer as an oktoberfest.  Its not about good beer per se... if it were they would be drinking IPAs :D  For the style its pretty interesting.   With three bombers of this in me, I could take over all of Europe... something the Kaiser never quite managed.
UPDATED: OCT 27, 2005 The Kaiser - is so smooth and sweet as well.  This is a great beer on tap thats for sure.  Had it out west -- wish I could get it on the east coast

2005. Clear copper colored body with a tan bready head.  Super sweet aromas of corny malts, sugars, sticky pancakes and syrup, and some hay and grains with a little overripe apple as well - basically smells like a malt liquor.  First touch on the lips there’s some hop action noticed, then everything gets enveloped in a sweet, thick, sticky wheat, grain and bread flavor.  The palate notices a bit of the hop character - it’s fairly dry, almost repugnant for a marzen.   Comes across as an abrasive, overhopped malt liquor, and while it’s drinkable, it certainly isn’t anything I would want to drink again.  No thanks.

Greens Beverage, Atlanta, Ga. - 22 oz bomber. Sparkling dark copper appearance with a sticky, frothy slightly off-white head, good sticky lacing clings to the glass. Aroma is not as prominent as I would have hoped - some sweet molasses-like notes, sweet bubble gum, but not very pronounced. Flavor has some sweet caramel notes, toffee, some roasted marshmallows.  Very thick mouthfeel for a lager. Overall, an interesting and refeshing take on an Oktoberfest - a style that gets slighlty boring by the end of October!

Copper/orange with a good tan head.  Good lace.  Really nice nose with caramel, toffee, courant and orange.  I liked the caramel and toffee taste.  The alcohol is very well balanced.  Great caramel mouthfeel and so smooth.  The alcohol is present but in a good way.  Very impressive beer in my opinion.  Nothing like its German counterparts but very interesting indeed.

Poured from 2005.I dont know how to describe the color.Kind of coppery/ that burnt orange GM makes.Has hops on the nose and definately on the taste.Had a slight sweetness to it but towards the end there was some spice.The alcohol was present but didnt overwhelm.Another winner from Avery.

Draught @ Papago(Oktoberfest).  Pours dark brown/amber, thin light tan head,  and light lace.  Aroma was strong and jumped out of the glass.  Full of dark syrupy malts, spicy and juicy hops in the middle and finish.  Medium/heavy body. Drinkability is lower because of the richness of the beer. Alcohol masked very nicely.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2007 Now this is the beer for Celebration!
The malts and hops blends almost perfectly. Taste of caramel and toffee with the hops of an IPA. Not for beginners, purists take heart!

22oz bottle 2005. pours a lovely deep dark golden color. thin white head dissipates quickly. smells malty, hoppy, sweet with a light roastieness tastes very nice. smooth malt and hops you can taste the alcohol but i like it. smooth mouthfeel at first followed by a dry bitterness that encourages you to drink more. really quite good.

Gorgeous copper colour. Thick head recedes to lasting 1/4". Good malty nose although not overly strong. Very good malt and hop flavour. Alcohol is present but part of the balance. Hops are strong but the malt is stronger and keeps them in line. Very quaffable for a big beer. Much thanks to Legion242.

Very coppery amber color, nice but head and some lace.  The aroma is sweet, a little spicy and floral, with a malty background.  The malt really begins to come through when  I take a sip of this one.  Its malty, sweet, and a tiny hoppy finish.  The body is medium, not thin or too heavy either.  I like this...and now Im gonna finish the bigass bottle!

The fact that this is an Imperial Oktoberfest gives it an extra point in the overall score. Suddenly...an Imperial Berliner weisse doesn´t seem that far away.(Or what do you say Mr. Brown?)
Dark amber in colour, thick white head. Sweet, buttery, slight almondy nose. Bitter, nutty, slight alcoholic flavour with some hoppiness. Sweet in finish.
Whats not to love of a beer called The Kaiser?  Deep golden color, slight tan head.  Good malty smoothness with caramel flavors and flowery nose.

2004 Bomber.  Beautiful clear deep copper pour with a 1/2" beige head.  Nice intricate lacing as it went down.  Sweet caramel aroma with hints of pumpkin spice and some floral hops.  Full flavor with some initial bitterness, a sweet caramel base, and some floral hops, autumn spices, and alcohol toward the finish.  Very nice transition through the palate, and a sweet warming finish.  Very good brew all around!
Malty,caramely,mildly hoppy copper colored. Very tasty. Better than most Oktoberfest beers. For 9% this stuff goes down too easy.
Bottled (8.9%). Dark copper colour, small creamy beige head. Hops and citrusfruit in aroma. Caramellish sweet flavour along with bitterish fruit. Small peak of alcohol in finish too.

rating #400.  pours like a thin liquid copper.  aroma of caramel and some pumpkin spice.  flavor is of caramel and spicey hops, slightly sweet on the lips with some alcohol noted.  palate is a bit thin.  certainly not a bad beer, just not quite as good as I expected.

Bottled, alc. 8.9%, vintage 2005
Copper brown, small tanned head. Flowery hoppy, a bit malty aroma. Medium-bodied, a bit sugary, hoppy with a sweetish aftertaste. Not much to do with the original oktoberfest-style anyway.

(Stockholm Beer Festival 2005) Amber, offwhite head. Nutty aroma, some almond, malty and also a bit sourish. Malty nutty flavor, some almond, some hops and some alcohol. Never heard of an "Imperial Oktoberfestbier" before, but it was a quite nice experience...

(bottle sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival) Dark golden with a low bubbly head. Sweet malty aroma of nuts, caramel, molasses and brown sugar. Smooth malty flavour burnt sugar, vanilla and notes with a light undertone of grassy hops. Long sweet malty aftertaste.

Yet another mediocre offering form Avery.  Very thick pour but quite filtered from the look of things.  Slight bubbly head hangs around for a short whilte.  Nose is moslty malty.  Pretty thick to drink brew, with malt acting as the main flavor stay, but the hopage also making its impact.  Nothing really noteworthy coming out of the bottle.

Out of the bottle it pours thicker than your typical Oktoberfest.  Yep, same copper tone and foamy head.  Drinks like liquid caramel.  Very sweet.  Theres no way to guess that this is up near the 9% range: smooth, smooth, smooth.  Serve to an unsuspecting friend (or somebody you want to get to know better).  Somewhat spicy notes in the hops almost bring this brew altogether in one finely balanced creation.  Still, its pretty much dominated by the malts, which make the hops their Fräulein.

2005 - 22oz. bomber. This one pours a lasting thick head. Color is clear copper. Aroma has faint hops, but lots of toasy, malty scents.  Flavor comes on very strong, starts malty and a bit chewy, and the hops give it more bite than the style allows, then the finish is dry and a bit overpowered by the alcohol. This is a huge beer, way off tilt for an Octoberfest, but enjoyable nonetheless.

Imperial is right!  I wouldnt see it posible to drop more than a couple stiens of this.   I cant remember a marzen with this hop profile.  The malt and spice give it balance, but this is a style known to be unbalanced on the smooth matly side.   Apples and nutmeg are trying to cut through the leafiness, but just dont get there.  An solid bull-like brew, to be treated with caution.

Pour is a nice deep caramel color with no head.  Aroma is a huge mix of toasted malts, candied apple and oily hops.  Flavor is malt, caramel, candy cane and dose of hops.  Very pleasing on all levels and even the alcohol makes a warming presence.  I surrender to the Kaiser!

this is a style that i dont normally rant and rave over, but this is quite the exception to that.  this was a damn good beer, rich malty and refreshing.  no alcohol presence at all.  a little hoppier than most oktoberfest brews ive had, but this was still probably the best example of this style ive ever had.. awesome beer.

2005. Copper/amber. Thick, bubbly light tan/off-white head. All malt aroma- some subtle hops also. Big hops up front and then the malt smoothes it out. Very thick for lager, but still goes down easy. Finish is dry and crisp with some alcohol and the hops surging back at the last second. The more of this I drink, the easier it goes down. Dangerous. Very good, probably my favorite Oktoberfest.

Rating # 830
 Vintage 2004
The body is a beautiful hue of amber and chestnut; and the head is resilient, tall and khaki. The aroma and flavor beautifully convey luscious submissions of toffee, molasses, and mouth watering caramel apples rolled in diced peanuts. You know the candy Sugar Daddies, well somehow Avery fit a couple sticks of those into this bottle as well! Also, wonderful suggestions of brown sugar, date sugars, plums and brandy soaked cherries. A year later and the hops are still holding strong; spicy, woodsy and rather citric with suggestions of orange peel in the finish. The palate is both sticky and chewy hints of multi grain cereal in the beautifully rounded finish!  
A wonderful beer indeed! I just bought 6 bottles of 2005 for my cellar

2004 Bottle (really thought I had a 2003 but oh well).  Had this tailgating at Auburn this weekend.  Poured a great looking amber color with a little head and light carbonation.  The aroma is malty with minerals, and fallish spicy hop hints.  The flavor is malty, burnt caramel and molasses.  Well balanced hops (pine I would say).  Crisp in the beginning but becomes thick and heavy in body (a bit too much for me) and a bit dryish towards the end.  Really a nice fall beer.  Drinking this on a cool autumn day is very pleasing.
Draught at Tylers in Durham, NC. Clear amber color. Nice malty nose and flavor. Alcohol and caramel are also prominent. Somewhat spicy. Moderate carbonation. A good beer.

Fruity, slightly sweet berry malt aromas with typical German malt flavors and a distinctive yeast character.  Amped-up malt and alcohol profiles make for a thick body with a strong, slightly bitter malty alcohol profile.

Deep red-maroon hue with tinges of orange. Tall, creamy, off-white head with some large bubbles.  Good lacing to boot.  Huge biscuit and toasted bread malt aroma.  Layer upon layer of floral and herbal hop notes.  Other aromas of cinnamon grahm cracker and a touch of pepper and alcohol.  Not that style matters here, but I dont find the aroma to be that far off the mark; not quite toasty enough and a little too hoppy, but nice nonetheless.  Heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter flavor.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter finish.  Light alcohol notes.  Medium-full body, creamy texture, near fizzy carbonation.  Good malty sweetness and a bit too much bitterness, but its really the tingling acidity that breaks this one for me.

Petes Wicked was my entree into the world of beer and Petes Oktoberfest was the first marriage of my favorite season with a beer that reflected it in color and character. Since then I have always loved the arrival of the beautiful and wistful Oktoberfests just as the air started to cool and the leaves became brilliant.
After drinking bigger and more complex beers I began to find the Oktoberfests to be thin and one maybe two dimensional. The Kaiser has redeemed the style for me in artfully intensifying without blowing out of proportion all the malty, sweet, spicy aspects of this seasonal brew. To acheive this complexity without becoming something altogether different is masterful. Thanks to Avery for bringing me back to an earlier stage of beer appreciation.

Clear, copper-y appearance, lush head, cream-toned and rocky. Quite attractive in the glass.
Aroma speaks initially of caramel and nuts, then spices and dark fruits, malt is on top with a whisper of hops. Finishes its display still full of character, before mellowing out.
Taste: Massive presence in the mouth, chewy and gooey maltiness, a well-rounded sweetness. Almost ponderously thick on the palate. Primary actors from the nose step onto the tongue and please the senses there. The fruitiness, the herbal/ nutty thing, but mostly the caramel malt. Full bodied, with a long, spicy, dry finish. Loving it!
This is a fresh 2005 edition, and the abv listed is 8.9%. The alcohol comes to the fore after 1/3 through the bottle, and begins a slight burn, but the taste is terrific, so it only adds to the excitement. 
A real acheivement by Avery, this big, ballsy brew. Im pointing all my thumbs upward in its honor, and will now lay back and luxuriate with the remainder of the bottle.
Malty lager lovers, and Oktoberfest freaks, this is your commander, bow down before him!

Looks  normal enough, slight gold to amber color looking dense but not thick if that makes any sense. Medium sticky head shoots out aromas of fresh well water, and the well just happens to be in the middle of a field of green barley. Hop vines encircle the field. Awesomely smooth flavor with some very nice honey flavors (lets say clover and fireweed 70/30) in the finish. Any German brewery would be proud to offer this up but theyd probably just call it a doppelbock, either way its right up there with my other fave nitro powered Octoberfest, Autumnal Fire.

Oktoberfest squared! All of the malty wonder of a top-quality Oktoberfest but at a far greater intensity. The beer pours a deep copper, with a nice head that dissapates slowly. The malt in the nose is accompanied by hints of alcohol, and the hugely malty flavor is followed by a nice hoppy finish. The mouthfeel is just right--not watery at all, and the only drawback was that I had only bought one bottle!

Imperial Oktoberfest sounds like an oxymoron at first, since how can a style known for high drinkability be melded with the group of styles that are known for massive assaults on all senses?  To find out I had to pop the cap off of this Avery seasonal arriving newly in Georgia.

After the 22 oz. bomber was uncapped, and the beer poured into a mug, the look was similar to a standard Oktoberfestbier, but just a shade or two darker.  The head was two finger tall, and lacy, and the most impressive part of the look was the sloooowly rising tiny bubbles through the thick and viscous body.  The aroma was quite unlike the real biers of the season, with a really massive bouquet of hops greeting me at the first whiff.  There were also the Avery signature alcohol fumes.  With those two smells assaulting my nostrils, this brew did not do much to distinguish itself from the other big offerings from the Boulder brewery.

The taste was also hop dominated, however the malts did put up quite a Kampf here.  The richness and intensity of the alternating malt and hops flavors reminded me a lot of a barleywine.  The hops were peppery, pungent, and citric, while the malt was juicy berry, red delicious apple, and brown sugar flavored.  The mouthfeel was thick and hairy like a German barmaid raised on a steady diet of Bratwurst.  A definite sipper, this one was nothing like a Märzen made for gulping.

Imperial Oktoberfest = Dopplebock + Hops

This beer was different for an oktoberfest.  it was stronger than I was used to in an oktoberfest, but that was offset by the caramel flavor and great smell!  this was a well done beer by those great people at Avery!  I will be having this one again!  cheers!

No head, dark cloudy red. Smelled sweet with strong caramal scent. Full bodies, medium texture with a lively carbonation and  malty finish. The taste had hints of toasted malt and caramel. Nice alcohol bite at the end.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2005 2005 Bottle and tap at Flying Saucer.  Awesome brew.  Pours a golden amber with a nice lattice of lace.  Aroma is faint, but has a tinge of sugar.  Flavor is sweet with cotton candy and strawberry.  Palate is thick and coating.  Grrrrrrrrrreat beer, but not yer typical Oktoberfest.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: This was a great beer. The deep amber was cperfect for this beer. Hoppy, Malty with a nice bite of alcohol.  This one is one for the record books.
The aroma is malty with a slight floral hint.  The beer pours a golden brown with a nice white head.  There is a taste of malt with strong overtones of hop bitterness.  The finish is astringent.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2005 From a 22-oz bomber purchased at Sun Singer in Champaign IL
 What the great wide-open hell is an "imperial Oktoberfest" anyway? Has the word "imperial" simply become synonymous with "high gravity version of" whatever style follows the word on the label? If so, I suppose this beer is close to the mark. It is a complex dark, rich, sweet malty lager. Where it misses the mark, as Avery does with many of its products, is with its unpleasantly astringent  hop flavor that is exceptionally aggressive for the style. Oktoberfests, of course,  typically have a low to moderate hop profile, letting the complex malts do the heavy lifting. This beer is WAY too hop-forward for the style. This is a decent beer, but not an Oktoberfest -- imperial or othrewise.

Pours a clear deep orange/red color with a small white-bubble head. The aroma is very enticing, with clean malt, hops, and alcohol. The taste is clean malt, big alcohol with a bitter hop/alcohol finish. This one is a little young and hot but I think it will age very well. WHen I think about what an "Imperial Oktoberfest" would be like, this is it.
Wispy, soapy head. Wonderful malt nose and palate. Extremely smooth. I, too, cant imagine why this style needed to "imperilazed", but it kinda works. Good on ya, Avery.
Clear  orange red with a creamy head and lacing. Slick mouthfeel with sharp hop and alcohol bite. Its very hot.  Good malt background.  Very nice beer.

Thanks Santa!  Nose is brown sugar, plum, tobacco, slightly vinous with rich red malt.  Golden copper body with a thin tan head.  Flavor is sweet caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits, tobacco, slightly woody.  Reminds me of a nice old ale.  Ill admit that Ive been scared off of Averys big beers in the past but this one rocks!

Bottled, thanks JCW! Pale nut brown. Orangey hop aroma. Sweet with fairly soft mouthfeel. Crystal malt flavours alongside tangerine and coffee, as well as strong notes of alcohol. Sweet and almost sticky. Pretty good beer, but about as far away from an oktoberfest as you can come when talking about lagers.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 2004 bottle at The Avery Experience.  Pours copper to amber with a rocky tan head; spotty lacing.  Citrus pine hop and sweet sugary caramel malt aroma.  Dry pine hop and an alcohol caramel malt finish.  Spicy and warming medium bodied palate.

01/28/2008, 2007 vintage: Nutty, banana bread aroma with hints of alcohol.  Mixture of spices completes the unique and mystical aroma.  Flavor is warming, spicy, and full-bodied, bread-like with banana and caramel, cookie notes.
B ottle poured copper with an amber head. Aromas of sweet fruit, and malt. Flavors of carmel, a bitter fruitiness, a hint of bread with a somewhat bitter aftertaste.

Full bodied, full flavored, full throttle - but I dont fully understand. I mean, its uber fun and all. The label w/ Kaiser and helmet was half the fun. I really enjoy Avery and wouldnt wish for them to curtail experimentation at all, but for some brewers this means hit or miss. This wasnt a big miss for me, but a bit of a mess. Malty and just over the top in a way I didnt appreciate. I dig an IPA that goes overboard or a barleywine, but maybe Ive been injected by the Reinheitsgebot virus.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2005 (22 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with goldtwins, thanks Larry!) I know that many breweries are trying to "Imperialize" their beers, and I’m definitely on board with this trend, but I just think an Oktoberfest is a somewhat subtle style that shouldn’t be a victim of this "supersize me" mentality.  Adding more malt makes it too sweet and too heavy, and additional hops makes it far too bitter to be an Oktoberfest.  Just make a good Oktoberfest, is that too much to ask?  Anyway, this is a very flavorful brew, but it just tastes too sweet and caramely, too bitter, too alcoholic to even be classified as an Oktoberfest.  Honestly, the bitterness is just too much period, and rather than tasting hoppy, it’s rather astringent and harsh from start to finish, but especially in the finish.  Alcohol is overdone, burning, way too hot, bordering on toxic, but this has been aged for several months, so what’s the deal?  In the end, it just doesn’t taste very good.  The palate is pretty heavy, somewhat sticky and cloying, despite the bitter finish.  The nose is lightly caramely, but actually very much dominated by a pleasant, sweet fruitiness.  Surprisingly, alcohol seems pretty minimal in the nose.  Deep, ruddy amber in color.  Light tan head rises to a respectable size, nearly an inch, and shows decent retention, never fading less than a full, thin layer.  Lacing is modest, leaving a few uneven rings with sporadic patches.  While it smells and looks appealing, I hate to say it, but this is not all that pleasant a beer to drink.  Just too harsh in flavor and on the palate.  Gotta know when to say when, and in my opinion, Avery has far exceeded the bounds of this style.

Gorgeous reddish orange body with smallish white head.  Mild, fruity/spicy aroma, that reminds me of a barleywine.  In fact, the beer reminds me of a weak, watered down barleywine.  Heavy on the spices and malts.  Caramel and dates, figs and some hearty hops.  This beer is interesting, but it is not quite delicate enough for an oktoberfest brew.  Astringent and alcoholic finish.

Copper color, small off-white head - mostly caramel in the aroma, with background herbal and floral notes - cloying sweetness, offset by a somewhat out-of-balance hoppiness - marzen is a rather subtle style, and one that doesnt seem to take to being a "big beer" very well - sometimes you need to know when not to make a huge beer.
this is a good beer, it poured with a small head, decent smell, good strong alcohol taste, drinkable.

Bottle.  Amber body with off-white foamy head.  Very nice aroma, 
chocolate and caramel.  Flavor is pretty much as the other American
oktoberfest beers that I have had, but just more of everything.  It was
interesting to note that it seemed to really be drinkable, and the abv is
not very noticeable (no alcohol burn).  I think this beer is slightly dangerous
because of that.

22 oz. bottle. Dark amber color. Medium sized beige white foamy head, strong lacing. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar and sweet. A medium to full bodied Imperial Octorberfest/Marzen. Malts are fruity, caramel and sweet. Slightly bitter hops. Lots of sweet, caramel, bready malts. A big bold Marzen, lots of flavor. Slight touch of alcohol bite at 9.3%. A big ramped up Marzen. Kind of interesting, subtle. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a touch of alcohol.
Very hearty.  Sweet and delicious.  This is a strong beer but infinitely drinkable.  Many levels of spices and hoppiness.  Avery knows how to make beers strong as hell.

This review will be short and to the point.  Imagine your favorite American Oktoberfest.  Now imagine those same rich malts, caramel sweetness and hops coming through at twice the flavor.  Now imagine it also has twice the alcohol.  Faithful to the style, just on steriods like the other heavy Avery brews.  Another fine job.

Copper appearance with a nice lingering head. Taste is sweet and somewhat robust with the alcohol making its presence known in the aftertaste. I found this to be pleasant and drinkable and a nice experiment in the style.

Deep orange body with a light slightly yellowish head. The aroma is deep malty oranges with some bananas and vanilla. The taste is brad with some pears and slightly spicy cinnamon. There is also a dry character of apple cider. Complex and interesting. I thought this was a little big, but what else would I expect from Avery.

Thanks to Zathrus13 for the bottle.  Pours a pleasing orange red color with a slight haziness.  Sweet hop aroma complemented by tinges of muted hops.    Thin white head dissapates quickly.  Rather malty nose, followed by a blugeoning sweetness.  Very syrupy, crystal malt and caramel notes abound.    The finish has alcohol dominance, with residual spiciness and floral tones from the hops finally coming through.  Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy.  Lacks a semblance of toastiness that I would normally expect from the style.

Sounded too interesting to pass up since an Imperial Oktoberfest is not something you come across every day. 22oz bottle with a picture of a Kaiser on the front. Appearance is a deep amber body with a tall off white head. Nice rings of lace were left decorating the glass as I drank this. The aroma of sweet malt and a bready smell masked the alcohol almost completely here. Still not a very complex smell. Malt sweetness dominates the palette along with a warming alcohol presence. A bit of a spicy sweet after taste lingers around for a bit. Mouthfeel is medium and almost full, definitely the thickest of the style I have had. Drinkability was fairly good, this is not where near a favorite style of mine but this is one I enjoyed. I would say give it a shot if you come across this.

22 oz. bottle.  Bottled in 2004.  Hazy reddish/brown iced-tea-looking pour with small light-sandy head.  Malty, caramel, apple cidery aroma with hints of spices.  Very malty and sweet with a spicy, tangy and bitter kick at the end.  Fairly bland with some caramel.  The high ABV is only marginally noticeable and warming.  An unusual oktoberfest for sure.  Tastes like a watered-down barleywine.  Unique.

From the bottle this pours a very clear amber with a small white head. This brew was just swimming in alcohol in both the aroma and flavor. Aroma has a very sweet caramel malt kick. Taste is very warming with lots of sweetness throughout, never really captured any of that oktoberfest characteristic in my opinion, maybe a lagered barleywine, i was expecting more of a toasty malt body without massive alcohol flavors and sweet syrupy flavors.

Nice looking carrot orange and amber body, slightly hazy. Head is rather large, fluffy and light brown. Fresh scent is all hops with pineapple and copper pennies.  Taste is watery and could benefit from some carbonation. Taste is thick and syrupy, like an oddly hopped barleywine.  Biting hop flavors, pine and metallic, on top of honey, leather and banana esters. Aftertaste is pencil shavings, metal and burnt sugars. Alcohol level is medium for a big beer. Overall, a beer with fresh ingredients but that is really not that great. Just because it has a flashy name and bottle doesnt make this a great beer. It needs better flavor continuity and a removal of the harsh flavors.

22 oz bottle:  Lasting off white head on an orangey amber body.  Hops seem citrusy and a little piney as opposed to floral or spicy. Perfumey alcohol, weak toasty malt.  Bland aroma to say the least.  Well balanced at first w/ some weak malt flavors.  Light grapefruity citrus hops flavor & bitterness into the finish & aftertaste that is resiny hop.  Too much bitterness IMHO.  Alcohol is a little hot, fuller body, astringent from hop bitterness, Medium low carbonation.  Imperial Octoberfest...Why??????  I dont see the point of taking a perfectly good style and making it bigger!!!  Not a favorite of mine.

Pours orange and hazy (though it is chill haze and goes away after it warms) with a thin off white head. Slighty tart aroma with some bread and apricot. Big ol body with a clean and spicy bitter finish. Flavors of yeast, caramel, malt. I had strong reservations about this one and it sat in my fridge for a few weeks but it is a sucessful experimental beer. Should maybe be lagered for a few monthes though to smooth out the rough edges..

Coppery amber body, nice soapy tan head. Buttery citrus hop aroma. Light, sweet buttered rye bread citrus hop taste. Pretty well balanced bitter/sweet, however much hoppier than a standard Oktoberfest. Like BBB63 said at a Tosa Tasting, "you give this to a German and he will shoot you in the face!"
a very nice deep amber greets a tasty bitterness, followed by sweeter aftertastes and subtle hints of honey.

Poured an amber color with a medium white head.  Malty aroma and flavors but not sweet.  Moslty caramel.  Problem is the lack of balance from the malt not being big enough to handle 9+%ABV.  The alcohol dominated too much.

Imperial oktoberfest eh?  Intersting gimmick.  Reddish orange color with a white head. Hoppy, fruity(cherry) aroma with some toasted malts, and also sugary notes.  Lots of malts in the taste, but with a big kick of hops, some carmel and a bit of alcohol as it warms.  A gimmick yes, but it tastes good none the less.

I am a big fan of the Czar and was looking forward to this bottle.  The Kaiser is a reddish orange beer with a frothy off-white head.  The nose was of alcohol and orange peel, which surprised me for an octoberfest.  Lots of malty sweetness in this beer but way too many hops to be an octoberfest (it reminded me of the Three Floyds in that respect).  Orange peel and apple sauce flavors with a long lingering bitterness.  Good beer but definitly a style buster.

Fairly rich amber hue with a modest head and lacing. Aroma-fruity-plums, raisins, a hint of lemon, a little boozy. Medium + in body and marzen like in the malt dept-caramely and lightly toasty but with considerably more hop bitterness and a noticable alcohol presence particularly in the finish. Seemed awkward. Not your average Ofest for sure but worth a try for big beer fans.

Appearance: clear copper color.Thick creamy looking head.  so-so lacing.  Aroma:  I must be on crack.  The first aroma hint I got was of jalapeno peppers.  Also smells like the sweet georgia tea that Kevin brought to work.  Bonus aroma points for originality.  Palate: sweet, mild spiciness, fresh and clean.  Flavor:  sweet georgian tea, mild pepper.  Thanks Chuck!

pours a nice copper color w/ a laced b ig white head.  smelled of weak malt, barly, a bit odd floral/citrus.  Palate is carbonated, a little thick, not very creamy though.  Flavor is a bit to sweet maybe some candied oranges in it, a bit of sweet tea,  a weak floral hop finish, and some sweet malt overall a deent beer but nothing that special.

22 oz bottle passed around and swigged from with ClarkVV, tiggmtl, Rastacouere, MartinT (just kiddin bout the swiggin).  Bright, clear red with a decent lasting head...malty, faintly almandine nose, simple/sweet but also faintly astringent as it warms...sweet front, malty and thick body starts out fine but grows quite alcoholic and bitter at the finish which doesnt work in this beer for me.  No thanks.

2004 bottle at the 3/6/05 Montreal tasting with Tiggmtl, MartinT, Muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.  Very brilliant, orange color with some copper-brown hues throughout.  Clear, as weve come to expect from this brewery. . .Beige head sticks around for a while and then is gone, never to return.  A difficult beer for me to rate objectively, because ever since I heard them release this, I was pretty angry about having them call it an Imperial Oktoberfest.  Call it a doppelbock, or something.  Hell, its not that far off from Smuttonator.  Which immediately makes you think hops.  Yes, the hops are here in force.  Bitter, resinous, overhopped flavor and aroma, with caramel malt backing quite nicely, giving it a respectable body.  Slightly chewy/sticky mouthfeel and a big candied-orange flavor, with plenty of sharp citrus notes.  Finishes with floral hops, caramel covered oranges (made that up) and a faint nuttiness.  I have no patience for overhopped beers, regardless of the type of hops.

Sweet nutty marzipan with a fair sweet maltiness and a hint of alcohol in the aroma.  Clear amber-copper with decent cover of tan head.  Strong alcohol, orange-citrus hop flavours are fairly dominant over a light caramel/toffee malt body that feels a bit too thin to support it.  High carbonation makes this one feel a tad gassy.  Bottle (trade Dec. 2004) enjoyed with ClarkVV, MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.  Thanks, Kawa!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2008 The Lure:Grapefruit and pine cream agreeably blends into an oily nuttiness. Smells bigger than your typical Oktoberfest, but not overdone in any way.

The Festivities:A touch of caramel and peppery yeast swings into an orangey, resinous, green hoppy ending. Alcohol is pretty well-hidden and the body possesses a few cute love handles. Addendum: a 2-year-old bottle stayed its ground nicely.

Transcendence:An apparently  sturdy general on the outside reveals a thoughtful and caring personality.

Orange hue displays red hints. White cover. Very oily aroma, nutty, fuelic hops/alcohol blend a la Stone. Very sweet yet very hoppy creates a condensed nut oil, almond skin like flavour. Heavily oily and foresty hops of a brend I dont really like, peanut like. I can see myself enjoying this with a decent toasted malt background a a 90degrees turnover from those American hops to a noble hallertau like variety, the Avery yeast makes it feel pretty hot and fuelic a bit like hog heaven I find. Highly carbonated, thin-medium body. Not my type.

Bottle:  Nice aroma of caramel, toffee, fruit and some citrusy hops.   Pours a real dark hazy amber with an off-white head with pretty good retention.  Great lacing.  Very malty.  Lots of caramel, brown sugar,  and fruit.  Definitely a spicey finish with just barely an alcohol presence.  Hops linger in the background and really blend mix well. Somewhat bock-like.   An excellent Oktoberfest.  Probably the best Ive had.
Pours a rich copper with firm head. Malty aroma with light hints of toast. Body is medium with a solid malt backbone. Relatively smooth finish.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2012 2012 Version:
Great roasted malt sweet nose.  Wonderful big flavor with a smooth finish.  


Previous Review: 2005 Bottle
Sweet malt and hoppy.  Pours a dark honey colore.  You can really taste the alcohol and a heavy sweetness.

Clear deep copper coloured body with reddish highlights and a nice off-white head that fades quickly. Aroma of strong malt, caramalised sugars, nuts, fresh hops and citrus. Throw in just about everything and you get this aroma. Truly a delight for beer lovers of any style - nicely done! Medium-bodied; Strong malt, hops and bitter nuts dominate the taste. Leaves the mouth dry and full of malty flavours. Aftertaste shows the hops, alcohol and malt very well. Overall, a bit strong for the style and perhaps too overly done. Regardless, still a good beer that is much better than a lot of other average beers. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 21-January-2005.

Deep copper, pretty head, nice and firm.  Considering how much sugar was probably pumped into it to get it this strong, the nose is expectedly sweet, lots of caramel but not much in the way of typical bready/biscuity marzen character.  Alcohol is noticeable there, and its very noticeable in the flavor.  Well, its not really all that noticeable because the nasty sweetness kind of overpowers everything else.  My teeth hurt, it was so sweet.  It tasted like a marzen mixed with a cheaply made sweet liqueur of some sort, like sugared, alcohol-ized fruit.  Too much burn at the end.  I enjoyed this beer amazingly little.  Oh, and its not a freakin marzen.  I dont care whats on the stupid label.

Really a beautiful beer in the glass.   Rich, copper and clear.  Aromas are bread and malt, with a bit of floral wafting up.  In the flavor, however, the yeast is not as big of a player.  The interplay of malt, hops, and alcohol give The Kaiser a triple punch.  The palate doesnt blend these flavors, rather, they arrive one after another.

Sampled at From The Vine beer tasting Jan 14th, 2005: Pours a hazy orange-amber color with a thin off-white head. Minimal lacing. The aroma is sweet caramel and malt. Medium-bodied with flavors of toasted malt, caramel and piney hops. Alcohol is pretty well-hidden too. The finish is lightly spiced and hoppy. This is a pretty good Oktoberfest, but I am not convinced it is deserving of slapping an "Imperial" tag on it just because there is more alcohol in it.

Small sample from bomber at From the Vine beer tasting in Lewis Center, Ohio.  Light golden; big head.  Aroma caramel, hops, and alcohol.  Flavor has sort of a "flat," not-so-sugary-sweetness to it; mostly hoppy, a bit malty.  Slick and smooth.

The only imp. o-fest i have ever tried or heard of. Looks like any other o-fest beer, brownish with a tiny head. Aroma even resembles an o-fest, caramel, skunkiness. Taste hits you hard. Big sweet flavor throughout with a mild alcohol kick at the end.

Dark amber with no head. Sweet malty caramel aroma with a slight hint of hops. Flavor is just about the same except for sweet aftertaste, that leaves you wanting more. A beer that could creep on you for sure. A little surprised at the average, I must say.

Orangey amber in color with a modestly dense, off-white head.  Aroma is deep, rich caramel and an oily alcohol note I find common to high alcohol lagers.  Flavor is very full-bodied (it gets you here and it get you here).  Some earthy, plummy notes along with toasty caramel, a rather strong hit of hop bitterness, residual sweetness, spicy/perfumey hop flavor, and a dose of warming alcohol surrounding everything.  I like this but I still prefer a well-made, traditional gravity Octoberfest better.

Poured a cloudy amber with virtually no head. Light banana aroma, candyish. Fairly sweet on the tongue initially followed by a mild alcohol finish. Mostly malty and maybe a  little one dimensional but still a nice beer that packs a punch.
Decent Marzen style although a little more on the hoppy side than usual.  Upfront malt with a dry finish.  A little too much of a fench rider for me.  More contrast than balance.
Dark amber color with no head.  Very malty aroma, followed up by a pretty boring malt taste.  Its a good Oktoberfest, bur really isnt offering much else.
Hazy red color with nice caramel aroma. Flavor is sweet with a perfect marriage of malts.Alcohol comes on late and finishes strong but does not overwhelm the finish. Really nice beer!

Glassy red color and a nice thick head on top.  The smell is an acidic malty one, reminds me of green olives a bit.   The flavor is a really good balance of sweetness and malty heartyness.  The alcohol is not really present until the last bit, where it leaves a little tingle on the mouth.  The flavor has a leafy heft to it, and ends with a sweeter side.  Quite a nice brew, but I think Im a bit partial to anything with the word Imperial in it.
Pours a hazy amber with a small white head and little carbonation. Aroma has a nutty caramel scent. Flavor is sweet and malty with a warming sensation down your throat. Alcohol is well disguised.
