Red Coloring with Big White Head.  Wonderful Oktoberfest Brew!  Lots of Warming to This one as Well.. Makes Detecting Other Flavors Hard With the Alcohol...But Theyre Also so Well Balanced..Theres Nothing That Particularly Stands Out.  Avery is Making me a Lover of Their Brews!
pours a clear copper color with small even head.  aroma is really nice...a nice mixture of malt and hops.  flavor is really balanced between all the ingredients.  this is an intesting style.

Clear amber brew with a sizable layer of creamy foam.Nose is a large dose of toffee and even a little grain/earthy aroma,not to mention a sweet hopiness to it.This was good as the balance between the flavors was well done.no one flavor outdoing the others.Sweet and delicious.

Thanks to MrFacto for sending this one down to Tennessee!
This pours out a deep, rich, dark amber color and as I pour it, I can see it has plenty of body as it builds a nice thick off white head.
Mellow maltiness in the aroma with a bit of yeast that is very inviting.
This has a good Oktoberfest flavor to it with perhaps a hint of alcohol, otherwise its just a good Oktoberfest all the way.  You could call it a Bocktoberfest I suppose, the lines get fuzzy when you have something like this, but its a flavorful well crafted beer whatever you choose to call it.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2007 An Impy OktobeerFest Hmmm??? Got this from  jimmack04 At the first NJ ratebeerians meeting Dec8th. Large head, could be my pour, but it is hanging around with good lacing. Deep redish orange color.Aroma of strong hops and spice and malt. Sweet but a strong alcohol taste in the back as well. My mouth is watering as the flavor linger and mellows. This is excellent.

Pours a deep amber with a fluffy white head. Aromas of munich malts and spicy saaz hops. Very typical Octoberfest qualities until you get to the flavor department. Way too sweet. A descent hop bitterness but not enough flavor to balance out the huge sweetness. A very typical Avery character to. Certainly differentiates itself from a doppelbock, Ill give it that. What will be next, an Imperial Mild Ale?

Brilliant pour, massive carbonation slowly rising to the top as it helps build a solid tan head.  A very nice clear amber beer.  Nice smooth roasted and sweet malt aroma. Medium to full body with creamy malt that also ranges from roasted to sweet.  A nice fruity taste at the front of the mouth really sits on teh touhg.  This beer is built very nicely and fits together quite well.

Clear golden amber with thick white head. Lager nose, w/light carmel, pillowy malt and delicate quality of peach on the nose. Med weight with sweet mid and slightly drying finish. Carmel, light hops, toffee, sweet malt and delicate hops. I LIKE!

Beautiful clear ruby with a thick beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt and plenty of hops. Taste has notes of heavy caramel, roasty malts, brown sugar/molasses, dark fruits and wood. Very well hopped and sweet with an alcohol presence. Slightly roasted and bitter finish. Silky smooth mouthfeel with sublte carbonation which coats the mouth very nicely. Great lacing and head retention. Nice stuff.

i think calling this an oktoberfest is a stretch, but i guess its the closest style there is--its too extreme, too hoppy for the style but its still really good.  tons of dark malt, but it feels like theres an abundance of cascade hops that gives the palate a slight tang.  very good beer.

Okay.  This beer brings up the style v.  sheer goodness debate.  This is absolutely not an oktoberfest.  It tastes like Averys IIPA, just with slightly different malts.  A few oktoberfest malts do not an oktoberfest make.  Other than that, its a tasty, though supremely one-dimensional beer.  HOPS!

Bright, clear red with a thick, tan head.  Big, warm nose of sticky caramel, alcohol, whole grains, earthy, noble hops, toffee, toasted bread, and some noticable spiciness.  The body is full and rather robust, especially for the style.  The flavor is nice, starting sweet, becoming warm at the top and finishing with an earthy, spicy bitterness.  Not really my favorite beer, but Im glad I got to try it.  I prefer my Oktoberfest beers to be less intense.  They should be well balanced and highly drinkable.  This is good but will not be a regular at my table.

Poured dark orange/amber with a tall white head that left a lacing on the glass.  Very strong aroma, with a nose of oktoberfest maltiness mixed with a distinct hoppiness.  Taste starts off with sweet oktoberfest malt with the usual seasonal spiciness, but fades into a doulbe IPA hop character.  Alcohol well-hidden.  Very complex, and the best oktoberfest Ive had.

I know they get a lot of criticism as being a marketing gimmick, but I tend to love "Imperial" versions of beers.  Imperial Pilsner?  Sure!  Double Helles?  Why not?  So when I saw Avery with an Impy Okto, I was excited.  And apprehensive.  After all, just because it is imperial doesnt mean its good.  This, however, did not disappoint.  Clear copper, touch of ruby and orange, slender head that fades completely.  Aroma is fantastic, some caramel malts mixed in with a lovely nose of floral hops.  The flavor changes over time.  Initially when cool, the malt start is caramel accented, with a floral hop finish.  As it warmed towards room temperature, roasted coffee notes began to emerge from the malts, while a well integrated earthy hop flavor showed on the finish.  Full bodied, luscious, and throroughly enjoyable.  This was a fun, interesting beer, one of the best Ive had in quite some time.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 2005 bottle sampled 1/17/06: Clear orange copper pour with a thin-lacing, frothy off-white head.  Rich, sweet malty and strongly noble hopped aroma has an enticing balance.  Good fresh citric hoppiness melds well with the amount of sweet, sticky caramel malt.  I like this vintage better than the 2004.  A very nice "imperial" style brew.

2004 bottle sampled 11/24/04: Pours a rich copper brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is full of sweet German caramel malt and a touch of hoppiness.  Body starts a sweet and viscous blend of caramel and toasted malts.  Finishes more dry and hoppy with more of a bitter US hop presence.  The malt billing here seems to be right on par with what I would consider an imperial oktoberfest, but the hops exert more bitterness than Id prefer.  Still a nice and interesting brew.

An orange-amber beer with a huge orange head. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel as well as hints of hops. The flavor is dominated by alcohol, that runs over the tongue, but also has notes of hops and caramel.

Bottle: Clear ruby orange with light tan head that quickly fades to a very thin ring around the outside of the glass.  Aroma: Sweet aroma, caramel, alcohol, light raisin, sweet grapes, mild citrus and grass.  Taste: Initial sweet caramel and hop bite, then the alcohol comes through a bit with some citrus, mild grapefruit, lemon, orange, and some caramel, bread, and a touch of spicy/sour yeast.  While I enjoyed it, Im not so sure this style works(tastes like a double IPA with mild hops)....credit for trying though.
candy/cherry malt aroma, transparent ruby, candylike and caramely alcohol dominate with a slightly bitter finish, a tad leathery

Bottle poured a clear redish amber with an average sized creamy off white had that lasted quite a while.  Excellent fine lacing as well. A fairly heavy piney hop aroma.  Flavors were nice dark malts and fairly sweet with a significant alchol taste as well.  Average carbonation and a nice finish.

Clear dark amber colored with a thick light tan head. Sweet in the aroma, malt, hops and grass and little alcohol. Rather heavy. Also sweet flavor with a nice bitter finish. Malty and hoppy and a dry end. Warming from the alcohol. A nice beer and my first Imperial Oktoberfest which is cool to try!

Ruby red color, foamy head, nose of cobwebby laagered malts. Crystallized malts, strong alcohol mouth feel but smooth malty & brown sugar notes. Not quite an Oktoberfest but taste. More like a barleywine lager. Figs & pear. Thanks Eric!

Mahogany with a thick, white creamy head. Light citrus aromas containing lemons and orange. Malty and mellow. A slight hint of medicine. Bitter hops with a very malty body of caramel and roast. Pepper and another spice comes through. Alcohol. Very sharp bite at the end making the beer slightly acidic to me. Champagne mouthfeel as it was rather well carbonated. Ends with a bitter maltiness.

Bottled: Amber coloured. Clear. Beige dense head. Very malty and sweet aroma. Aroma is very well hidden. Flavour is sweet as well, and has some hoppy and herbal notes. Is dry and has alcahol notes. Ends on a light bitter note and with a light alcaholburnt. Im not 100% convinced that making an imperial or barrel aged version of all beersstyles is something good, but for sure some funny beers is made. This is one of them.
Pours dark clear amber body, medium fluffy white head. Hoppy nose, backed up with some servere fruityness. Some alcohol in the flavor, hops and nice bready malts. Good one.

This is one BIG beer. It tasted more like a dopplebock than a Marzen. Burnt orange in color with an ample tan head, the huge malty nose gave away the alchohol content right away. Bready and sweet throughout this is an extreme version of the style. Very tasty, but somehow not very refined.

Poured caramel color with nice big ivory head...smell is sweet with alcohol, caramel, dough, and some strange spice...taste is very malty upfront with toasty sweet flavors swiftly followed up by intense hop bitterness...finish is dry at first with sweet alcohol finishing it out...I agree with TChrome, this is an Oktoberfest, but about as extreme as it gets...

This really does seem to be an Oktoberfest albeit one pushed to the boundries of any kind of style definition.  Beer pours reddish amber with a big fully retained off white head.  Aroma is BIG.  Notes of sweet, bready malt, alcohol, and nectar.  Flavor is also big, but a bit more restrained than the aroma.  Flavors include sweet bread, caramel, bit of hops in the finish, some alcohol warmth on the way down.  Enjoyable and very adventerous on the part of Avery.  Thanks Kevin42!!

Bottled. Acquired in a trade with joeybgood. Thanks Joe! Bronze nody with a medium tanned head. Nose is Light alcohol, sweetened notes, light fruit, malt, and some decent hop character. Taste is stronger malt and alcohol. More upfront fruits, hops, light caramel and light bisuity flavors round this out. Faint spice as well, perhaps. Body is medium with a decent alcohol warmth and mild stickiness. Finishes with mild hop bitterness, some more alcohol notes, and caramel. Good beer!

American Strong Lager here we go... Sparkling clear dark amber with very lazy bubbles and a dense manila head. The aroma is sweet malt, crystal as well as some organic earthiness. So far so good. Alcohol really comes through in the flavor, whoa! Good amount of hops in this one also. Sweetness is there but the alcohol is big. Fairly quick finish, a good amount of bitterness throughout, not as full bodied as I had imagined it would be. Interesting beer that stands well on its own, though it is not an Octoberfest by any real strethc of the imagination. I think of Octoberfests as delicate, this is anything but.

i really enjoyed this beer...great amber red color...thin head; great aroma- a strong fruity alcohol smell (strawberries galore); flavor complemented the smell; a little strong in terms of the alcohol flavoring, but abundant in hops, fruits, and spices; i really enjoyed this beer

This doesnt really work for me.  Pleasant appearance (clear copper-orange body, thin/medium cream head) and a very interesting aroma- fruit (akin to strawberry syrup, as badnewsbeers suggested), honey, soy and strong alcohol notes.  The flavor was a bit of a let-down, however.  The best Oktoberfests have layered breads and caramels that engage all parts of the tongue, but the toast and hints of caramel The Kaiser offers were quickly subdued and overwhelmed by the surprisingly noticeable ethanol flavors.  The quick alcohol "hit" prevented the beer from developing any complexity.  In the end, this tastes like a ballyhooed malt liquor, despite the inviting aroma.

Clear amber with medium beige/orange head.  Aroma is medium sweet, earthy, caramel, some syrup and light alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, earthy, some orange, pine, finishing alcohol and light metallic.  Full body that holds the alcohol well, rather drinkable for the ABV.  As it warms, it takes on more barleywine characteristics -- sweet alcoholic maltiness takes over.  Nice beer, but I wouldnt call it an Oktoberfest.

Rusty color. huge malty, alcoholic nose with orange peel and toasted aromas peaking through.  Cinnamon apple nose once it is room temp.  Huige body, malty and thick, almost like drinking wort in the middle, malt is sticky and outrageous.  Blocks out most of the best features here, including that toasty malt dryness and flowery, heathery hops.

This brew pours with a deep amber body topped by a medium thick head with good lacing.  The aroma and flavor are sweet and malty with a little candy sugar, a touch of caramel and a little hoppy bitterness.  Medium to full bodied, smooth and a touch dry.

Pours brilliant deep orange color with slight light brown/tan head.  The effervescence is mesmerizing to watch in the glass.  Nose is malt, caramel and winey, yet somewhat spicy.  Flavor is big, chewy with  a touch of bitterness.  Alcohol has warming sensation which lingers for a while.

#1100.  Pours clear orange with touches of ruby and a huge, creamy ecru head.  Aroma of malt, hops, fruit, toffee.  Tastes malty, with dark fruit, hops, slight breadiness.  Firm, somewhat dense palate which ends in an acidic, malty finish.  Very well hidden alcohol, but not really complex.  The balance seems slightly off.  I agree with Mike et al about aging this, but I honestly dont know if I can let it sit that long without craving it.  It didnt knock my socks off like I expected, but this is still an excellent, assertive lager.  Cheers to Avery in the innovation department.  As long as they crank out beers like this, Ill keep buying them.  Even considering my listed flaws (which are minor) I still deem this 4.0-worthy.  In a year or two, I suspect this will approach 4.5 or so.

Very floral aroma, German hops, lovely mouthfeel, somewhat stinging, like a strong weed, as if this were "eau de poison ivy", something vegetal.  Red-brown color, good lively head.  Lots of caramel, floral, and latent spice.  I like what theyve done with the Oktoberfest style to give it layers of interest.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007  Rerate #2 , a 2005 two-year bottle. Shockingly a muddled hue with a fading but clinging lace. The aroma is pure caramel and bready malts with some allspice and light cinnamon nose. The taste is sweet but not cloy, there is some alcohol here but it is meshing well into the flavors. Quite enjoyable and SO MUCH BETTER than the other Marzen brews I have had this season. Rerate: A year old bottle that has been aging gracefully in my "cellar". The bitters have mellowed out and the spice flavor seem to meld in a smoother finish. I enjoyed this much more than the 1st time and have change my Flavor and Overall score point each.  Original rating: Bottle: Ruby brown hue with small fizzy but mostly lasting head and good lace. The aroma has notes of caramel, toast, orange zest, aromatic and floral hops, earthy yeast esters, peppery spice, and noticeable phenols. The taste starts with a twangy fruit and sweet malt combination followed by a heavy dose of spice, bitters, and alcohol. Some citric and yeast background for some balance. The feel is aggressive, lively, biting, and a bit metallic. Overall, it is enjoyable but still too young. The hops need to meld into the flavor and the bite hopefully mellowed. Another in agreement to age this, another Avery monster.

Bottle marked Bottled in 2004. Appearance was a smooth medium sized ivory head, good lacing, carbonated, transparent and an orange hue. Aroma was malty, hops and spicy. Flavor was malty, hoppy and spicy with a lingering aftertaste. Tingly and harsh mouthfeel.
Slight caramel malt aroma.  Body is somewhat malty and balances the alcohol very well.  Not as malty as I would have expected, but very smooth none the less.
Clear red color with a big beige head. Aroma of caramel malt. Flavor starts out with caramel malt and finishes with some pretty nice hops.Fairly warming too. This is a great Octoberfest.
UPDATED: OCT 7, 2011 Lovely amber color. Sweetish malt aroma. Flavor is sweet caramel malt, hint of floral hops. Much better than the first time I tried it.

This bottled brew marked bottled in 2004 poured a large sized head of foamy fine to large sized mostly lasting light tan bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body contained average carbonation, was transparent and brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of malty dark malt .  Its mouth feel is initially comes on like gang busters initially tingly harsh vinous hop with a lingering  slightly tingly other palate and a wow the vinous palate really hits strong smooth aftertaste.  Its flavor contained vinuous malty caramel  notes and was a little too harsh for my liking as it spoiled the enjoyment of the beer.  Not one I would buy again.
clear amber, slightly sweet  finish,  sticky on the tongue, medium body. this is a pretty nice oktoberfest

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2004 22oz. bomber:  The beer pours a fairly clear orangish-amber color.  There was only a little head.  The nose is somewhat caramel malt nose.  Also hints of alcohol, spices and floral notes.  The taste is a bit sweet, with some alcohol coming through.  Also some evidence of fruits and spices.  Good, but a bit rough around the edges.  I agree that this could age a bit to smooth it out.

Bottle. Deep orange color with a malty nose. Has a great floral hoppy finish. There is some spice there-kind of like cloves/black pepper/anise, put not quite. Some lemon zest/citrus notes on the finish.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2004 04 Bottle.  Clear red body, light tan head.  Very effervescent aroma - seems like alcohol combined with spicy hops.  Otherwise theres a bready sweetness in the aroma.  Big, unrefined flavor and mouthfeel.  Its a jamboree of roasty caramel malt and vinous, spicy hops.  I was excited about this after the first few sips but now Im realzing its just another overdone big beer.  Others have mentioend this beer would be a good canditate for aging and I think theyre right.  Id give it a year or more.
Sweet, caramel nose.  High sugar, apple, and carmalized brown sugar tastes.  Alcohol comes through pretty well.  Very thick, and a nice orange color.
bottle.  amber color with thick off-white head.  good lacing.  has a taste of hops but alcohol taste follows....a little much for me.

Bottle.  Pours a brilliantly clear red-amber color.  Big off-white head is long lived.  Great lacing.  Sweet malt aroma, some hops in the nose.  Hop aromas are mainly floral and earthy as advertised.  Taste is a nice balance of malt and hops.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel.  Very nicely done.

Brown-reddish color with a small tan head.  Sweet caramel aroma with notes of hops. Alcohol is ever present in this beer. Bold strong body that says,  I am the one and only.  I dont think the hops are over the top but the abv is  a little much.  Still a nice and zesty oktoberfest which should be admired and feared throughout.

Dark copper orange red with a big tan head, great lacing.  Aroma is sweet smokey caramel fruity and some earthy hops.  Body is thick, as I was expecting, given its huge abv (for a Fest, anyway).  Smokey burnt caramel sugar malts paired with earthy floral warm hop balance.  This seemed to be heading towards Bock territory.  Dangerously drinkable - I had little inclination as to the abv here.

Pours a brilliantly clear, ruby-amber-copper color.  It is topped by a frothy white head that is generated by a medium level of carbonation.  The aroma is sweetly malty with notes of caramel, biscuits.  It also has a low level of hop aromatics that contribute a slightly fruity note intermingled with a spicy-herbal-grassy note.  This beer is quite thick bodied and sweet, but the thing that I really notice during my first sip is how hoppy this is.  It is quite a bit more balanced towards the hops than even a doubling of a traditional Oktoberfest recipe would suggest.  Leave it to the American brewers to hop up a traditionally malty beer, though as a pioneer of the Imperial Oktoberfest, I guess they can do what ever they want.

Given all of this, this beer would actually not be as interesting or balanced if not for the over-the-top hops.  The beer is quite sweet, and would likely be sticky if not for the hop punch.  The beer has a pungent, spicy, bergamot, herbal hop flavor to it, which floats on a malty backbone that is redolent of caramel, and biscuit notes.  The finish is a bit astringent, with a mixture of hop bitterness and alcohol.  This thing could definitely use some mellowing.  If it were not for the finish this would be at its best now.  I think a couple of months of age, could really help to mellow this beer out.

The new glow / appeal of this beer has definitely faded for me, now that I have finished half a glass.  The beer just seems a bit too harsh and unbalanced.  I definitely recommend aging this for quite a while, I have two more bottles which I will perhaps try again in the spring.

10.08.04  Standard Avery foil capped bomber with a crazy, shiny label.  The pour is a light caramel-copper color with a medium sized, quickly fading head.  Aromas are malty and sweet as a marzen ought to be; light flowery hops; slight hints of salt and pepper; nothing over the top.  Flavors are certainly floral and sweet with a nice biscuity malt.  An odd combination of sharp hops and honey thick mouthfeel make this an experience like no other oktoberfest.  Im not totally convinced that this was the best idea...a sipping beer, but in a true session style.  I guess I just dont get it.

color is mostly clear orange with slight reddish notes. head is thick and creamy, almond colored. has a sweet toasted caramel aroma that i love in an Ofest. alcohol is high, but completely undetected by my nose. alcohol again is virtually non-detectable in the flavor. there are toasted notes, mild toffee and the slightest alcohol burn.  very tasty, not an alcohol monster as i expected.

bottle. pours a red hued deep brown, has a very thick light tan head. grass and some kind of wood(walnut?Pecan?)are present in the aroma. taste is surprisingly smooth for the ABV of this bad boy. strong spicy malt flavor with a very strong hop presence. sticky mouthfeel that reminds me of of a chocolate malt with too much syrup. there is a very slight taste of caramel that i am noticing in this also. alcohol lingers a bit on the finish of this, that is the only hint that shows up that would make someone wonder how much alcohol is in this. an interesting brew, that i have enjoyed immensly.

22 oz bomber-pours a nice ruby red hue with an off-white head that was gone in an instant.  noble hops, grassy notes,  big surupy german malts and alcohol.  Big spicy hops presences in the flavors along with lots of hot alcohol llike the Beast toned down. a little rough around the edged, but lets see how this one ages.  Averys beers are always clean, but they need to mask the alcohol better on these big brews.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2005 Deep Copper.

Unpleasant, medicinal aroma, with notes of cherries, popcorn, butter toffee, mixed nuts and spicy floral hops. 

Enormous malty backbone of dark fruitiness (grapes, red apples), caramel and toffee. The hops are spicy, moderately bitter, unexciting and floral. A hint of mixed nuts, green plants and butter are present on the finish.

Dark copper brown with great lacing. Aroma is malty, smooth and hopped-up. The flavor is extremely hoppy followed by a malty sweetness. Too much hops. Hops. Hops. Hops. Heartburning hops. Enough already. Not much room for oktoberfest in this bottle.  Its been hopped beyond recognition.
Medium amber with a thick head.  Sweet, nutty toffeeish flavor with notes of caramel and some hops.  Nice and warming with a smooth silky mouthfeel and a dry finish.

Clean but complex aroma, hazelnut, caramel, pine, hints of citrus.  Brilliant copper color, thick frothy head, gorgeous.  Full malty flavor up front, with an herbal, piney hop flavor coming through in the middle, even balance, with toasty malt and piney hop flavors lingering in the finish.  Creamy and full bodied, with a little warming in the end.  An interesting invention by the folks over at Avery, definitely worth trying.

Interestingly powerful aroma, plenty of sweet, toasty caramel and cookieish maltiness alongside the strongly fruity, flowery hop presence, and with some fainter notes of earth, pine and alcohol. Deep reddish copper color, clear and filtered, with a finely creamy head leaving some fetchingly delicate lacing behind.  Flavor profile is profoundly sweet and sugary, abundant light brown sugar and caramel but brewed with a correspondingly large dosage of hops -- fruity, leafy and lightly spicy, and with a lightly warming, lingering malt finish.  Alcohol is quite apparent once the beer warms a bit, and it packs the associated punch.  Palate is smooth, effervescent and thick, a touch fiery, with a decidedly full body.  Overall, about as was expected; it is interesting to sample this the first "Imperial Oktoberfest".  Cheers, Bert!

Pours a deep amber hue with a small off-white head.  Aromas of roasted malts, dough, and a little wheat.  Flavors of roasted malts, a light spice,  a slight bitterness and some caramel.  Probably the best example of the style, and one of the better brews from this brewery.

Deep clear amber color with a small off-white head that leaves some lacing in my glass. Bready, spicy candy like aroma, Fruity caramel and nutty flavors. Full bodied with a thick almost syrupy mouthfeel, finishes sweet. More like a dopplebock than an oktoberfest, I had no problem finishing the 22 ounce bottle.
A very nice oktoberfest style brew from Avery.  Full flavor and body, with a nice color and head.  One of the better Oktoberfests around.

Bottle pours a translucent reddish copper, large eggshell colored frothy head, low carbonation, with spotty lacing. &nbsp Sweet hop, slight pine, malts, flowers, and even some pixie dust on the nose. &nbsp Flavor is of sweet malts, slight charred wood, a bit of hops, and grapefruit. &nbsp Good body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes with a spiced up maltiness. &nbsp More hop bitterness than the usual style, but its quite refreshing for a change. &nbsp Quite unique it is. &nbsp Thanks goes out to pdee for the trade!

Great big frothy light tan head which lasts for a while.  Light carbonation.  Nice sheet of lacing covering the inside of the glass.  Spicey and hoppy aroma.  Light grapefruit and a bit of flowers.  Hops is dominant over the malts.  Color is a nice deep amber.   Decent amount of malts in the flavor but I expected more from a marzen.  Good hops balance in there also.  Somewhat light and crisp taste.  More spices, some alcohol and a touch of citrus.  Finish is slightly bitter and warming from the 9+% alcohol.  A good beer that pushes the limits of the style.  A little bit hoppier than a typical oktoberfest but still good.

Pours copper with a nice beige head.  Of the several beers of this style at this tasting, this was the best.  Nice complexity in the nose with caramel, berries, floral, spice.  Balanced carbonation and texture gave it a good mouthfeel.  The flavor was more what I consider a good Oktoberfest/Marzen to be like.  Avery has done it again.

A rubbery, plasticy, alcohol laden aroma with some woody spiciness greets you - German, yes, but also piney elements. The body is slippery, lagerlike, but still, thinner than that (the alcohol?). Caramelly, big time - burnt plastic with a barky pine - this is like an Imperial Alt, maybe, with a few Centennials thrown in the kettle. Hard to judge, frankly, given the 9% plus, and a pretty fatiguing sweetness at the end. Even though I like it, and I like experimentation, I suppose I like my lagers pretty trad - for example, its hard to get the Hallertau here. Fuddy duddy, signing off...
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: 9/19/04:  Bottle. Malty, alcoholic aroma.  Ruby-brown bodied with very little head and no lacing.  Pronounced malt flavor with other evidence of caramel, alcohol and a touch of hops at the finish.  Pleasant ending which is sweet.  Alcohol is well hidden.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2004 A small tan head sits above a deep copper color.  The aroma is sweet malt, brown sugar, with a bit of hops and fruit. The taste is what you might expect, an amped up Octoberfest. The sweet malt and brown sugar are followed by hops, and a bit of bitterness at the end. The body is on the heavy side, but not too much to make it unpleasant. All in all, very intesesting.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 Beaming orange copper. Tight ivory head deposits webby rings of lace. Tangy roast, honey richness, varnish, and floral hops in the nose. Damp wool and honeydew suggestions. Fuzzy, slightly velvety carbonation. Manageable thickness. Opens with bold earthy malt layers with a sweet alcohol tailing. Alcohol gradually intensifies, climaxing at the center and amplifying the commanding hop bitterness with hints of medicine and raw cane sugar. Earthy roast fails to mesh with the hops, but theres plenty of redeeming bright mineral qualities and clean airiness underneath, which offsets the figgy malts. Medicinal flavor resurfaces late, erasing much of the remaining hoppiness. Slight roast astringency in the finish, with a clean, underlying lagery mineral note, fresh, but subdued, hops, and vaporous blasts of alcohol. Bready, leathery malts and minerals linger. Surprisingly complex, yet subtle enough to retain its drinkability throughout the glass. This is much more than the novelty I was expecting, and for their first venture into the land of lager, my hat's off.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Avery puts out another goode brew.  Hoppy, malty, and some roasty flavor. Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2005 Rate 2005 This is a for real marzen.  Orange to bronze in color and very carmelly, thick and sweet.


his is an interesting beer.  Bronze colored, translucent, pours with a moderate tan head.  Aroma is carmel and of Noble hops.  This beer reaks with Saaz, some much so that it dominates the carmel body similiar to the way a pilsner might.  Flavor is bitter and slightly sweet. Roast flavor is non-existent, ant the hops are over the top.  Having said that it isnt a bad beer in its own right, just deviates significantly from the style.   Finish is fairly dry, especially for a marzen!

This beer should be called a bock, not an oktoberfest.  It didnt resemble an oktoberfest beer at all.  It was a good beer but calling it an imperial oktoberfest is wrong.  It is a nice big slightly bitter bock beer.

Deep amberish chestnut, creamy off white head.  Aromas slowly emerged as it warmed with hints of sweet malts, fresh spiced chocolate and cherry bread, with some light herbal grassy qualities to note.  Malty bready flavors  get balanced out by the spicy hop kick on the backside.   Full bodied, syrupy, prickly carbonation, dry spicy hop finish.  I think they pulled it off nicely.  Keep up the great work.

Amber to brown in color with a smaller light tan head and minimal lace. Definite lager aromas with a touch more alcohol and hops. Touch of ripe fruit also detected in the nose. Thicker lightly silky feel. On the edge of being too heavy, but I like it. My second bottle thanks to a beer exchange artist, which will be keep quiet, and after the first, I thought to myself this is a Marzen Malt Liquor. It has the rich malt of a marzen, but then has the alcohol and mild bite as it warms of a malt liquor. A bit to much for what is to be an easy quaff. But its all about extremes now, right. Imperial this, barrel aged that.  Im dangerously close to a rant. But then again that is what is great about this country (USA), we what what we want, when we want it, and lots of it. Go for it!

Deep Red amber color with nice white foam.  Good lace on glass.  aroma is faintly malty.  Flavor is sweet at first with a good malt kick.  Alcohol is evident in this beer.  Mild hops on the finish.  Good body.  Pleasant, almost nutty aftertaste.

poured a a nice deep amber with a creamy head I do have to say of the beers I have had the re of the amber color this is the best looking of them all. aroma hops, fruity, citus leaning to the orange, floral as it start to warm hints of lemon and the alcohol comes out . flavor malts, orange, hints of grapefruit, and the alcohol comes out just right and it just adds to the good flavors of this good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2004 Bright amber body with abundant carbonation and a soapy but dense off-white head. Rich malty aroma of bread crusts, fruit and nuts. Spicy, cinnamon hop quality as well. Pungent, but nice. Huge malty flavor. Flurry of noble hops in the finish. Metallic, astringency comes into play after a few sips. Thick, oily palate. Noticeable alcohol but not overpowering. This is a belly-warming sipper that gets bigger and bigger as you spend more time with it. Interesting, but not great.
This beer was nice to look at and the aroma was fine, but to be honest, the alcohol taste was just too much.  This is a nice try at a new style, but there is still some refinement before perfection.

Rich brown color with aromas that ranged from roasted malt,, warm caramel, toffee, hops, ripe cherries and dry grapes. The taste is even more complex. Sweet and hoppy, crisp and yet packs a wallop. Other than The Czar, a really fine Avery beer.

Running out of room in the beer fridge but will have to make room for a case of this one after having my first on Saturday. If you enjoy complex malty beers then this is must try. Hides the alcohol very well, extreamly smooth for  such a young beer and will only get better which is very frightening. Next to the 2001 vintage of Reverend which Avery served up at their 11th Aniversery party last month this is the best beer Ive had from Colorado (been to 20 of the brew pubs here). Cant wait for that Fall chill to roll in to try another. I have 60 or so different beers in the fridge now and while I was drinking this one I wasnt thinking about any of em, well except the ones Im gonna have to pop a cap to make room for this classic.
Bottle. Big malty aroma and flavor. Munich notes all throughout. Excellent. Nice aroma. Rich tasting. Clean finish. Enjoyable.

Damn. This tastes rather like a German Ofest, or maybe Spaten Optimator. Big malty aroma and flavor. Munich notes everywhere. Rich. Alcohol comes through a bit so you know you are drinking something big, but overall the palate is smooth and mellow. Clean finish. I am impressed with the drinkability of this at over 9%.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: The beer after it disemboguing from the 22-ounce brown bottle resides temporarily in my glass a limpid luminous brown with a behemothic creamy light tan head that erodes leaving a thick blanket of lace to obscure the glass. Nose is malt dominated, sweet and fresh to the senses, start is sweet with a delectable malt profile and the top moderate in its feel to the palate. Finish is strikingly acidic, the hops determined in their spicy bite with the aftertaste decidedly dry, another magnificent beer from one of my top ten breweries, and a fantastic label, my kudos to the great people at Avery once again.

More beer labels need the Iron Cross.  Great label.  I like how the huge amount of malt is spread throughout the beer.  It never becomes too much.  That is because the aroma has a lot of spciy hops, which also show up a bit in its flavor.  There is even some very light berry elements.  The body is not too viscous.   The finish is the nicest of all: clean and almost cutting.  Reminds me a lot of DeGroens Doppelbock.  Very good.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2004 This beer may not be a traditional oktoberfest, but it is a terrific beer. Dark
amber/copper with a thick off white head. Sweet malt aroma with a hint of
the alcohol to follow. Tastes sort of like
a cross between an oktoberfest and a
barleywine. Nice malt flavor with a very full body and a slight hop bitterness at the end. Alcohol is well hidden.
(Bottled Aug/12/2004) Very little head and lace. The palate is smooth, rounded, warm, malty, and alcoholic. Long malty finish. Overall, this is a pretty godd Double Bock. Well attenuated.

Large light tan head, good retention and lace. Clear amber/red hued brew, a sight to behold. Malty, spicey hop nose with a touch of honey and alcohol. Medium body, creamy texture. Medium sweet malt body with hints of chocolate, alcohol and a certain fruityness to it. Dry, hot finish. Unfortunately the alcohl is the dominant force in this brew, more so as it warms. Almost a medicinal flavor at the end.

Pours a transparent rusty red with a large head that slowly fades to a solid layer. Aroma is malty, slightly syrupy sweet with a slight but sharp grassy hop kick. Flavor a strong but very smooth and clean maltyness, slight caramel, balanced very well by a spicy, grassy hoppy bitterness. Very tasty but still clean and smooth. The alcohol is well hidden.

Lets start this off by saying this: This beer is NOT a fall seasonal.
It is a "One of". Meaning its only going to brewed once, and thats it. Check their website if you dont believe me. That being said, lets review it. 22 oz. brown bomber bottle, with a silver foil overwrap on the crown. Very colorful label, Iron Cross and all.
Bottled in 2004 date on front label. Poured out a deep copper / reddish amber color, with a huge off-white head that wouldnt go away. It looked like someone spooned whipped cream on top of my beer. Very sticky head, it left a thick, sticky lacing down the sides of the glass. The beer itself is very clear. Aromas are of fresh Munich malts, maybe some Vienna in the mix as well. Earthy Noble hops in the aromas, my guess is Hallertauer or Hersbrucker.
Maybe a pinch of Perle for the bittering. Anyway, theyre spicy, earthy, and slightly fruity. (You cant fool this old kraut.)
Regal tastes of fresh water, fresh malts, and fresh hops. Slight caramel, along with spicy notes mix with the fruity hops to make a wonderful experience for the beer connoisseur. This beer is not to be missed. Smooth mouthfeel comes from the lagering process. Alcohol is fairly well hidden, but makes its presence known as its swallowed. Warming to a fault, this beer would be excellent on a chilly, windy November evening, when the leaves are blowing around, and the Earth is settling in for a Winter slumber. It would warm you to the bones, and take your breath away. Too bad its a "One of", because this would make an excellent seasonal. I know Id buy it again. The finish is smooth, well balanced, and slightly earthy and fruity at the same time. I highly recommend this beer, if you can find it before its all gone. Good luck to you.

Copper color with a small off white head that lasted through the glass, no lacing.  Sweet caramel, banana, bubblegum aroma.  Taste of oak, vanilla, caramel.  Sweet and alcoholic mouthfeel.  Interesting, does not seem to be an Oktoberfest.

The Kaiser pours a reddish amber with a decent light brown head that goes to a thin film and laces the glass.

Its aroma is toasted malt, some spicy hops and some vinous alcohol.

The flavor is sweet (a little too much so), slightly fruity, caramel malts initially, with some spicy hops.  A strong acidic alcohol taste dominates through to the finish.  It tastes a little medicinal - it reminds me a little of cherry nyquil.  It is pretty full bodied and creamy.

I wanted to like this.  I like Avery beers, but this one, like the Beast, disappointed me.  Too much alcohol, too over the top.

Crystal clear, amber lager with a mid-sized, frothy, off-white head. Decent retention and weepy lacework. The aroma is very malty with notes of sherry, cherries, alcohol, caramel and the odd man out, noble hops. The flavor is sweet and malty with some strange notes. I dont know what I dont love about the flavor. The malt profile, the yeast or the hops? There's something off. Not at all bad, but disappointing. Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and very lively carbonation. Lengthy, bitter-sweet finish.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2005 Bottled on 8-12-04(printed on case)Aroma is sweet and malty with some banana vibing yeast and green hops in there(not  of the citrus evoking varietys of coarse).Nice copper appearance with a healthy head,weak lace.A pretty great tasting beer, unique,a must try for Big Beer lovers.Is this thier first lager(it is quite a beast of a lager)There is some nice balance between the thick german malts and the fresh resiny hops.This should age pretty gracfully.A great idea from a great brewery.Finishes clean and dry,and lingers...This beer does take some getting used to(especially for a marzen but some of the qualitys are really there)Alcohol is well integrated and this is really starting to grow on me.Nice creamy mouth with enough hops to create a feeling of balance near perfection.Has a bit of that stringbean vibe in the after taste.I  will be quaffing this more than the rest of the marzens this year.Cheers Avery! on a job well done(I was wondering when they would finally make a lager(especially of this size)(2004 4.2) 
>>>>>>>>Bottled on 8-4-05.This is very dissapointing  and a waste of money(and Im paying at distributor cost)which is 4.67!!  sweet almost cloying Raisiny malts,alcohol,hops not impressive at all,not as much class compared to last years..I dont know,its a good beer but just dissapointing this year.

Another beaut from Avery.  Clear copper body with big head that laces on down the glass.  There is a serious malt presence here, both in nose and taste, that makes the beer sweet and velvety, but the flavor is surprisingly complex.  The initial sweetness gracefully melts into a dry, bitter hop finish. The ABV is hardly noticeable, overall a fantastic brew.

Great head. Aroma is hoppy, dry, hearty, and indicative of lager. Color is a clear copper hue. Very malty, fully body. Taste has apparent alcohol, but balances out quickly. Nice sweet malty feel that fades out with an earthy/alcohol taste that eventually turns dry. Bitterness is kind of in the background the whole time. Interesting beer, to say the least.

Regardless of whether or not the high ABV is proper for the style, this beer rocks!  It tastes like an Octoberfest should taste like.   Nice flavor  with a bit of hop and a great alcohol warmth without the nasty flavor of too much alcohol.  Just right for a cool October evening on the porch.  And it looks wonderful, great lacing and a nice, lasting head over the traditional O-Fest color.

Every time Avery comes out with a new beer its like Christmas, and when I look down into the bottle, I might as well be looking down the barrel of a brand new Daisy Red Rider BB Gun with a compass in the stock. The Kaiser isnt just another tie or some lousy socks, either. Its yet another shining star in the Avery Milky Way. The beer pours clear and has an amber-red glow with a light tan head. Chewy, inviting nose. Un-fricken-believable mouthfeel -- extremely creamy and fluffy, as if youre swallowing a cloud. Malts had notes of dark toast, toffee, and a little chocolate. Malt-lovers shouldnt be disappointed. Hops were very balancing and complemented the malts well. Bitterness level was fitting and not over-the-top at all. Gentle notes of oranges and flowers. Kind of spicy and peppery, too. Alcohol wasnt really noticeable when drinking it, but it sure left behind a cozy warmth in the ol esophagus. Great stuff! The real Christmas is gonna have to step up to compete with this.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2005 2005 bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is clear dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), moderately hoppy (apricot, orange, flowers), with a note of peach. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Full body, creamy/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.  A marked improvement over the 2004, the 2005 relies more on the malt in its nose and doesnt clobber with sharp piney hops. Still cant say its German in character (sorry guys...its very nice, but Id never guess from the aroma that it came from a German brewery, nor that its German styled).  Where the 2004 most resembled an American Strong Ale (based on its strength and hop character), its now more like an English Strong Ale...apricotty/orangey (British-smelling) hops, thick/juicy/sticky malt that reminds me of Maris Otter, what can I say?  But Im not complaining, just describing.  Its a big strong malty beer, lager or not, and as such its very luxurious and delightful.  Thumbs up overall.  Nice improvement, guys!

2004 bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is clear dark amber. Aroma is moderately hoppy (resin/pine, apricot, flowers), moderately malty (cookie). Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, creamy/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. The aroma is surprisingly docile for as big a beer as it is, and sadly not very German in nature (despite the use of German malt & yeast, Hallertauer Trad & Tettnanger hops)...it has that familiar pine sap/resin "green hop" twang that grates on me. Belches confirm its quite American in nature where the hops are concerned. And the malt character isnt nearly as toasty as the better Oktoberfests Ive had...its kind of ordinary in that aspect. And despite knowing this is a lager, I would still put it in the American Strong Ale category...it smells like one and tastes like one, and frankly cant think of a better style on this site for it. But my main disappointment is only in the aroma; it looks nice, has good balance (very drinkable at 9.3%, and although leaning to the sweet side just a tad too much, its not fatiguing), and a luscious mouthfeel. Overall, this misses the target IMHO, and doesnt really resemble a German Oktoberfest (even a strong one). But as an ASA, it works just fine. [score = 3.5]
